Just as a cook might measure the age of a cake by counting the number of days since it was baked, tree rings can be counted to determine a tree's age. The newest ring is at the outside of the trunk and each year another ring is added towards the center. By counting these rings, we can estimate how old a tree is.	tree's age calculation	Explain tree's age calculation using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 counting tree rings
The tree's age calculation is like a cake recipe. The recipe has three parts: the ingredients, the cooking time, and the cooling time. The ingredients are mixed together and put in the oven. The baking time is set and the cake is cooked. After it is taken out of the oven, it needs to cool down before it can be eaten. In the same way, a tree's growth can be divided into three parts: its ingredients (the environment), its growing time (the years it takes to grow), and its cooling time (the years after it grows when its size doesn't change).	tree's age calculation	Explain tree's age calculation using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cake recipe
Cooking analogy for glycolysis: Glycolysis is like the cooking of a small piece of meat. The meat is chopped into small pieces and then put into a pan with some oil or butter. As the meat cooks, it begins to release juices. These juices flow out of the meat and mix with the fat or oil in the pan, creating a sauce. In glycolysis, glucose (the meat) is chopped into small pieces and then put into a cell with some oxygen (the oil or butter). As the glucose cooks, it begins to release energy. This energy flows out of the glucose and mixes with ADP (the fat or oil), creating ATP	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking a small piece of meat###| glucose | meat###| oxygen | oil or butter
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose into two molecules of pyruvate. This can be thought of as cooking a pizza. The first step is to heat up the oven and put the pizza dough on a baking sheet. Next, you spread sauce over the top of the dough. Next, you add cheese and toppings to your liking. Finally, you bake the pizza in the oven until it is cooked through. In glycolysis, glucose is heated up (energized) and split into two molecules of pyruvate. The sauce represents oxygen atoms which help to break down glucose into pyruvate. The cheese and toppings represent nitrogen and carbon atoms from pyruvate.	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking a pizza
Cooking analogy for glycolysis: think of the sugar in a cake as glucose. The cake is made up of many small cells, each cell containing a little sugar. When you put the cake in the oven, the heat starts to break down the sugar into molecules called monosaccharides. These molecules are then able to move around more easily and enter into the cells of the cake. Once inside the cells, they are further broken down into even smaller molecules called ATP (adenosine triphosphate). This process is similar to what happens during glycolysis - glucose is broken down into smaller molecules that can enter into the cells where they are further broken down to create ATP.	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 breaking down sugar into molecules called monosaccharides###| cake | small cells each containing a little sugar###| oven | heat starts to break down the sugar into molecules called monosaccharides###| ATP | adenosine triph
If you've ever tried to stir a pot of soup or sauce and had the spoon hit a hot spot, causing the liquid to fly up and then quickly fall back down, you've experienced anti-stokes scattering. The same thing happens with light: when it encounters a hot spot (an area with a higher concentration of energy), some of the light is scattered in all directions. This causes photons to be expelled from the hot spot at high speed, only to be pulled back in by the surrounding material.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 stirring a pot of soup or sauce
When you cook something in the oven, the heat from the oven will cause water to evaporate. This is because hot things emit energy in the form of photons that are hotter than the surrounding environment. These photons cause molecules in the food to vibrate and this vibration causes them to break away from each other. The process of breaking away from each other is called scattering. Anti-stokes scattering happens when a photon hits a molecule and it absorbs energy from the photon and then emits a new photon that is cooler than the original photon.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 when a photon hits a molecule and it absorbs energy from the photon and then emits a new photon that is cooler than the original photon
If you are cooking a pot of soup on the stove, and you stir it with a spoon, the soup will be more evenly heated than if you just let it sit. The stirring action causes the hot liquid to mix with the colder liquid, so that they both heat up more quickly. In a similar way, when light shines through a suspension of small particles (like pollen in the air), some of the light is scattered in all directions. If you were to look at this suspension straight on, you would see a bright patch where all of the light was coming from directly overhead. But if you looked at it from an angle, you would see darker areas because less light was reaching your eye. This scattering effect is called stokes scattering after Sir George Stokes who first described it mathematically in 1845.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 scattering effect is called stokes scattering after Sir George Stokes who first described it mathematically in 1845
Stokes scattering is much like the diffusion of heat when two objects are cooking next to each other. Just as heat energy slowly spreads out from one object to another, so too does light energy scatter off particles in the atmosphere. The further away an object is from the light source, the more diffuse and scattered the light will be.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 diffusion of heat
Stokes scattering is the process of light being scattered by small particles. This analogy uses cooking to help explain the process. When you are cooking, and a small particle like salt or pepper gets in the way of the heat, it scatters the heat. The same thing happens with light; when it hits a small particle, it scatters the light.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 scattering heat while cooking
A median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. It can be thought of as the equivalent of cooking half a chicken.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking half a chicken
The median lethal dose is the amount of a toxin required to kill half of the members of a tested population. To think about it in terms of cooking, imagine you are making dinner for a group of people and you want to make sure there is enough food so that everyone gets at least one serving. You would start by estimating how much food each person will eat and then doubling that amount. That would be your starting point for deciding how much food to prepare. In the same way, scientists use the median lethal dose as a starting point for estimating how much of a toxin is needed to kill half of the animals in a test population.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 doubling the amount of food for a group of people
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that will kill 50% of a population of test animals in a given time period. This can be thought of as the amount of a substance required to make a pot of soup poisonous enough to kill half the people who eat it.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 amount of a substance required to make a pot of soup poisonous enough to kill half the people who eat it
The universe is like a pot of boiling water. The water is the universe, and the bubbles are the galaxies.	universe	Explain universe using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 pot of boiling water###| galaxies | bubbles
The universe is like a big pot of soup. The ingredients are the elements and the heat is the energy from the sun. The soup cooks over time, and as it cooks, new ingredients are added to it. Some of those ingredients fall out of the pot and become planets or stars. Others rise to the top and become gases or plasma.	universe	Explain universe using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 big pot of soup###| elements | ingredients###| energy from the sun | heat###| planets | ingredients that fall out of the pot###| stars | ingredients that rise to the top
The universe can be thought of as a great kitchen. In this kitchen, there are an infinite number of ingredients and pans and pots and utensils. There is also an infinite amount of space in which to cook. The cooks in this kitchen are the universes creators or gods. They can create anything they want with the ingredients at their disposal.	universe	Explain universe using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 kitchen
Cooking analogy: Enzymes are like cooking spices. They are not the main ingredients, but they add flavor and make everything taste better. In the same way, enzymes help to speed up chemical reactions in the body without being used up in the process.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking spices
Enzyme mechanism can be explained using a cooking analogy. Enzymes are like cookbooks, they provide the instructions for how to make a dish. The ingredients in the recipe are like the substrates of the enzyme. The substrate binds to the enzyme and then is converted into the product of the reaction.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking analogy
In cooking, enzymes are responsible for the chemical reactions that occur in doughs and batters as they rise and bake. Enzymes work by breaking down large molecules into smaller ones. In breadmaking, for example, the enzyme amylase breaks starch down into maltose and glucose. These small molecules then interact with each other to create the long chains that make up a loaf of bread.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 chemical reactions in doughs and batters
There are many different types of anova, but a simple cooking analogy can help to understand the concept. Say you have two pots of soup, one made with chicken and one without. You want to know if there is a difference in taste between the two soups. To find out, you could do a blind taste test with a group of people. In this case, the type of soup (chicken or no chicken) would be your independent variable, and the opinion of each taster would be your dependent variable. By doing this test, you would be performing an ANOVA test.	anova	Explain anova using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 blind taste test
It's like when you're cooking and you have a pot of water on the stove, and you put in two different kinds of pasta. The noodles will cook at different rates, so after a while, some will be softer than others. But if you look at the entire pot of pasta, it'll all be cooked evenly. That's kind of what anova does - it looks at all the data together to see if there are any differences between groups, but it also takes into account how much data is in each group.	anova	Explain anova using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 looking at data to see if there are any differences between groups
A thermostat is like a chef. The chef monitors the temperature of the food and makes adjustments to the stove's heat as needed to ensure that the food cooks evenly. Likewise, a thermostat monitors the temperature of a room or building and makes adjustments to the heating or cooling system as needed to ensure that the desired temperature is maintained.	thermostat	Explain thermostat using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 chef
A thermostat is like a cook who monitors the temperature of a pot of soup on the stove. If the soup starts to get too hot, the cook turns down the heat until the soup reaches a comfortable temperature. Similarly, if your home gets too warm, your thermostat will turn on the air conditioning until your home reaches a comfortable temperature.	thermostat	Explain thermostat using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cook who monitors the temperature of a pot of soup on the stove
A thermostat is a device that regulates the temperature of a system by controlling the amount of heat or energy provided to it. A cooking analogy would be using a stovetop burner to cook food. The thermostat would be like the knob on the burner that you use to control the heat.	thermostat	Explain thermostat using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 knob on a burner
Chemical equilibrium is a state in which the concentrations of all reactants and products remain constant. A cooking analogy would be to think of a pot of boiling water with salt added. The salt dissolves in the water and creates a new equilibrium where both the salt and water are present in solution.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 a pot of boiling water with salt added
Chemical equilibrium is like a pot of boiling water. The water reaches a temperature where the molecules inside are moving so rapidly that they can escape from the surface. At this point, the water will start to boil. If you add more heat, the temperature will rise and more molecules will escape. If you remove some of the heat, the temperature will drop and fewer molecules will escape. Eventually, you reach a point where adding or removing heat doesn't change the boiling point anymore. This is called chemical equilibrium.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 a pot of boiling water
Chemical equilibrium is a state in which the concentrations of all chemical species are constant. In analogy to cooking, it would be like if your food was always at a fixed temperature, regardless of how long you left it on the stove.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking food at a fixed temperature
Cooking analogy: just-in-time is like having all of the ingredients for a recipe on hand, except the eggs. You start to cook the dish and realize that you need eggs. Rather than running to the store, you go into your refrigerator or pantry and get the eggs that you need. The cooking process continues uninterrupted.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 having all of the ingredients for a recipe on hand, except the eggs
In cooking, just-in-time is a philosophy of food preparation that aims to minimize the amount of time between when a dish is prepared and when it's consumed. The same idea can be applied to manufacturing: Parts are only produced as they're needed, rather than in bulk ahead of time. This helps reduce waste and keep costs down.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Just-in-time is like a cook who prepares food as it is ordered. The cook doesn't make a big pot of soup and have to eat the leftovers for lunch all week. Instead, the cook makes just enough soup for one order and then moves on to prepare the next dish.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 a cook who prepares food as it is ordered
Adaptive immunity is like a well-seasoned pan. The first time you cook with it, the pan doesn't taste very good. But after using it several times, the pan becomes seasoned and the food tastes better. Adaptive immunity works in a similar way. The first time your body encounters an infection, your immune system isn't very good at fighting off the infection. But after repeated exposures to that same infection, your immune system becomes better equipped to fight off the infection.	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 well-seasoned pan
Cooking analogy: adaptive immunity can be thought of as a stove. The stove has two knobs, one for temperature (innate immunity) and one for flame intensity (adaptive immunity). Turning up the heat on the stove increases the temperature of the pan, just as turning up the inflammation in your body increases the temperature of your internal environment. The higher temperature makes it easier to cook food in the pan, just as increasing the activity of white blood cells makes it easier to fight infection.	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 stove###| innate immunity | temperature knob###| adaptive immunity | flame intensity knob
Adaptive immunity can be thought of as an oven. The first time you turn it on, the temperature is very high. This is because the oven needs to get up to temperature in order to cook your food. However, if you turn the oven up too high, it will burn your food. So, after a while, you learn how to set the oven at a lower temperature so that your food cooks evenly without burning. This is similar to how adaptive immunity works: our immune system starts out with a strong response (like turning on the oven at full blast), but eventually learns how to respond more effectively (by turning down the heat).	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 an oven
If you are using an oven to cook a pizza, the amount of heat that is applied to the pizza is determined by how big the oven is and how hot it is. The size of the oven determines how much heat can be applied at one time, and the temperature of the oven determines how hot that heat will be. If you want your pizza to cook evenly, you need to set the oven at a consistent temperature so that all parts of the pizza are heated equally.In electrical terms, this analogy would mean that voltage (the size of the oven) would be analogous to wattage (how hot the oven is), while resistance (the thickness of the crust on your pizza) would be analogous to impedance.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking a pizza
If you have an electric oven with a heating element that is turned on, the power (watts) going into the oven will cause a certain amount of heat to be generated inside the oven. The wattage is like the amperage, and it determines how much heat is created. The resistance of the oven walls and door are like the ohms, and they determine how much of the heat created inside the oven escapes. Just as in an electrical circuit, if there is too much current (amperage) flowing through a resistor (like a cooking appliance), it will overheat and potentially damage itself.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 electrical circuit
When you cook with electricity, you use an electric stove. The stove has a knob that lets you set the power level, from 0 (off) to 9 (high). If you set the knob to 9, the stove will generate more heat than if you set it to 0. Ohm's law is like this knob. It tells us how much heat (or electricity) will be generated by a circuit depending on the resistance of that circuit.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 electric stove knob
If you are baking a cake, the recipe is the transcription of how to make the cake. The ingredients and instructions are written down so that someone else can follow them and create the same cake.	transcription	Explain transcription using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 recipe
If you are cooking a dish and need to follow a recipe, you would be transcribing the recipe. Transcription is when you write down what someone says word for word.	transcription	Explain transcription using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 following a recipe

The activator protein is a bit like an oven timer. It starts the cooking process by turning on the heat, and then it turns off the heat when the food is ready.	activator protein	Explain activator protein using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 an oven timer

When you turn on a burner on your stove, electricity flows from the wall to the burner. This flow of electricity creates a magnetic field that causes a heating element in the burner to heat up. The hot element then heats up the pan on top of it, and voila - you have cooked food!	electric circuit	Explain electric circuit using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 burner on a stove
An electric circuit is like a kitchen with an oven, stovetop, refrigerator, and sink. The oven is the resistor, the stovetop is the voltage source (battery), the refrigerator is the capacitor, and the sink is ground. When you turn on the stovetop, current flows from the battery through the resistors in your stovetop to make it hot. This current flow charges up the capacitors in your fridge so that they can keep food cold. When you turn off the stovetop, this same current flow goes through grounding wires in your kitchen to dissipate any remaining energy safely.	electric circuit	Explain electric circuit using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 kitchen with an oven, stovetop, refrigerator, and sink
Cooking analogy: an electric circuit is like a stove. The stove has a heating element that produces heat. The heat from the element flows through the pan and cooks the food.	electric circuit	Explain electric circuit using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 stove
Cooking analogy: The hydrophobic effect can be thought of as the tendency of oils and fats to clump together, while water tends to spread out. This is why oil and vinegar dressings don't mix well - the oil repels the water.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 tendency of oils and fats to clump together
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous solution. This can be explained using a cooking analogy. Nonpolar molecules, like oil, will not dissolve in water because they are repelled by the polar water molecules. The oil will form small droplets that will separate from the water.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking analogy
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in a solvent, such as water. This can be explained using a cooking analogy. Imagine you are making a salad. You have some oil and vinegar dressing. The oil is a nonpolar molecule and the vinegar is a polar molecule. If you mix them together, they will separate into two layers. The oil will form one layer on top of the vinegar because it is not attracted to the water (the polar molecules).	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 oil and vinegar dressing
Cooking analogy: When you cook something in a pan, the heat from the stovetop transfers energy to the food, causing it to cook. The same thing happens with biological signals - they transfer energy to the cells in your body, causing them to respond.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking in a pan
Cooking analogy: Transduction is the process of turning one form of energy into another. In cooking, heat energy is turned into kinetic energy, which causes molecules to move around and do work (e.g., cook food). In biological signal transduction, electrical or chemical signals are converted into molecular movements that result in a specific cellular response.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Biological signal transduction is a lot like cooking. In both cases, you are taking something raw and turning it into something delicious. With cooking, you start with ingredients that are raw and need to be cooked in order to be edible. With biological signal transduction, you start with signals that are raw and need to be processed in order to have an effect on the cell. In both cases, the goal is to create something that is more delicious than what you started with.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using a cooking analogy.	ht	cooking	 cooking

The molecules at the edges of the container are moving more quickly than the molecules in the center. These filaments help to maintain the shape of the cell and to organize the cell's contents.	cytoskeleton	Using a cooking analogy, explain cytoskeleton.	lt	cooking	 skeleton of a cooking pot

A hydrogen electron orbital is like a cooking pot on the stove. The pot is filled with water and is on the stove, heating up. The water is like the electrons in an atom and the stove is like the nucleus. The pot is getting hotter and hotter and the water is boiling. The boiling water is like the electrons in an atom that are getting more and more excited.	hydrogen electron's orbital	Using a cooking analogy, explain hydrogen electron's orbital.	lt	cooking	 cooking pot on the stove###| electrons in an atom | water in the pot###| nucleus | stove

When you cook food, you use heat to kill any bacteria that may be present. This is similar to how the body fights off invading bacteria. Action potential is like when you turn on a stove. The stove has a small coil in it that gets hot when you turn on the stove. This coil then heats up the metal in the pan and starts to cook the food. The action potential is like the coil in the stove. It is a small burst of energy that travels down the neuron and starts to cook the food (the neurotransmitters).	action potential	Using a cooking analogy, explain action potential.	lt	cooking	 turning on a stove
Ribosomes are like the stove in a kitchen. They are responsible for taking the instructions from the recipe (DNA) and creating the finished product (proteins).	ribosomes	Using a cooking analogy, explain ribosomes.	lt	cooking	 stove in a kitchen
The Golgi apparatus is a bit like a kitchen. It takes the raw ingredients that come in from the outside world, and processes them into something that the cell can use. It does this by packaging the proteins and other molecules into small sacs called vesicles. These vesicles can then be transported to wherever they are needed in the cell.	golgi apparatus	Using a cooking analogy, explain golgi apparatus.	lt	cooking	 kitchen

A density wave is like a ripple in a pond. It is a disturbance that travels through a medium. In the case of a pond, the water is the medium and the ripple is the disturbance. Column chromatography is like using a colander to separate pasta from water. The pasta (the compound being separated) is the solid, while the water (the solvent) is the liquid. The colander (the chromatography column) is filled with small holes (the stationary phase), which the pasta passes through while the water washes it away. The size of the holes determines how much of the pasta is separated from the water.	column chromatography	Using a cooking analogy, explain column chromatography.	lt	cooking	 using a colander to separate pasta from water

Cooking a meal is a process that can be controlled to produce a desired outcome. The same is true for many industrial processes. A process control block (PCB) is a tool used in process control to help achieve a desired outcome.A PCB is a digital or analog controller that is used to regulate a process. The controller receives input from sensors that measure the process variable, and then outputs a signal to actuators that adjust the process. The controller can be tuned to achieve a desired setpoint for the process variable.The PCB is a key component of a process control system. The system uses feedback from the process to adjust the controller and maintain the process variable at the desired setpoint.	process control block	Using a cooking analogy, explain process control block.	lt	cooking	 a tool used in process control###| desired outcome | a desired setpoint

The same recipe can be used to make the same cake every time, even if the ingredients are different. The same encoding can be used to send the same message every time, even if the contents of the message are different.	message encoding	Using a cooking analogy, explain message encoding.	lt	cooking	 using a recipe to make a cake

A nuclear envelope is like a kitchen. It is a place where food is prepared. The nuclear envelope is made up of two membranes that surround the nucleus. The membranes keep the nucleus safe and separate from the rest of the cell.	nuclear envelope	What is a good analogy to explain nuclear envelope to student who likes cooking?	lt	cooking	 kitchen

A good analogy to explain Kirchhoff's voltage law to a student who likes cooking is to think of voltage as being like pressure in a pipe. Just as the pressure in a pipe increases the further down the pipe you go, the voltage in a circuit increases the further down the circuit you go. This is why the voltage at the top of a battery is higher than the voltage at the bottom of a battery.	kirchoff's voltage law	What is a good analogy to explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes cooking?	lt	cooking	 pressure in a pipe

The cook can access the cookbook whenever they need to create a meal. The cookbook contains a variety of recipes that can be used to create different types of meals. Column chromatography is like making a cake. The cake batter is the mixture of ingredients that will be baked into a cake. The ingredients are mixed together and then put into a cake pan. The cake is cooked in the oven and then it is ready to eat. Column chromatography is like making a cake because the mixture of ingredients (solutes) are put into a column and then the column is heated. The solutes will move up and down the column based on their size and how much they are attracted to the solvent. The solutes will then be collected and analyzed.	column chromatography	What is a good analogy to explain column chromatography to student who likes cooking?	lt	cooking	 making a cake

Cooking is a process that involves the transfer of heat from a stove to a pot of food. The stove is the source of the heat, and the pot is the destination. In the same way, transport vesicles are responsible for the transfer of molecules from one part of a cell to another. The source of the molecules is the cytoplasm, and the destination is the membrane of a transport vesicle.	transport vesicles	What is a good analogy to explain transport vesicles to student who likes cooking?	lt	cooking	 cytoplasm###| molecules | cytoplasm

The plasma membrane has a heating element that produces heat, and the heat is used to cook food. The plasma membrane has a surface that the food is placed on, and the food is cooked by the heat that is produced by the heating element. The stove has a fan that circulates the air around the cooking surface, and the fan helps to cook the food evenly. Action potential is like when you turn on the stove to cook. The stove is like the neuron, and the gas is like the action potential. When you turn on the stove, the gas starts flowing and the heat builds up. When the heat reaches a certain point, the gas ignites and the flame starts cooking the food. The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a reaction. This is the step that determines how fast a reaction will occur. Column chromatography is like cooking a big pot of spaghetti. The spaghetti is the mixture of different ingredients, and the pot is the column. The ingredients are mixed together and then put into the pot. The pot is heated until the spaghetti is cooked. The cooked spaghetti is then put into a colander to separate the spaghetti from the water. The water is the unwanted ingredients, and the spaghetti is the wanted ingredients. The same thing happens with column chromatography. The mixture is put into the column, and the column is heated until the mixture is cooked. The cooked mixture is then put into a colander to separate the wanted ingredients from the unwanted ingredients.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking a big pot of spaghetti
Dynamic chemical equilibrium is like a pot of soup on the stove. The soup is in a state of equilibrium where the temperature is constant and the soup is neither boiling nor cooling. If you turn up the heat, the soup will start to boil. If you turn the heat down, the soup will start to cool. The soup is in a state of dynamic equilibrium where the temperature is constant even though the soup is boiling or cooling.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 a pot of soup on the stove

Cooking is all about ratios. For example, when you are baking a cake, you might use one cup of sugar for every two cups of flour. This is a ratio of 1:2. Glycolysis is like cooking a pizza. The pizza dough is the glucose molecule and the toppings are the pyruvate molecules. When you cook a pot of soup on the stove, the heat from the stove causes the soup to boil. The boiling soup produces bubbles that rise to the surface and burst. The bubbles produce heat and light that we see as they rise to the surface and burst. This is an example of stokes scattering.Now let's imagine that we have a pot of soup on the stove, and we add a few drops of food coloring to it. The food coloring will slowly diffuse through the soup, and eventually it will reach the surface. As the food coloring diffuses to the surface, it will produce bubbles. These bubbles will rise to the surface and burst, just like the bubbles produced by the boiling soup. However, the bubbles produced by the food coloring will not produce as much heat or light as the bubbles produced by the boiling soup. This is because the food coloring is not as hot as the soup.This is an example of anti-stokes scattering. The bubbles produced by the food coloring are not as hot as the bubbles produced by the boiling soup, so they produce less heat and light.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 food coloring diffusing through soup
Cooking is all about heat. The higher the heat, the faster the cooking. When you turn up the heat on your stove, the molecules in the food start to move faster. This is because the heat is energy, and energy makes things move. The faster the molecules move, the more they bump into each other. When they bump into each other, they exchange energy. This is called heat transfer. The more heat you add, the more the molecules move, and the more they bump into each other. This causes the food to cook faster.Stokes scattering is a lot like cooking. The higher the energy, the faster the scattering. When you turn up the energy on your light source, the photons start to move faster. This is because the energy is pushing them along. The faster the photons move, the more they bump into the atoms in the material. When they bump into the atoms, they exchange energy. This is called scattering. The more energy you add, the more the photons move, and the more they bump into the atoms. This causes the material to scatter light faster.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that is lethal to 50% of the population. In other words, it is the dose that kills half of the people who take it. To put it in perspective, think about cooking. If you are cooking a pot of soup and you add too much salt, it will be too salty and no one will want to eat it. However, if you add too little salt, the soup will be bland and no one will want to eat it either. The median lethal dose is like the perfect amount of salt to add to a pot of soup - it will make the soup taste just right and everyone will want to eat it.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 perfect amount of salt to add to a pot of soup

The soup is cooked over time, and it changes as it cooks.	universe	Using an analogy, explain universe to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 big pot of soup

Glycogen is like a garden hose. It can be filled with water and then used to water plants. The hose can also be emptied and used again. A bacterial invasion is similar to an infestation of weeds in a garden. The weeds will compete with the plants for resources, such as water, sunlight, and nutrients. A gardener is watering her plants. She starts with the plants at the back of the garden and works her way to the front. She uses more and more water as she gets closer to the plants in the front. This is similar to an action potential. The water is like the voltage of the cell. The plants in the back are the most distant from the water, so they have the lowest voltage. The plants in the front are the closest to the water, so they have the highest voltage.	action potential	Explain action potential using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener watering her plants
A star's main-sequence lifetime is determined by how much fuel it has. The more fuel a star has, the longer it will stay on the main sequence. A star is like a plant. It needs water, sunlight, and nutrients to grow. The more water, sunlight, and nutrients it gets, the longer it will stay alive.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 growth of plants

A capacitor is like a container of water. If you have a hose with a lot of water pressure, it is easy to squirt water out of the hose. But if you have a container with a small hole in the bottom, it is hard to get water out of the container. The water pressure is like the voltage of the capacitor. The size of the hole is like the capacitance.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 size of the hole in the bottom of a container
Electric current is like water flowing through a hose. Just as the water pressure can be increased by increasing the water flow, the electric current can be increased by increasing the number of electrons flowing through the wire.	electric current	Explain electric current using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 water flowing through a hose
Water pressure is like voltage. Just as garden hoses can have different water pressures, electrical circuits can have different voltages. The higher the water pressure, the more powerful the stream of water. The higher the voltage, the more powerful the electrical current.	voltage	Explain voltage using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 water pressure
In gardening, plants that are close together can share water and nutrients through their roots. Plants that are far apart cannot do this as easily. Cells are similar - cells that are close together can share water and nutrients through their cell membranes. Cells that are far apart cannot do this as easily.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardening
Kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero. This law can be explained using a gardening analogy. Imagine that you are a gardener and you have a hose with a nozzle on it. If you turn the nozzle on, water will flow out of the hose and into the garden. If you close the nozzle, the water will stop flowing. The water in the hose is like voltage and the water in the garden is like current. The voltage is the potential difference between the two points and the current is the amount of water that flows between the two points. The sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero because the water in the hose is trying to flow in two directions at once and the water in the garden is trying to flow in one direction.	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener analogy
A density wave is like a wave of people that moves through a crowd. The people at the front of the wave are packed together, while the people at the back are spread out.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 wave of people in a crowd
Enzymes are like gardeners. They help things grow and they make sure everything is working properly.	enzymes	Explain enzymes using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardeners

The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. A gardener is tending to her plants. She waters them and then waits for them to grow. She then waters them again. The water is the reactant and the plant is the product. The gardener is constantly adding water and the plant is constantly using water. The water is in dynamic equilibrium with the plant.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Explain dynamic chemical equilibrium using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener watering plants

A limiting reactant is a reactant that is used up first in a chemical reaction. An excess reactant is a reactant that is not used up in a chemical reaction. In gardening, a limiting reactant would be the amount of soil that is available to plants. An excess reactant would be the amount of water that is available to plants.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardening

The universe is like a garden. It has been carefully tended and cultivated for billions of years. The universe is constantly growing and evolving, just like a garden.	universe	Explain universe using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 garden

If you have a garden and you want to know how much fertilizer to use, you could do an experiment where you apply different amounts of fertilizer to different parts of the garden and then measure how well each part grows. This would be a controlled experiment, and you would use an analysis of variance (anova) to see if there was a difference in the growth of the different parts of the garden.	anova	Explain anova using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 measuring the growth of different parts of a garden
A thermostat is like a gardener who waters the plants at a certain time each day and adjusts the watering depending on the weather. The thermostat turns on the heat or air conditioning at a certain time each day and adjusts the temperature depending on the weather.	thermostat	Explain thermostat using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who waters plants
Chemical equilibrium is like a garden where the plants are in balance. The plants get the right amount of water, light, and nutrients to grow. If one plant gets too much water, for example, the other plants will get less. The same is true for chemical equilibrium. If one chemical gets too much of a reactant, the other chemicals will get less.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 a garden
A gardener who plants seeds in the spring will not have vegetables to harvest until the fall. A gardener who plants seeds in the fall will not have vegetables to harvest until the spring. A gardener who plants seeds in the summer will have vegetables to harvest in the fall.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 planting seeds in the summer
Adaptive immunity can be thought of as a gardener who plants a variety of different flowers in her garden. The gardener knows that some of the flowers will be more resistant to pests and diseases than others. So, when pests or diseases attack the garden, the gardener will be more likely to have a flower that is resistant to that particular pest or disease.In the same way, the body's adaptive immune system contains different cells that are specifically designed to fight off different pests and diseases. When a foreign invader (such as a virus or bacteria) enters the body, the adaptive immune system will mobilize its troops to attack and destroy the invader.	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who plants a variety of different flowers
If you have a hose with a certain amount of water pressure, and you want to increase the water pressure at the end of the hose, you can do so by increasing the water pressure at the faucet. The amount of water that comes out of the hose at the end is determined by the water pressure at the faucet and the resistance of the hose. In the same way, if you have a circuit with a certain amount of voltage and you want to increase the voltage at the end of the circuit, you can do so by increasing the voltage at the beginning of the circuit. The amount of current that flows through the circuit is determined by the voltage and the resistance of the circuit.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 water pressure at the faucet
Transcription is the process of copying a gene's DNA sequence into a new molecule of messenger RNA (mRNA). This process is similar to a gardener copying a plant's genetic information into a new seed. The mRNA can then leave the cell nucleus and travel to the cell's protein-making factories, called ribosomes, where it is used to create proteins.	transcription	Explain transcription using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 copying a gene's DNA sequence into a new molecule of messenger RNA (mRNA)
RNA polymerase is like a gardener who plants seeds in the ground. The gardener waters the seeds and then waits for them to grow into plants. The plants then produce flowers and fruit. RNA polymerase does the same thing with DNA. It plants the DNA seeds in the ground, waters them, and then waits for them to grow into RNA. The RNA then produces proteins.	rna polymerase	Explain rna polymerase using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who plants seeds in the ground
Ribosomes are like the gardeners who plant the seeds and water the plants. The plants are the proteins that are made by the ribosomes, and the seeds are the RNA that the ribosomes use to make the proteins.	ribosome	Explain ribosome using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who plants the seeds and waters the plants###| protein | plant
The activator protein is like a gardener who waters the plants and helps them grow. The activator protein helps the transcription factor bind to the DNA and start the transcription process.	activator protein	Explain activator protein using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who waters the plants
Electricity is like water in a garden hose. The water pressure in the hose is like the voltage in an electric circuit. The amount of water flowing through the hose is like the current in an electric circuit. The water in the hose is like the electrons in an electric circuit.	electric circuit	Explain electric circuit using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 garden hose
Water molecules are attracted to each other and are also attracted to the surface of the soil. This attraction creates a force that pushes the water molecules down into the soil. The water molecules are also attracted to the surface of the plants, but the attraction is weaker than the attraction to the soil. This force creates a force that pulls the water molecules up into the plants. The water molecules that are attracted to the surface of the plants are called the water surface tension.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 water surface tension
A gardener watering her plants is an analogy for a cell receiving a signal from its environment. The water is the signal and the plants are the cells. The gardener is the receptor and the water is the ligand. The gardener's muscles are the effector.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener watering her plants
In gardening, nadh is the nutrient that helps plants to convert sunlight into energy. It is analogous to norepinephrine in humans, which helps to convert glucose into energy.	nadh	Explain nadh using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 norepinephrine

In gardening, nadh is the nutrient that helps plants turn sunlight into sugar. Without nadh, plants cannot create energy and will eventually die. In the body, nadh is responsible for turning food into energy.	nadh	Explain nadh using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 the nutrient that helps plants turn sunlight into sugar###| body | food into energy
Just as a gardener needs to add fertilizer to the soil in order to help plants grow, our bodies need protein in order to build and maintain muscle. Protein is made up of smaller molecules called amino acids, which are the "building blocks" of protein. We get most of the amino acids we need from food, but there are a few that our bodies can make on their own.	proteins	Explain proteins using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 amino acids

The same is true for proteins - they start out as tiny molecules called amino acids and, with the right conditions (nutrients from food), they will grow into larger proteins.	proteins	Explain proteins using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 plants in your garden

The Golgi apparatus is like the gardener who plants the seeds, waters them, and then harvests the vegetables. The plant's cells produce the proteins that are needed for growth. Macrophages are the gardeners of your immune system. They survey your body for any signs of infection or disease, and then work to clear away any harmful cells or substances. A macrophage is a large white blood cell that absorbs and digests bacteria, dead cells, and other debris. Macrophages are like the gardeners of your body - they keep things clean and free from infection.	macrophages	Explain macrophages using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardeners

The analogy of gardening is helpful in understanding how t-helper cells work. In gardening, there are different types of soilclay, loam and sand. The type of soil that a gardener uses will depend on the plants they are growing. For example, if they want to grow tomatoes, they would use loam because it is good for holding moisture and nutrients. If they wanted to grow carrots, they would use sandy soil because it has good drainage. T-helper cells are like the type of soil; each one works best with certain antigens (like plants). There are different types of t-helper cells that work with different antigens; just as there are different types of soils that work best with certain plants.	t-helper cells	Explain t-helper cells using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardening
In gardening, there are different types of plants that need different types of care. For example, a rose bush needs water and sunlight while a cactus does not. In the same way, t-helper cells are responsible for identifying different antigens and providing the necessary signals for an immune response.	t-helper cells	Explain t-helper cells using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 identifying different antigens###| immune response | providing the necessary signals
A t-helper cell is like a gardener. It helps to direct and guide other cells in the body to do their jobs effectively.	t-helper cells	Explain t-helper cells using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardeners

However, they also play an important role in the garden by helping to fight off pests and diseases.	b-lymphocytes	Explain b-lymphocytes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 weeds in your garden

A cytotoxic t-lymphocyte is a type of white blood cell that helps the body fight infection. In a gardening analogy, they can be thought of as the gardener's helper. They work to destroy any cells that are infected or damaged, including cancer cells.	cytotoxic t-lymphocytes	Explain cytotoxic t-lymphocytes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardener's helper
A gardener may use compost to improve the soil in her garden. The compost contains bacteria, which will invade the healthy soil and help it to decompose. In a similar way, invading bacteria can help break down organic matter and improve the environment for other organisms.	invasion of bacterias	Explain invasion of bacterias using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 compost
The analogy of bacteria invading a garden is much like an infestation of ants. The ants are constantly looking for new food sources and they will invade a garden in order to get to the plants or fruits that they are looking for. The bacteria work in a very similar way. They are always looking for new ways to infect people and once they find a way in, they can quickly spread throughout the body.	invasion of bacterias	Explain invasion of bacterias using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 infestation of ants
Bacteria can be seen as garden pests that invade and destroy plants. Just as a gardener might use pesticides to get rid of these pests, antibiotics are used to kill bacteria.	invasion of bacterias	Explain invasion of bacterias using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 pests in a garden###| use of antibiotics | use of pesticides
Imagine you are a gardener. You have just planted some flowers and now you need to water them. To do this, you take a hose and put it in the ground near the plants. When you turn on the water, the pressure of the water against the ground forces liquid up through the hose and into the flower pots.Now imagine that each flower pot has a small hole in it so that liquid can escape from it (but not enter). If you turn on the water slowly, only a little bit of liquid will flow out of each pot. But if you turn on the water with more force, more liquid will flow out of each pot.This is similar to what happens when there is an action potential in a neuron. The voltage difference between inside and outside of a neuron causes sodium ions to rush into the neuron, like water rushing through holes in flower pots. This influx of sodium ions creates an electrical current that travels down the length of the neuron until it reaches its end point (the synapse). There, neurotransmitters are released which cross over to receptors on neighboring neurons where they generate another action potential	action potential	Explain action potential using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water rushing through holes in flower pots###| synapse | end point of a hose
When a gardener wants to water their plants, they go over to the hose and turn it on. This allows water to flow from the faucet into the hose, and eventually out of the spout and onto the plants. The gardener can control how much water is flowing by turning the faucet on and off.In a similar way, when a neuron is stimulated, an action potential occurs. This means that voltage-gated Na+ channels open up, allowing Na+ ions to flow into the neuron. This influx of Na+ ions causes the neuron to become more positive inside (depolarization), which in turn opens up even more voltage-gated Na+ channels. As more and moreNa+ ions flow in, the membrane potential continues to increase until it reaches its peak value (+40 mV). At this point, all of the voltage-gated Na+ channels close and K+ ion channels open up, allowing K+ ions to leavethe neuron (repolarization). Once repolarized, the neuron is ready for another action potential	action potential	Explain action potential using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 flowing water
The gardener analogy for the action potential is that of a hose. When the water is turned on at full force, it gushes out of the hose. This is analogous to when the neuron fires and sends an action potential down its axon. If you turn the water on slowly, you get a dribble; this is analogous to a graded potential.	action potential	Explain action potential using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 the water gushing out of the hose###| graded potential | the water dribbling out of the hose
Chromatography is the process of separating a mixture into its individual components. This can be done using either a physical or chemical separation technique. In gardening, chromatography can be used to separate different colors of soil. The different colors are each placed in their own container and then water is slowly added until the soils are all mixed together. Once the soils are mixed, a small amount of this mixture is placed on a filter paper and allowed to dry. Once the sample has dried, it will be ready for analysis. To perform the analysis, we will need some food coloring dye and alcohol. We will also need a ruler or other measuring device with millimeter markings. First, we will use the food coloring dye to color one end of the filter paper strip red. Next, we will add alcohol to another end of the strip until it is wet but not soaking wet (this should take about 10 drops). Now we're ready to start testing our soil samples! We'll place each soil sample at one end of our strip and wait for them to travel down the strip by capillary action (the same way that water travels up through plants). The further down the strip that a particular soil sample travels, the more saturated that particular soil was with water when it was mixed with our original batch. We can use this information to create a "soil moisture" map of our garden!	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardening
If you want to separate the colors in a bouquet of flowers, you can use chromatography. The process works something like this: You put a few drops of water on each flower, then place them on a piece of paper. Next, you fold the paper in half and rub it together. This will cause the water to spread out and wet the entire surface of the paper. Finally, you wait for the water to dry. As it dries, it will pull the different colors in each flower apart. The result will be a colorful rainbow on the paper (see image).	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 separating colors in a bouquet of flowers
Chromatography is used to separate the different chemicals in a mixture. A gardening analogy would be to think of each chemical as a different type of soil (clay, sand, silt). The mixture is poured into a jar and then water is added. The water will wash over the soil, carrying away some of the chemicals with it. As the water washes over the soil, it separates the chemicals based on their size and weight. The heavier soils (clay, sand) will stay at the bottom of the jar while the lighter soils (silt) will be carried away by the water.	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 analogy of gardening
A star's main-sequence lifetime is determined by how much nuclear fuel it has. More massive stars use up their fuel more quickly and therefore have shorter main-sequence lifetimes than less massive stars. You can think of a star's life as being like the life of a plant. The longer the plant lives, the more growth it experiences. A small, young plant will live for only a year or two, while a large, old tree may live for hundreds of years. In the same way, a small, young star will have a short main-sequence lifetime while a large, old star will have a long main-sequence lifetime.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 life of a plant
The lifetime of a star is determined by how much fuel it has. A star like the sun will burn for about 10 billion years, while a red dwarf might last for trillions of years. This is kind of like comparing the lifespan of a cactus to an oak tree. The cactus has less fuel and will die sooner, while the oak has more fuel and will live longer.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 lifespan of a cactus vs an oak tree
The main sequence lifetime of a star is the amount of time it spends burning hydrogen in its core. This can be thought of as the length of time a gardener spends weeding their garden. Weeds will continue to grow as long as they have sunlight and water, just like a star will continue to burn hydrogen in its core as long as it has fuel.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 the length of time a gardener spends weeding their garden
A nucleus is like the center of a garden. It helps to control what grows and how it grows.	nucleus	Explain nucleus using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 center of a garden
The nucleus is the center of a plant cell. It contains the genetic information that dictates how the cell grows and functions. The nucleus is analogous to the brain of a human being, controlling all aspects of cellular activity.	nucleus	Explain nucleus using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 brain
A nucleus is like a gardener. It takes care of the plants (chromosomes) and makes sure they grow correctly.	nucleus	Explain nucleus using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardener
Ribosomes are like the gardeners who plant and water the seeds, then watch them grow into plants. The ribosomes read the genetic information in a strand of DNA to create a specific protein.	ribosomes	Explain ribosomes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardeners who plant and water the seeds
Ribosomes are like the seeds of a plant. The seeds need water and soil in order to grow into a full-sized plant. In the same way, ribosomes need mRNA (the water) and tRNA (the soil) in order to create proteins.	ribosomes	Explain ribosomes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 seeds of a plant###| mRNA | water###| tRNA | soil
Ribosomes are the machines in a plant that create new proteins. They work a bit like a sewing machine, taking instructions from DNA to create new pieces of protein that are needed for the plant to grow.	ribosomes	Explain ribosomes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 sewing machines
The Golgi apparatus can be thought of as a gardener. The Golgi apparatus takes care of the plants (mitochondria), watering them, fertilizing them, and removing any dead plants. It also monitors the environment around the plants to make sure they are in the best possible conditions.	golgi apparatus	Explain golgi apparatus using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardener
The Golgi apparatus can be thought of as a kind of gardening tool. It helps to package and label the products of the cell's production line so that they can be sent off to their correct destinations. Just like with any other garden tool, it takes some time and practice to learn how to use the Golgi apparatus properly!	golgi apparatus	Explain golgi apparatus using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardening tool
The Golgi apparatus can be thought of as the gardening department of a plant. It is responsible for packaging and shipping materials to different parts of the cell, much like how a garden center might send plants and soil to different parts of a yard.	golgi apparatus	Explain golgi apparatus using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardening department of a plant
Lysosomes are like the garbage disposal in your kitchen sink. The trash (or food) goes into the garbage disposal, and then it is ground up and washed away. Lysosomes do the same thing to cells that are damaged or no longer needed.	lysosomes	Explain lysosomes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garbage disposal
Lysosomes are like the garbage disposal in your kitchen. They digest waste and recycles materials.	lysosomes	Explain lysosomes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garbage disposal
Lysosomes are like a compost heap in the garden. The plant takes in food (nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium) and carbon from the air and uses it to create new leaves, flowers, fruits or vegetables. The lysosomes take the waste from the plant - leaves that have fallen off, old flowers or fruit - and break them down into their component parts so that they can be used again by the plant to create more food.	lysosomes	Explain lysosomes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 compost heap in the garden
A nuclear envelope is a membrane that surrounds the nucleus of a cell. It functions as a barrier between the nucleus and the cytoplasm. The nuclear envelope is similar to the skin of a fruit or vegetable. It protects the inside of the fruit or vegetable from outside contaminants, while allowing nutrients to flow in and out.	nuclear envelope	Explain nuclear envelope using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 skin of a fruit or vegetable
Nuclear envelope is like a garden fence. It helps to contain the nuclear material within the cell and also regulates what goes in and out.	nuclear envelope	Explain nuclear envelope using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garden fence
A nuclear envelope is like a fence around the nucleus of a cell. It helps to keep the DNA inside and protect it from damage.	nuclear envelope	Explain nuclear envelope using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 fence around the nucleus of a cell
One way to think about vacuoles is to imagine them as holding bags of water in a plant's cells. Just as gardeners use watering cans to give their plants a drink, the vacuoles suck up water from the cell cytoplasm and store it in their bag-like membranes. This gives the plant tissue a turgid or swollen appearance, similar to how inflated balloons look different from deflated ones. The pressure of all that extra water inside the cell helps keep it rigid so it can stand up straight against gravity.	vacuoles	Explain vacuoles using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 holding bags of water in a plant's cells
A vacuole is a bit like a garden shed. It's a small, enclosed space where you can store things. In the plant world, vacuoles are used to store water, nutrients and other important chemicals.	vacuoles	Explain vacuoles using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garden sheds
A vacuole is like a big bag of water that helps plants stay firm and upright. It's kind of like the water in your garden hose. When you turn on the hose, the pressure from the water coming out pushes against the sides of the hose, which in turn makes it hard for the hose to move around. The same thing happens with a plant stem - when there's more pressure inside the stem from all of that extra water in the vacuole, it becomes harder for the stem to bend or move.	vacuoles	Explain vacuoles using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water in garden hose
The cytoplasm is like the soil in a garden. It contains all of the nutrients that the plant needs to grow and thrive.	cytoplasm	Explain cytoplasm using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 soil in a garden
The cytoplasm can be thought of as the soil in a garden. It is the foundation on which everything else grows. The cytoplasm contains all of the nutrients and water that plants need to thrive.	cytoplasm	Explain cytoplasm using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 soil in a garden
The cytoplasm is like the soil in a garden. It contains all of the nutrients that the plant needs to grow and thrive.	cytoplasm	Explain cytoplasm using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 soil in a garden
Chromosomes are like the branches of a tree. They start off small and grow larger as they get further from the trunk. The leaves on the end of the branches are called chromosomes.	chromosome	Explain chromosome using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 the leaves on the end of the branches
A chromosome is like a garden hose. It is long and flexible, and can be easily bent and twisted to fit into tight spaces. Chromosomes are made up of DNA, which is like the water that flows through the hose.	chromosome	Explain chromosome using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garden hose###| DNA | water
Chromosomes are like the seeds in a packet of vegetable seeds. The packet may have 20 or more different types of seeds, but each seed is still just a small part of the whole. Veggies grow from these little seeds, and as they grow, they become separate plants with their own unique qualities (some are green while others are purple; some taste sweet while others are bitter). Inside each plant, you'll find even more little seeds called chromosomes. Just like the big packet of seeds that started everything, chromosomes contain all the information needed to create a new living being.	chromosome	Explain chromosome using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 a small part of the whole###| vegetable seed | a small part of the whole

As the seeds grow, they produce shoots and leaves (new proteins). The size and shape of the garden plot (vesicle) depends on how much space is available in the soil.	vesicles	Explain vesicles using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 tiny garden plots

In a garden, plants need three things to survive: water, air, and soil. Plants get water from the soil; they get their carbon dioxide from the air; and they get their nutrients from the soil. The cell membrane can be thought of as a garden fence. The fence is made of metal wires, and it surrounds the garden to keep the plants inside the garden. The fence also prevents animals from coming into the garden and eating the plants. In the same way, the cell membrane surrounds and protects the cells from outside invaders (such as bacteria) and keeps what's inside the cell separated from what's outside.	cell membrane	Explain cell membrane using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garden fence

The golgi body can be thought of as the gardener. It is responsible for taking care of and processing all of the materials that go into making a plant thrive. A capacitor is like a container of water. If you have two containers, one with more water and one with less, the one with more water will be harder to push down. This is because it has more capacitance. Just like in a garden, the plants that have more water (capacitance) in their soil are harder to move than the plants that have less water.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water in a container
If you have ever planted a garden, you know that you need to water it regularly for the plants to grow. The water is like electricity and the plants are like capacitors. If you don't water the plants regularly, they will die.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 plants###| water | electricity
Capacitance is the ability of a material to store an electric charge. It is measured in farads and can be increased by adding more plates to the capacitor or by using a material with a high dielectric constant. A gardening analogy would be to think of capacitance as being similar to water storage in a rain barrel. The more water that is stored, the more capacitance there is.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water storage in a rain barrel
Electric current is like water flowing through a hose. Just as the water pressure in the hose depends on how much water is coming out of the faucet, the electrical voltage in a wire depends on how much electric charge is moving through it. The more water that's flowing, the higher the pressure (voltage). And just as you can stop the flow of water by closing off the valve, you can stop or slow down electric current by adding a resistor.	electric current	Explain electric current using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water flowing through a hose###| voltage | water pressure in a hose###| resistor | valve
Electric current is like the flow of water in a garden hose. Just as the water pressure creates a steady flow through the hose, an electric potential (or voltage) applied to one end of a wire will create a steady flow of electrons through the wire.	electric current	Explain electric current using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 flow of water in a garden hose

If it's not cooked correctly, it can easily break or become unusable.	brittle software	Explain brittle software using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 overcooked eggs or fish

This is similar to how a wave travels from one place to another. Cooking analogy for DNA replication:Cooking analogy for DNA replication: Just as you would need two pots to cook a meal for two people, you need two strands of DNA to replicate a molecule of DNA. The two strands of DNA are like the two pots, and the replication process is like cooking the meal. The two strands of DNA are each like a recipe, and when they are put together, they create a new recipe that can be used to make a new molecule of DNA.	dna replication	Explain dna replication using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 cooking a meal
RNA transcription is a bit like cooking a meal. The recipe is the DNA, and the cook is the RNA polymerase. The cook reads the recipe and starts cooking, following the instructions. As the cook cooks, they create new RNA molecules, which are a bit like the finished meal.	rna transcription	Explain rna transcription using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 cooking a meal

The action potential is like an electric current that travels down the neuron. This current is created by the movement of positively charged ions, such as potassium and sodium, into and out of the neuron. The action potential starts at the neuron's cell body and travels down the axon to the end of the neuron.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 current created by the movement of positively charged ions

A layered architecture is like a cake. The cake is made up of many layers, and each layer is made up of many smaller parts. The cake is held together by a frosting or icing. The same is true for a layered architecture. The architecture is made up of many layers, and each layer is made up of many smaller parts. The layers are held together by a framework or infrastructure.	layered architecture	Explain layered architecture using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 cake
In cooking, a limiting reactant is a reactant that is in short supply and limits the amount of product that can be formed. For example, if you are making a cake and run out of flour, the cake will not be able to be made. An excess reactant is a reactant that is in excess and is not used up in the reaction.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 cooking
A eukaryotic cell is like a big pot of soup. The ingredients in the soup are the proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates. The pot is the cell membrane, and the stove is the cell's nucleus. The soup is cooked by the heat of the stove, and the cell is cooked by the heat of the nucleus.	eukaryotic cell	Explain eukaryotic cell using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 big pot of soup###| proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates | ingredients in the soup###| cell membrane | pot###| cell's nucleus | stove
A prokaryotic cell is like a pot of soup. The cell wall is like the pot, and the cytoplasm is like the soup. The kernel is the heart of the operating system. It is responsible for managing the system's resources and providing basic services to the other parts of the system. It is like the cook in a kitchen. The cook is responsible for preparing the food and making sure that everything runs smoothly in the kitchen.	operating systems kernel	Explain operating systems kernel using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 cook in a kitchen
A limiting reactant is a reactant that is used up first in a chemical reaction. It is the reactant that determines how much product can be made. For example, if you are making a cake and you only have one egg, that egg is the limiting reactant. You can only make as much cake as you can with one egg.	limiting reactant	Explain limiting reactant using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 reactant that is used up first in a chemical reaction

The cook then uses heat to cook the food and make it ready to eat.Similarly, message encoding takes all of the information in a message and puts it together into a format that can be sent over a network. The encoding process uses a set of rules to create a message that can be read by a computer. The encoding process also uses a type of heat (usually electricity) to send the message over a network.	message encoding	Explain message encoding using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 cooking a meal

When light shines on a piece of red pepper, some of the light is scattered in all directions. This is similar to the way that light is scattered when it shines on a cooked piece of red pepper. The red pepper scatters the light in all directions because of the bumps and ridges on its surface. These bumps and ridges cause the light to bounce off in different directions.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 scattering of light when it shines on a cooked piece of red pepper

The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that is lethal to 50% of the population. This can be thought of as the amount of a substance that is lethal to a group of people as if they were all in one big pot and you were trying to cook them all to death. The median lethal dose would be the amount of the substance that would kill half of the people in the pot.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 cooking a group of people in one pot

An anova is a statistical analysis tool used to compare the means of two or more groups. It is similar to a t-test, but can be used with more than two groups. The analysis determines whether the means of the groups are statistically different from each other. This can be thought of as a way to compare the results of two different cooking methods, for example.	anova	Explain anova using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 comparing the means of two or more groups

The temperature is constant and the reaction is not happening or stopping.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 a pot of boiling water
Just-in-time is a production philosophy that aims to produce only what is needed, when it is needed. This is done by closely monitoring inventory levels and only producing items as they are ordered by customers. This is similar to cooking a meal. A cook would not prepare a meal hours in advance if they know that only a few people will be eating. Instead, they would cook only what is needed, when it is needed.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 cooking a meal
Adaptive immunity is like a cookbook. It is a collection of recipes that the body can use to make antibodies to fight infection.	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 cookbook
If you have a pot of water on the stove and set it to medium heat, the water will start to boil at around 212 degrees Fahrenheit. If you double the amount of heat (turn up the stove to high), the water will boil much more quickly. This is because the water is trying to reach equilibrium - the state where the energy being put into it is equal to the energy being released. The same is true for electricity. If you have a circuit with a resistor in it and you apply more voltage, the resistor will heat up because it is trying to reach equilibrium.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using a cooking analogy.	lt	cooking	 water trying to reach equilibrium
