A plasma membrane is like a kitchen oven. It separates the inside of the oven from the outside, and it allows heat to pass in one direction (into the oven) and not the other (out of the oven).	plasma membrane	What is a good analogy to explain plasma membrane to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 kitchen oven
A good analogy to explain the plasma membrane to a student who likes cooking is by comparing it to a pot of boiling water. The pot of water represents the cell, and the water inside of the pot represents the cytoplasm. The lid of the pot represents the plasma membrane, and the heat source beneath the pot represents the mitochondria. Just as heat is applied to the pot of water in order to make it boil, energy is applied to cells in order to make them function. In both cases, temperature is important in order for things to happen.	plasma membrane	What is a good analogy to explain plasma membrane to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 pot of boiling water

Lysosomes can be thought of as the stomachs of cells. Just like your stomach breaks down food to extract nutrients, lysosomes break down old or damaged proteins, fats and other materials in the cell to recycle them.	lysosome	What is a good analogy to explain lysosome to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 stomach
Lysosomes are like the stomach of a cell. The stomach is where food gets digested and broken down into pieces that the body can use. Lysosomes do the same thing to proteins, fats, and other molecules inside of cells.	lysosome	What is a good analogy to explain lysosome to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 stomach
A lysosome is a bit like the garbage disposal in your kitchen. It's a small organelle that can break down big pieces of food into smaller pieces. This helps to make sure that the cell can use all of the nutrients from the food and doesn't have to get rid of any waste.	lysosome	What is a good analogy to explain lysosome to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 garbage disposal
Peroxisomes are like the ovens in a kitchen. They cook the food that is inside them.	peroxisomes	What is a good analogy to explain peroxisomes to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 ovens in a kitchen
A peroxisome is like a small kitchen in the cell. Just as in a regular kitchen, there are appliances (such as a stove and refrigerator) that perform different tasks (like cooking food or keeping it cold), so too are there different types of machines within the peroxisome that each carry out a specific job.	peroxisomes	What is a good analogy to explain peroxisomes to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 small kitchen in the cell
A peroxisome is like a mini-fridge for your cells. It helps keep the cell's food cold and fresh.	peroxisomes	What is a good analogy to explain peroxisomes to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 mini-fridge for cells
Mitochondria can be thought of as the "ovens" of the cell. They are responsible for producing energy (in the form of ATP) for the cell to use. Just like an oven, mitochondria need fuel in order to work properly. This fuel comes from food that we eat, which is broken down into small pieces inside of our digestive system. These small pieces then enter into the cells and are used by the mitochondria to create ATP.	mitochondria	What is a good analogy to explain mitochondria to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 ovens of the cell
Mitochondria are like the ovens in a kitchen. They take in food (fuel) and create energy for the cell.	mitochondria	What is a good analogy to explain mitochondria to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 ovens in a kitchen

Cooking pasta is a good analogy to explain the cytoskeleton. The noodles represent the cells, and the sauce represents the cytoskeleton. Just as pasta needs water to cook properly, cells need cytoplasm (the watery solution inside cells) to function properly. The sauce thickens when it cooks and coats the noodles; in a similar way, cytoskeletal proteins thicken and coat the cell membrane to give it strength and stability	cytoskeleton	What is a good analogy to explain cytoskeleton to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 pasta###| cell membrane | sauce

A good analogy to explain the first line of defense in the body to a student who likes cooking is that it is like a bouncer at a nightclub. The bouncer's job is to keep out people who are not supposed to be in the club and to make sure that everyone inside is behaving appropriately. In the same way, the first line of defense in the body's immune system keeps out germs and viruses and makes sure that everything else inside the body is functioning properly.	first line of defense in the body	What is a good analogy to explain first line of defense in the body to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 bouncer at a nightclub
One analogy to explain the body's first line of defense is that it is like a kitchen. The stomach is like the stove, and the small intestine is like the oven. When someone eats something unhealthy or dangerous, their stomach (stove) will start cooking (digesting) it. If there are any harmful toxins or bacteria in the food, they will die in the heat of the digestion process. However, if something slips by and makes it into the small intestine (oven), then those harmful toxins or bacteria have a chance to survive and make you sick.	first line of defense in the body	What is a good analogy to explain first line of defense in the body to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 analogy of a kitchen
The first line of defense in the body is like a chef's knife. It is sharp and can easily cut through food. The immune system works in a similar way by attacking any germs or viruses that enter the body.	first line of defense in the body	What is a good analogy to explain first line of defense in the body to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 chef's knife###| immune system | attacking germs or viruses
A macrophage is like a big pot that can cook a lot of food at once. It's able to take in and digest large amounts of material.	macrophages	What is a good analogy to explain macrophages to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 big pots
A macrophage is a lot like a chef in a kitchen. They both have important jobs to do, and they both work together to make the whole system run smoothly. The chef creates all of the delicious food that people enjoy, while the macrophages help keep the body healthy by fighting off infection and getting rid of dead cells.	macrophages	What is a good analogy to explain macrophages to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 chefs in a kitchen
A macrophage is like a big sponge that can soak up a lot of bacteria and other debris.	macrophages	What is a good analogy to explain macrophages to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 big sponges
A t-helper cell is similar to a chef in a kitchen. The chef creates recipes and directs the cooks on what to make. In the same way, the t-helper cell tells other cells what kind of response they should have to an antigen (like a recipe).	t-helper cells	What is a good analogy to explain t-helper cells to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 chefs in a kitchen

A cytotoxic T-lymphocyte is a bit like a chef in the kitchen. The chef can see what ingredients are in the recipe and how they are supposed to be used. But sometimes, the chef might come across an ingredient that doesn't seem to fit in with the recipe. In this case, the chef has two options: (1) follow the recipe as written and hope that everything turns out okay or (2) use their culinary expertise to adapt the recipe so that it works better. Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes work in a similar way. They can see which cells belong in our bodies and which don't. If they encounter something strange (like cancer cells), they have two options: (1) destroy them immediately or (2) try to figure out how to get rid of them without causing too much damage to healthy cells nearby.	cytotoxic t-lymphocytes	What is a good analogy to explain cytotoxic t-lymphocytes to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 chefs in the kitchen
Cytotoxic t-lymphocytes can be compared to a chef in a restaurant. The chef is responsible for preparing the food and making sure it is served fresh and tastes good. Cytotoxic t-lymphocytes are responsible for killing infected cells and destroying cancer cells. They work to keep the body healthy by ensuring that harmful cells are destroyed before they can cause damage.	cytotoxic t-lymphocytes	What is a good analogy to explain cytotoxic t-lymphocytes to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 chef in a restaurant
Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes can be thought of as the "chefs" of the immune system. Action potential is like a stove. When you turn on the stove, it takes a little while for the heat to build up. Once the heat reaches a certain point, it turns into an unstoppable force that cooks your food.	action potential	What is a good analogy to explain action potential to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 stove
Action potential can be explained as an electrical current that travels down a nerve fiber. It is similar to when you turn on a stove burner by flipping the switch. The electricity flows from the breaker box, through the wires in your house, and into the stove. Once it reaches the stove, it heats up the element and creates heat.	action potential	What is a good analogy to explain action potential to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 turning on a stove burner
When you cook something in a pan, the heat from the stovetop causes molecules in the food to move around and collide with each other. This creates friction which produces energy that heats up the food. The same thing happens when an action potential travels down an axon. Voltage-gated sodium channels open up and allow sodium ions to flow into the neuron. This creates a positive charge inside the neuron which causes potassium ions to flow out of the neuron. This creates a negative charge outside of the neuron which causes more voltage-gated sodium channels to open up. This cycle repeats itself over and over again, creating an action potential that travels down the axon	action potential	What is a good analogy to explain action potential to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking something in a pan
One way to think of chromatography is as if you are cooking. The different ingredients in a dish (solutes) are like the various colors that make up light. When you shine a light through a prism, the colors spread out because they are all traveling at different speeds. This is similar to what happens when white light shines on a piece of paper with ink on it - the black ink will cause some of the light waves to be absorbed and others to be reflected. The different colors will travel down the paper at different speeds, causing them to separate from one another.	experiment of chromatography	What is a good analogy to explain experiment of chromatography to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking
One way to think of chromatography is as if you are separating the individual ingredients in a recipe. For example, when you bake chocolate chip cookies, the chocolate chips are distributed throughout the cookie. But by using chromatography, you can extract the individual components (such as sugar, butter, and flour) that make up the cookie dough.	experiment of chromatography	What is a good analogy to explain experiment of chromatography to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 separating the individual ingredients in a recipe
A good analogy to explain chromatography to a student who likes cooking is that it is like separating the ingredients in a recipe. The different components of the recipe (e.g., flour, sugar, eggs) are all mixed together when you first measure them out, but by using chromatography we can separate them and see each individual component.	experiment of chromatography	What is a good analogy to explain experiment of chromatography to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 separating the ingredients in a recipe
One way to think about the main-sequence lifetime of a star is to imagine it as the time it takes for a star to cook a piece of meat. The longer you cook the meat, the more cooked it becomes. Cooking a turkey is an analogy for understanding the main-sequence lifetimes of stars. The size of the bird is like the star's mass, and how long it takes to cook is related to the star's lifetime. For example, a small chicken will cook more quickly than a large turkey. Similarly, smaller stars have shorter lifetimes than larger stars.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	What is a good analogy to explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking a turkey
A star's "lifetime" can be thought of as the time it spends as a main sequence star. This is determined by its mass. The higher the mass, the shorter the lifetime (on average). For example, a high-mass star might spend only 10 million years as a main sequence star, while a low-mass star might live for 100 billion years. You could think of this in terms of cooking: A high-mass stove burner would heat up quickly and then cool down quickly, while a low-mass stove burner would take longer to heat up but stay warm for awhile afterwards.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	What is a good analogy to explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking on a stove burner

Cooking can be divided into two categories: baking and boiling. When you bake something, you cook it with dry heat in an oven. When you boil something, you cook it with moist heat in a pot on the stove. Cells can also be divided into two categories: prokaryotic cells and eukaryotic cells. Prokaryotic cells are like baked goods; they are simple and have a single cell membrane. Eukaryotic cells are like boiled foods; they are complex and have multiple organelles enclosed within a plasma membrane.	cells	What is a good analogy to explain cells to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking
Cooking can be divided into two categories: baking and boiling. Baking is the process of heating food in an enclosed environment, like an oven. Boiling is the process of cooking food in water that is brought to a boil. Cells can also be divided into two categories: prokaryotic cells and eukaryotic cells. Prokaryotic cells are simple cells without a membrane-enclosed nucleus or other organelles. Eukaryotic cells are more complex cells with a membrane-enclosed nucleus and other organelles.Just as baking involves heating food in an enclosed environment, prokaryotic cell metabolism (the chemical processes that occur inside a cell) happens in an enclosed area called the cytoplasm. Just as boiling involves cooking food in water that is brought to a boil, eukaryotic cell metabolism occurs in watery solutions called cytosol and extracellular fluid.	cells	What is a good analogy to explain cells to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking

This is similar to what happens when you apply a voltage across a capacitor. The electric field from the voltage causes the electron in the capacitor plates to move around more. But if you put a lid on the pot, the boiling process will happen much more quickly. A cell is like a kitchen. The cell has different parts that specialize in doing different things (like cooking, cleaning, and serving food). Cellular specialization is a bit like having a cook who specializes in making pizzas and another cook who specializes in making desserts. The pizza chef doesn't need to know how to make a dessert, and vice versa. But both cooks need to be able to communicate with each other so that they can work together to create the best meal possible for their customers. In the same way, different parts of the cell specialize in doing different things (like making proteins or processing energy), but they all need to be able to communicate with each other so that the cell can function properly.	specialization and communication in a cell	What is a good analogy to explain specialization and communication in a cell to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 specialization and communication in a kitchen
Cooking is a great analogy for specialization and communication in cells. In cooking, there are different jobs that need to be done in order to create a finished dish. Someone needs to chop the vegetables, someone else needs to cook the meat, someone else needs to make the sauce, etc. The different parts of the kitchen need to communicate with each other in order to make sure that everything comes together properly. The same thing happens within cells. Kirchoff's voltage law is similar to the way recipes work in cooking. Just as a recipe calls for certain ingredients and specifies how much of each ingredient to use, Kirchoff's voltage law describes how voltages combine in an electrical circuit. The law states that the total voltage in a closed circuit is the sum of the individual voltages at all points in the circuit.	kirchoff's voltage law	What is a good analogy to explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 recipes in cooking
A good analogy to explain Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (KVL) to a student who likes cooking is to think of electricity as being similar to food. Just as you need energy in the form of food to power your body, you need electrical energy (in the form of voltage) to power electronic devices. The amount of voltage needed is determined by how hungry the device is (known as its "demand"). Like people, different devices have different appetites (or "requirements"). So just as you might need a variety of foods in your diet to meet your nutritional needs, you might need a variety of voltages to meet the requirements of different devices. KVL simply states that the sum total of all the voltages seen around a closed loop must be zero. This means that if there are two paths for electricity to flow from one point to another, and those two paths are connected by a wire, then the voltage at each end of those two paths must be equal.	kirchoff's voltage law	What is a good analogy to explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 analogy of electricity to food
One way to think of Kirchhoff's Voltage Law is that it is like a recipe for making a cake. The ingredients (voltages) are all put into the bowl at the same time, and then they are mixed together. Once they are all combined, the cake can be baked in the oven. In order for the cake to come out correctly, you have to follow the recipe exactly. If you don't add enough sugar, for example, then the cake will be too sour.	kirchoff's voltage law	What is a good analogy to explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 recipe for making a cake
A density wave can be thought of as a ripple in a pond. Just as waves move across the surface of water, a density wave moves through a gas or liquid. The wave is created when something disturbs the equilibrium state of the substance. For example, when you drop a rock into a pool of water, it creates waves that spread out from the point where the rock hit the water.	nature of a density wave	What is a good analogy to explain nature of a density wave to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 ripple in a pond
A density wave can be compared to a large group of people walking through a crowded room. As more and more people enter the room, it becomes increasingly crowded until it reaches its maximum capacity. At this point, no more people can fit into the room and the crowd begins to thin out again.	nature of a density wave	What is a good analogy to explain nature of a density wave to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 large group of people walking through a crowded room
A density wave is like when you are cooking a pot of macaroni and cheese. The pasta is all packed together at the beginning, but as it cooks, it starts to spread out and takes up more space.	nature of a density wave	What is a good analogy to explain nature of a density wave to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 pasta cooking######A density wave is like when you are cooking a pot of macaroni and cheese. The pasta is all packed together at the beginning, but as it cooks, it starts to spread out and takes up more space.
Enzymes are like tiny machines in your body that help to break down food. Just as you need a machine to chop up vegetables for a stir-fry, you need enzymes to chop up the food in your stomach so that it can be absorbed into your bloodstream.	enzymes	What is a good analogy to explain enzymes to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 tiny machines in your body###| breaking down food | chopping up the food
Enzymes are proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions in the body. Enzymes work like a chef in a kitchen. The chef uses different utensils and ingredients to create a meal. In the same way, enzymes use different molecules to create new molecules.	enzymes	What is a good analogy to explain enzymes to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 chefs

The human active memory system is like a computer's hard drive. It can store a limited number of items and it takes time to access the information that is stored. The RAM, or random access memory, is like the working memory in humans. This is where we do our thinking and it has a limited capacity as well. When something new comes into our working memory, we have to decide what to do with it: either keep it there until we can deal with it later or forget about it altogether.	human active memory system	What is a good analogy to explain human active memory system to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 computer's hard drive###| RAM | working memory
The human active memory system can be likened to a kitchen. The brain is the stove, and the working memory is the stovetop. Just as pots and pans can be placed on the stovetop to cook, information can be placed in the working memory to be processed. Once the information has been cooked, it is then transferred to long-term memory for storage.	human active memory system	What is a good analogy to explain human active memory system to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 kitchen
One way to think of the human active memory system is as an ongoing grocery list. Whenever you encounter something newwhether it's a new food at the store or a new word in a foreign languageyou add it to your list. Later, when you need to remember that item, you can access your list and recall it from memory.	human active memory system	What is a good analogy to explain human active memory system to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 ongoing grocery list
Cooking a pot of soup on the stove is a good analogy to explain rate-determining step of a reaction. The rate at which the soup heats up is determined by how long it takes for the heat from the burner to transfer through the pot and heat up the soup. The rate-determining step in this analogy is how long it takes for heat to travel from the burner to the soup.	rate-determining step of a reaction	What is a good analogy to explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking a pot of soup on the stove
The rate-determining step of a reaction can be thought of as being similar to the act of boiling water. The time it takes for the water to come to a boil is determined by the rate-determining step (the point at which enough heat has been applied to cause a significant change in the system). In many cases, this is also when the most energy is released from the system.	rate-determining step of a reaction	What is a good analogy to explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 boiling water
If you want to make a pot of coffee, the first step is to pour water into the pot. The next step is to add coffee grounds. The final step is to turn on the stove. These three steps are all necessary in order to make coffee, and the rate-determining step is adding the coffee grounds, since this determines how long it takes for the coffee to be made.	rate-determining step of a reaction	What is a good analogy to explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 adding the coffee grounds
Column chromatography is like making a pizza. The different ingredients (the solutes) are the toppings and the dough is the column itself. You put the toppings on the dough and then cook it in an oven. The oven cooks the pizza and also separates the toppings from each other. This is similar to how column chromatography works; it separates the different solutes based on their chemical properties.	column chromatography	What is a good analogy to explain column chromatography to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 making a pizza
A student who likes cooking might understand column chromatography if they think of it as a way to separate ingredients in a recipe. The ingredients are put into the column, and then a liquid is poured over them. The different ingredients will move through the column at different speeds, so they can be separated out.	column chromatography	What is a good analogy to explain column chromatography to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 separating ingredients in a recipe
Column chromatography can be thought of as a way to separate ingredients in a recipe. The different ingredients are placed into columns, and then water is slowly poured over them. The ingredients will move through the column at different speeds, based on their size and weight. This allows for the separation of each ingredient.	column chromatography	What is a good analogy to explain column chromatography to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 separating ingredients in a recipe
A good analogy to explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to someone who likes cooking is as follows: think about a pot of soup on the stove. If you are stirring the soup constantly, it will be in a state of dynamic equilibrium because there is an equal amount of hot and cold liquid in the pot. However, if you stop stirring the soup, the warm liquid will gradually move to the top while the colder liquid sinks to the bottom. This is analogous to how chemical equilibrium works; if you disturb the system (by stirring), it will remain in equilibrium, but if you leave it alone, it will eventually reach equilibrium on its own.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	What is a good analogy to explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 stirring a pot of soup
Cooking is a good analogy to explain dynamic chemical equilibrium because it involves two types of reactions: endothermic and exothermic. In an endothermic reaction, heat is absorbed from the surroundings, whereas in an exothermic reaction, heat is released into the surroundings. When these two types of reactions occur simultaneously in an equilibrium state, the net result is no change in temperature.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	What is a good analogy to explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking
A good analogy to explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to a student who likes cooking is that the reaction between two ingredients in a recipe is like a chemical equilibrium. Just as the reaction reaches equilibrium, so too does the recipe reach a state of balance where all of the ingredients are mixed together in just the right proportions.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	What is a good analogy to explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 recipe reaching a state of balance

A resonance hybrid is a molecule that is made up of two or more atoms that share one or more pairs of electrons. This can be compared to two people who are cooking together in the kitchen. In the same way, the atoms in a resonance hybrid work together to create a new molecule.	resonance hybrid	What is a good analogy to explain resonance hybrid to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 two people cooking together in the kitchen

A good analogy to explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to a student who likes cooking is using measuring cups. Suppose you are baking a cake and need 1 cup of sugar. If you only have 2/3 cup of sugar, then the 1 cup of sugar is the limiting reactant. You can't make the cake with just 2/3 cup of sugar because there isn't enough for all the other ingredients. The excess reactant would be the 1/3 cup of sugar that isn't needed for the recipe.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	What is a good analogy to explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 measuring cups in cooking
One way to think about it is with food. If you are cooking a meal and only have so much of one ingredient, that ingredient is the limiting reactant. You can't make any more of it no matter how long you cook the dish. The other ingredients in the dish are excess reactants.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	What is a good analogy to explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking a meal
A good analogy for limiting reactant and excess reactant is to think of a recipe for cookies. The recipe might call for 1 cup of sugar, but if you only have 2/3 cup of sugar, then the recipe will only use up 2/3 cup of sugar and you will have 1/3 cup of sugar left over. This is an example of an excess reactant. If you want to make more cookies, you can either add another batch of the same recipe or change the recipe to use up all the sugar. Another example would be making a cake where the recipe calls for 3 eggs but you only have 2 eggs. In this case, the cake will only use up 2 eggs and you will have 1 egg left over. This is an example of a limiting reactant.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	What is a good analogy to explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 recipe for cookies

This analogy can be used when explaining an operating system kernel to someone who likes cooking. It has a hard texture and a mild flavor, just like in cooking.	operating systems kernel	What is a good analogy to explain operating systems kernel to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 kernel in cooking

Similarly, the kernel is responsible for all of the activity on a computer, and coordinates all of the different tasks that are happening on the computer.	operating systems kernel	What is a good analogy to explain operating systems kernel to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cook in a restaurant
A good analogy to explain limiting reactant to a student who likes cooking is that the limiting reactant is like the spice in food. If there is too much or too little of it, then the flavor of the food will be off. In a chemical reaction, if there is too much or too little of the limiting reactant, then the reaction won't proceed as planned.	limiting reactant	What is a good analogy to explain limiting reactant to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 spice in food
A good analogy to explain limiting reactant is using cooking as an example. Imagine you are making a cake and you only have two eggs. If you use both eggs, the cake will be very dense. However, if you use one egg, the cake will be less dense. This is because eggs are a limiting reactant in this recipe.	limiting reactant	What is a good analogy to explain limiting reactant to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 using eggs in a cake recipe
If you are cooking a meal and only have so much chicken, then the chicken is the limiting reactant. You can't make more chicken no matter how long you cook it. The other ingredients in the meal (rice, vegetables, etc.) will be used up until there is no more chicken left.	limiting reactant	What is a good analogy to explain limiting reactant to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking a meal

When you cook, different ingredients interact with each other to create a new dish. A good analogy to explain interaction between drugs and receptor sites to a student who likes cooking is as follows: Suppose you have two pots on the stove, one filled with water and one empty. If you place a pot of cold water onto the empty pot, the cold water will spread throughout the pot. Now suppose you add some hot water to the pot of cold water. The hot water will move away from where it was added and towards the colder areas of the pot. In this analogy, adding a drug (the hot water) to a receptor site (the empty pot) would make it more active (cause it to spread out).	interaction between drugs and receptor sites	What is a good analogy to explain interaction between drugs and receptor sites to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 adding a drug to a receptor site

The trees age calculation is like a recipe. Just as you need flour, sugar, eggs, and butter to make a cake, the tree needs carbon dioxide (CO 2 ), water (H 2 O), and sunlight (S) to create its tissues. The proportions of these ingredients determine how old the cake will be. In the same way, scientists can calculate a trees age by measuring how much CO 2 it has taken up from the atmosphere and determining how much H 2 O is left in its wood.	tree's age calculation	What is a good analogy to explain tree's age calculation to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 recipe
One way to think about how trees calculate their age is to imagine that they have a kitchen timer in their trunk. Each time the tree grows a ring, it sets the timer back to zero. Over time, as more and more rings are added, the timer slowly counts up. So, just like you can tell how long ago something happened by counting the number of hours since it started, trees can tell how old they are by counting the number of rings since they began growing	tree's age calculation	What is a good analogy to explain tree's age calculation to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 kitchen timer in trunk
Cooking a turkey is like calculating the age of a tree. To figure out the age of a turkey, you need to know how long it has been since it was hatched. To calculate the age of a tree, you need to know how long it has been since it was planted.	tree's age calculation	What is a good analogy to explain tree's age calculation to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 figuring out the age of a turkey
When you are cooking, and need to use a lot of sugar in your recipe, it is helpful to understand the process of glycolysis. The sugar is broken down into molecules that can be used by the body to create energy. This same process happens in our cells when we need energy to do things like move or think.	glycolysis	What is a good analogy to explain glycolysis to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking
Cooking a pizza is a good analogy to glycolysis. The dough is the glucose molecule, the sauce is the pyruvate molecule, and the cheese is the lactic acid molecule.	glycolysis	What is a good analogy to explain glycolysis to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking a pizza
One way to think about glycolysis is as the cooking of a pizza. The first step, like the spreading of sauce on a pizza crust, is the conversion of glucose (sugar) into two molecules of glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate. This process is catalyzed by an enzyme called glucokinase.	glycolysis	What is a good analogy to explain glycolysis to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking a pizza
Particles in a gas (like the air) are constantly bumping into each other and exchanging energy. The energy that is passed along when two particles collide is called momentum. When a high-energy light particle, like a photon, collides with a low-energy particle, like an atom, the photon can transfer some of its energy to the atom. This process is called scattering. In anti-stokes scattering, the photons lose more energy than they gain from the atoms, so their overall momentum decreases. It's kind of like when you cook something on high heat  it takes more effort (and fuel) to get it up to temperature than if you were to cook it on low heat for a longer period of time.	anti-stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking something on high heat
One way to think of anti-Stokes scattering is as if it is the opposite of stirring a pot of soup. When you stir a pot of soup, you are using energy to make the molecules in the soup move around. This makes the soup hotter. Anti-Stokes scattering happens when light hits a molecule and scatters in the opposite direction that the light was traveling. This makes the molecule colder.	anti-stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 opposite of stirring a pot of soup
One analogy to explain anti-stokes scattering to a student who likes cooking is that it is similar to the stirring of a pot of soup. Just as stirring the soup can make it warmer, anti-stokes scattering makes light particles move faster and become hotter.	anti-stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 stirring a pot of soup
Cooking and stokes scattering are both about heating up food. With cooking, you put the food in a hot pan and it starts to heat up. The hotter the pan, the more quickly the food will cook. With stokes scattering, you shine a light on something and it starts to heat up. The brighter the light, the more quickly it will heat up.	stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain stokes scattering to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking
Cooking is all about manipulating the energy that goes into your food. You use different techniques to heat, cook, and flavor your food. When light hits a material, it bounces off in all directions. This is like when you toss a pan of frying bacon around on the stovetop. The energy from the heat makes the bacon move around and bounce off each other. This is what causes the delicious smell of cooking bacon!	stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain stokes scattering to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 frying bacon
Cooking with a gas stove is similar to stokes scattering. The heat from the flame produces waves of energy that move through the air. When these waves hit an object, they cause it to heat up and start cooking.	stokes scattering	What is a good analogy to explain stokes scattering to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking with a gas stove
If you think of a teaspoon as the amount of a drug in a single dose, and tablespoons as multiple doses, then the median lethal dose would be the amount of drug it takes to kill half of the people who take it. So if you imagine cooking with teaspoons of salt, most people would not have any problems. But if you were to use tablespoons instead, there is a greater chance that someone might overdose on salt because there is more in each spoonful.	median lethal dose	What is a good analogy to explain median lethal dose to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 amount of drug it takes to kill half of the people who take it
A good analogy to explain median lethal dose to a student who likes cooking is that the median lethal dose would be the equivalent of two tablespoons of arsenic in a gallon of water.	median lethal dose	What is a good analogy to explain median lethal dose to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 two tablespoons of arsenic in a gallon of water
A median lethal dose is a measure of how much of a particular substance it takes to kill half the members of a tested population. In cooking, this would be equivalent to finding out how much poison it would take to kill 50% of the people who eat it.	median lethal dose	What is a good analogy to explain median lethal dose to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 poison in cooking

This makes the food easier to digest and helps your body absorb all the nutrients it needs. Enzymes work in a similar way inside your body, breaking down complex molecules in the food you eat into simple ones that can be used for energy or building new cells.	enzyme mechanism	What is a good analogy to explain enzyme mechanism to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking spices
One analogy to explain enzyme mechanism is that of an oven. Enzymes are like the heating elements in an oven, and they cause a chemical reaction (cooking the food). The temperature of the oven (the environment) determines how quickly the food will cook. The same is true for enzymesthe environment (temperature) affects how quickly they can cause a chemical reaction.	enzyme mechanism	What is a good analogy to explain enzyme mechanism to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 oven

A thermostat is a lot like a cooking thermometer. Just as cooks use thermometers to make sure their food reaches the right temperature, thermostats help heaters and air conditioners maintain the desired indoor temperature by constantly measuring it. If the reading falls below or rises above the set point, the furnace or air conditioner turns on or off to correct the situation.	thermostat	What is a good analogy to explain thermostat to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking thermometer
A thermostat is like a chefs oven. The chef can set the oven to a certain temperature, and then the thermostat will maintain that temperature by turning on or off the oven as needed.	thermostat	What is a good analogy to explain thermostat to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 chefs oven

A chemical equilibrium is very similar to a recipe for a dish. In both cases, the ingredients are combined in specific amounts to create a final product. If too much or too little of an ingredient is added, the end result will be different than what was intended. In the same way, if too much or too little of a chemical reaction occurs, the equilibrium state will be disrupted and the system will not work correctly.	chemical equilibrium	What is a good analogy to explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 recipe for a dish
One way to think of chemical equilibrium is to imagine a pan on the stove with food in it. If you turn up the heat, the food will start to cook. However, if you keep turning up the heat, eventually the food will reach a point where it starts to cook too quickly and burns. At this point, you have to turn down the heat or else the food will burn. In much the same way, when a chemical reaction reaches equilibrium, it has reached a point where further change is not possible without outside interference.	chemical equilibrium	What is a good analogy to explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 a pan on the stove with food in it
A good analogy to explain chemical equilibrium is the example of a pot of boiling water. At first, the temperature of the water increases as energy is added, but eventually the system reaches equilibrium and the temperature stops increasing. The same thing happens with chemicals in a reaction - at first they react and create new products, but eventually they reach equilibrium where there is no more change in concentration.	chemical equilibrium	What is a good analogy to explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 a pot of boiling water
A good analogy to explain just-in-time manufacturing is as follows: Suppose you are cooking a meal and you only have one pot. You need the pot to cook the pasta, so you can't start cooking the sauce until after the pasta is done. The sauce would be considered "just in time" because it is cooked when you need it, not before.	just-in-time	What is a good analogy to explain just-in-time to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking a meal
Just-in-time is like cooking a meal. You only cook what you need, when you need it. You don't make a big pot of soup and then have to eat it for the next five days.	just-in-time	What is a good analogy to explain just-in-time to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking a meal

You only cook what you need, when you need it, so you don't have any leftovers.	just-in-time	What is a good analogy to explain just-in-time to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 preparing food for a party
One analogy to explain adaptive immunity is that of a police force. The police are constantly monitoring the city for any signs of trouble and when they see something, they respond quickly. This is similar to how our immune system works. Our cells are constantly scanning our body for anything that looks like it could be a threat and then our immune system responds quickly to get rid of it.	adaptive immunity	What is a good analogy to explain adaptive immunity to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 police force
If you think of the immune system as a group of chefs, then adaptive immunity would be the sous chef. The sous chef is responsible for learning how to cook the dishes and preparing them perfectly. When there is a new dish that needs to be cooked, the sous chef will work with the chefs to create a recipe and make sure it is perfect. In the same way, adaptive immunity works with other parts of the immune system to learn how to fight off infections and protect us from disease.	adaptive immunity	What is a good analogy to explain adaptive immunity to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 sous chef
One way to think of adaptive immunity is as a well-trained chef. The immune system has been exposed to many different viruses and bacteria, so it knows how to quickly recognize them and mount a response. This is similar to how a good chef can look at a dish with lots of ingredients and know what flavors will work together.	adaptive immunity	What is a good analogy to explain adaptive immunity to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 a well-trained chef
A cook follows a recipe to make a dish. The recipe is like ohm's law, it tells the cook how much of each ingredient to use and in what order to put them together. Just as with electricity, if the cook uses too much or too little of an ingredient, the dish will not turn out right.	ohm's law	What is a good analogy to explain ohm's law to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 a recipe
A good analogy to explain ohm's law to a student who likes cooking is the electric stove. The stove has four knobs that control how much heat is applied to the burner. If you turn the knob up all the way, more electricity will flow through the burner and it will get hotter. If you turn the knob down, less electricity will flow through the burner and it will be cooler. Ohm's law is like this - if you increase or decrease the amount of current (electricity) flowing through a wire, it will cause a corresponding change in voltage (heat).	ohm's law	What is a good analogy to explain ohm's law to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 electric stove
Just as a recipe calls for certain measurements of ingredients like teaspoons and tablespoons, an electric current is measured in amps, volts, and ohms. Just as you wouldn't want to put too much salt in your food, you don't want too much current flowing through a circuit. Too much current can overheat or even melt the components in the circuit. Just like adding more vinegar makes a stronger dressing, increasing the voltage makes the current flow faster through the circuit.	ohm's law	What is a good analogy to explain ohm's law to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 recipe measurements###| amps | vinegar

Transcription is a lot like cooking. When you cook, you are taking the ingredients (like flour, sugar, and eggs) and turning them into something new (like cake or cookies). Transcription is the same way - you are taking the genetic information from DNA and turning it into proteins.	transcription	What is a good analogy to explain transcription to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking
Transcription is like following a recipe for a dish. The recipe tells you what ingredients to use and how to put them together. Transcription works in a similar way, by providing instructions for building RNA from DNA sequences.	transcription	What is a good analogy to explain transcription to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 following a recipe
RNA polymerase can be thought of as a chef in a kitchen. The chef is responsible for reading recipes and then cooking the food according to the recipe. In the same way, RNA polymerase reads DNA sequences and then creates new RNA molecules based on those sequences.	rna polymerase	What is a good analogy to explain rna polymerase to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 chef in a kitchen
A good analogy to explain RNA polymerase to a student who likes cooking is that it is similar to the baker in a bakery. The baker makes all of the bread by mixing together different ingredients and then baking the dough in an oven. In much the same way, RNA polymerase assembles new RNA molecules by combining pieces of genetic information from different sources.	rna polymerase	What is a good analogy to explain rna polymerase to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 baker in a bakery
A good analogy to explain RNA polymerase to a student who likes cooking is that the enzyme is like a cookbook. It tells the cells how to put together the individual ingredients (nucleotides) into chains (polymers).	rna polymerase	What is a good analogy to explain rna polymerase to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cookbook
Ribosomes can be thought of as the kitchen appliances in a cell. Just like an oven, stovetop, refrigerator, and dishwasher are used in a kitchen to cook food, ribosomes are used in cells to create proteins.	ribosome	What is a good analogy to explain ribosome to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 kitchen appliance
Ribosomes are like the stove in a kitchen. The DNA is like the recipe, and the ribosomes are like the cook that follows the recipe to create something delicious!	ribosome	What is a good analogy to explain ribosome to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 stove###| DNA | recipe###| ribosome | cook
A ribosome is like a kitchen. The DNA in the nucleus is like the recipe book. The mRNA leaves the nucleus and goes into the ribosomes, which are like kitchens. In these kitchens, different parts of the recipe (amino acids) are chopped up and put together to create new proteins	ribosome	What is a good analogy to explain ribosome to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 kitchen###| DNA | recipe book###| mRNA | leaving the nucleus and going into the ribosomes
One way to think of activator proteins is as the "seasoning" in a recipe. Just like salt, pepper and other spices can enhance the flavor of food, activator proteins help to activate (or turn on) certain genes in the cell.	activator protein	What is a good analogy to explain activator protein to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 seasoning in a recipe
An activator protein is like an oven timer. The timer tells the oven when to start cooking and when to stop cooking.	activator protein	What is a good analogy to explain activator protein to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 oven timer
An activator protein is like a chef. The chef activates the stove by turning on the knob, which then begins to heat up the pan. The activator protein does something similar by starting the process of gene expression.	activator protein	What is a good analogy to explain activator protein to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 chef
A circuit is like a recipe for baking cookies. Just as you need specific ingredients in order to make cookies, you need specific components in an electric circuit for it to function. The ingredients (or components) in a recipe might vary depending on what kind of cookie you want to make, but there are some basics that are always required (flour, sugar, butter, etc.). In the same way, there are some essentials that are always needed in an electric circuit (a power source, wires, a light bulb, etc.).	electric circuit	What is a good analogy to explain electric circuit to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 recipe for baking cookies
Electricity is like the heat from a stove. Just as you need to turn on the stove to get the heat, you need to turn on the electricity to get it flowing through your house. The stove analogy also works well because when you have something cooking on the stove, if there's not enough heat, it won't cook properly; and if there's too much heat, it could burn. It's important to have just the right amount of heat so that things cook evenly and don't over or undercook. In an electric circuit, you need just the right amount of voltage (heat) for things to work properly without burning out or blowing a fuse.	electric circuit	What is a good analogy to explain electric circuit to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 stove
Cooking a meal is like creating an electric circuit. Just as you need to have the right ingredients in your pot in order to create a delicious dinner, you need the right materials in your electrical circuit in order for it to work properly. In both cases, if one of the components is missing or incorrect, the whole system falls apart.	electric circuit	What is a good analogy to explain electric circuit to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking a meal
A good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to a student who likes cooking is the way oil and water react when you try to mix them. Oil and water don't mix because the oil molecules are attracted to each other more than they are attracted to the water molecules. This is called the hydrophobic effect.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 oil and water don't mix
Cooking oils and fats are hydrophobic because they do not mix with water. This is why you can put oil in a pan to heat it up without the water boiling away. The hot oil will rise to the top of the water, creating a barrier between the two that prevents them from mixing.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 oil and water not mixing
Water molecules are "sticky" and like to stick together. This is because the oxygen atom in water molecule has a strong pull on the hydrogen atoms in other water molecules. When water molecules are stuck together, they form a network that can hold onto things like dirt or food particles. Hydrophobic substances do not have this same sticking ability, so when they come into contact with water, they push the water away. Think of it as if the hydrophobic substance is an ice cube and the water is a glass of soda. The ice cube will push all of the soda out of the way to take up space in the glass.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 an ice cube in a glass of soda
One way to think of how a biological signal is transduced is to imagine it as being kind of like cooking food. In both cases, you are taking something raw and converting it into something that is more useful or edible. With cooking, you take raw ingredients like vegetables or meat and cook them in various ways until they are ready to eat. With signal transduction, you take a molecule called a ligand (something that can bind to another molecule) and convert it into a signal that can be read by the cell. This signal might tell the cell to do something like divide or produce some other protein.	biological signal transduction	What is a good analogy to explain biological signal transduction to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking food
One way to think of signal transduction is as a recipe for a cake. The ingredients (e.g., sugar, eggs, butter, flour) are mixed together in the correct proportions and then put into an oven to bake. The baking process causes the cake to rise and become fluffy and delicious. In much the same way, biological signals cause cells to respond by activating different proteins that carry out specific functions within the cell.	biological signal transduction	What is a good analogy to explain biological signal transduction to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 recipe for a cake
Biological signal transduction is a little like cooking. In both cases, you are taking something raw and turning it into something else that is more useful or edible. With cooking, you might start with some vegetables and cook them in a pot on the stove. This converts the vegetables from their raw state into something that is more cooked and can be eaten. With biological signal transduction, you might start with a molecule called a ligand, which is kind of like the vegetable in this analogy. The ligand binds to a receptor on the surface of a cell, sort of like how you would put the vegetables in the pot. Then, inside the cell, there are all sorts of enzymes that get activated by the receptor-ligand interaction. These enzymes then go on to convert other molecules within the cell into new products that can help or harm the cell. Just as with cooking, there are lots of different steps involved in biological signal transduction and not every process is always successful!	biological signal transduction	What is a good analogy to explain biological signal transduction to student who likes cooking?	ht	cooking	 cooking
Nadh is like the salt in cooking. It is a necessary ingredient that makes the food taste better.	nadh	Using an analogy, explain nadh to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 salt in cooking
Cooking proteins is a lot like cooking other foods. You need to use the right ingredients, cook them at the right temperature, and use the right techniques. Proteins are made up of amino acids, and there are 20 different kinds of amino acids. Some proteins are made up of just a few amino acids, while others are made up of many. Proteins can be cooked in many different ways, but they all have to be cooked properly in order to be safe to eat.	proteins	Using an analogy, explain proteins to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking other foods

Endoplasmic reticulum is like the kitchen of a house. It is where all the cooking happens. The endoplasmic reticulum is responsible for making all the proteins that are needed in the cell.	endoplasmic reticulum	Using an analogy, explain endoplasmic reticulum to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 kitchen of a house
The Golgi apparatus is a bit like a kitchen. It takes the raw ingredients that come in from the cell's cytoplasm (like flour, sugar, eggs, and butter) and processes them into something that the cell can use (like cakes, cookies, and pastries). The Golgi apparatus also packages up the finished products and sends them off to other parts of the cell, or even to other cells.	golgi	Using an analogy, explain golgi to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 kitchen
The plasma membrane is like a kitchen stove. The stove has a heating element that produces heat, and the heat is used to cook food. The plasma membrane has a heating element that produces heat, and the heat is used to cook food. The stove has a cooking surface that the food is placed on, and the food is cooked by the heat that is produced by the heating element. The plasma membrane has a surface that the food is placed on, and the food is cooked by the heat that is produced by the heating element. The stove has a fan that circulates the air around the cooking surface, and the fan helps to cook the food evenly. The plasma membrane has a fan that circulates the molecules around the surface, and the fan helps to cook the food evenly.	plasma membrane	Using an analogy, explain plasma membrane to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 kitchen stove

Action potential is like when you turn on the stove to cook. The stove is like the neuron, and the gas is like the action potential. When you turn on the stove, the gas starts flowing and the heat builds up. When the heat reaches a certain point, the gas ignites and the flame starts cooking the food. In the same way, when the action potential reaches a certain point, it ignites and the neuron fires.	action potential	Using an analogy, explain action potential to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 turning on the stove###| neuron | stove###| gas | action potential

Just as in cooking, where heat is transferred in a particular direction, electrical current flows in a particular direction. The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a reaction. This is the step that determines how fast a reaction will occur. In cooking, the rate-determining step is often the step where the food is being cooked. For example, if you are cooking a steak, the rate-determining step is the step where the steak is being cooked.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 the slowest step in a reaction
Column chromatography is like cooking a big pot of spaghetti. The spaghetti is the mixture of different ingredients, and the pot is the column. The ingredients are mixed together and then put into the pot. The pot is heated until the spaghetti is cooked. The cooked spaghetti is then put into a colander to separate the spaghetti from the water. The water is the unwanted ingredients, and the spaghetti is the wanted ingredients. The same thing happens with column chromatography. The mixture is put into the column, and the column is heated until the mixture is cooked. The cooked mixture is then put into a colander to separate the wanted ingredients from the unwanted ingredients.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking a big pot of spaghetti
Dynamic chemical equilibrium is like a pot of soup on the stove. The soup is in a state of equilibrium where the temperature is constant and the soup is neither boiling nor cooling. If you turn up the heat, the soup will start to boil. If you turn the heat down, the soup will start to cool. The soup is in a state of dynamic equilibrium where the temperature is constant even though the soup is boiling or cooling.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 a pot of soup on the stove

A eukaryotic cell is like a big kitchen. The cell has a lot of different appliances, like a stove, a refrigerator, and a sink. The appliances are all connected to each other, and they all work together to help the cook prepare a meal.	eukaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain eukaryotic cell to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 a big kitchen
A prokaryotic cell is like a kitchen. The cell has a stove (mitochondria), oven (ribosomes), and refrigerator (cytoplasm). The cell also has cabinets (nucleus) and a sink (cytosol). The cell uses the stove to cook food (proteins) and the oven to bake food (DNA). The refrigerator keeps food cold (glycogen). The cabinets store food (amino acids). The sink washes dishes (waste products).	prokaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain prokaryotic cell to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 kitchen
The kernel is the most important part of an operating system. It is responsible for managing all of the system's resources and ensuring that all of the other parts of the system work together. It is like the cook in a kitchen. The cook is responsible for ensuring that all of the ingredients are properly prepared and that the food is cooked correctly.	operating systems kernel	Using an analogy, explain operating systems kernel to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cook in a kitchen
A limiting reactant is a reactant that is in short supply and limits the amount of product that can be formed. In cooking, if you only have one egg, that egg will be the limiting reactant and you will only be able to make a single egg dish.	limiting reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 a reactant in short supply
Helicase is a protein that helps to unwind DNA so that it can be copied. It is a bit like a cooking assistant who helps to uncoil the spaghetti so that it can be cooked more easily.	helicase	Using an analogy, explain helicase to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking assistant who helps to uncoil the spaghetti
DNA replication binding proteins are like the kitchen utensils that help you cook. The proteins help to bind the DNA together so that it can be copied accurately.	dna replication binding proteins	Using an analogy, explain dna replication binding proteins to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 kitchen utensils
Ligase is a protein that helps to join two DNA strands together. It is like a kitchen tool called a "sealer" that helps to join two pieces of food together.	ligase	Using an analogy, explain ligase to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 kitchen tool called a "sealer"
Cooking is all about controlling the process to make sure the food is cooked evenly and to the desired level of doneness. The same is true for process control in a manufacturing or industrial setting. The process controller monitors the process and makes adjustments as needed to ensure the process stays on track.	process control block	Using an analogy, explain process control block to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking
Cooking is all about taking a set of ingredients and turning them into a dish that is both delicious and satisfying. In a similar way, encoding is all about taking a set of data and turning it into a message that can be understood by a computer. The ingredients in this case are the bits that make up the data, while the dish is the message that is created. Just as with cooking, there are a variety of different encoding methods that can be used, each with its own strengths and weaknesses.	message encoding	Using an analogy, explain message encoding to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking
When you cook a dish, you use ingredients that interact with each other to create a new flavor. In a similar way, drugs interact with receptor sites to create new effects. For example, if you add garlic to a dish, it will interact with other ingredients to create a new flavor. In the same way, drugs can interact with receptor sites to create new effects.	interaction between drugs and receptor sites	Using an analogy, explain interaction between drugs and receptor sites to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 interaction between ingredients and garlic
A monitor is like a stovetop. It is a surface that provides heat so that you can cook food.	monitor	Using an analogy, explain monitor to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 stovetop
The CPU is like the cook in the kitchen. It is responsible for preparing all of the food. It decides what to cook, how to cook it, and when to cook it.	cpu	Using an analogy, explain cpu to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cook in the kitchen
A motherboard is like the kitchen countertop. It is a flat surface that everything else is attached to. The stove is attached to the kitchen countertop, as is the refrigerator, the sink, and the cabinets. The motherboard is the flat surface that everything else is attached to in a computer. The processor is attached to the motherboard, as are the memory, the hard drive, the video card, and the sound card.	motherboard	Using an analogy, explain motherboard to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 kitchen countertop

The power supply unit has a cord that plugs into the wall and a plug that goes into the appliance.	power supply unit	Using an analogy, explain power supply unit to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 battery in a car

In the same way that a chef's knife can chop, slice, and dice vegetables quickly and easily, an audio card can help you edit and produce audio files quickly and easily.	audio card	Using an analogy, explain audio card to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 chef's knife

Cooking is all about ratios. For example, when you are baking a cake, you might use one cup of sugar for every two cups of flour. This is a ratio of 1:2. Tree's age calculation is also all about ratios. We can think of the tree's age as a ratio of the number of rings in the tree to the total number of years the tree has been alive.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 ratios (1:2)
Glycolysis is like cooking a pizza. The pizza dough is the glucose molecule and the toppings are the pyruvate molecules. The oven is the body's temperature and the pizza is the energy that the body needs.	glycolysis	Using an analogy, explain glycolysis to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking a pizza
When you cook a pot of soup on the stove, the heat from the stove causes the soup to boil. The boiling soup produces bubbles that rise to the surface and burst. The bubbles produce heat and light that we see as they rise to the surface and burst. This is an example of stokes scattering.Now let's imagine that we have a pot of soup on the stove, and we add a few drops of food coloring to it. The food coloring will slowly diffuse through the soup, and eventually it will reach the surface. As the food coloring diffuses to the surface, it will produce bubbles. These bubbles will rise to the surface and burst, just like the bubbles produced by the boiling soup. However, the bubbles produced by the food coloring will not produce as much heat or light as the bubbles produced by the boiling soup. This is because the food coloring is not as hot as the soup.This is an example of anti-stokes scattering. The bubbles produced by the food coloring are not as hot as the bubbles produced by the boiling soup, so they produce less heat and light.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 food coloring diffusing through soup
Cooking is all about heat. The higher the heat, the faster the cooking. When you turn up the heat on your stove, the molecules in the food start to move faster. This is because the heat is energy, and energy makes things move. The faster the molecules move, the more they bump into each other. When they bump into each other, they exchange energy. This is called heat transfer. The more heat you add, the more the molecules move, and the more they bump into each other. This causes the food to cook faster.Stokes scattering is a lot like cooking. The higher the energy, the faster the scattering. When you turn up the energy on your light source, the photons start to move faster. This is because the energy is pushing them along. The faster the photons move, the more they bump into the atoms in the material. When they bump into the atoms, they exchange energy. This is called scattering. The more energy you add, the more the photons move, and the more they bump into the atoms. This causes the material to scatter light faster.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that is lethal to 50% of the population. In other words, it is the dose that kills half of the people who take it. To put it in perspective, think about cooking. If you are cooking a pot of soup and you add too much salt, it will be too salty and no one will want to eat it. However, if you add too little salt, the soup will be bland and no one will want to eat it either. The median lethal dose is like the perfect amount of salt to add to a pot of soup - it will make the soup taste just right and everyone will want to eat it.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 perfect amount of salt to add to a pot of soup
The universe is like a big pot of soup. It's made up of all the ingredients that are put in it. The ingredients are the planets, the stars, and everything else in the universe. The soup is cooked over time, and it changes as it cooks.	universe	Using an analogy, explain universe to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 big pot of soup
Enzyme mechanism is like cooking. The enzyme is like the stove, and the substrate is like the food. The enzyme and the substrate react to create the product, just like the food and the stove react to create the meal.	enzyme mechanism	Using an analogy, explain enzyme mechanism to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 cooking
Anova is a statistical technique used to compare the means of two or more groups. It is similar to the t-test, but is more powerful. It is used to determine whether the means of the groups are statistically different from each other.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 t-test
Chemical equilibrium is like a recipe for a cake. The recipe has all of the ingredients in it, and as long as you follow the instructions, you will end up with a cake. The same is true for chemical equilibrium. The reactants and products are all in the equation, and as long as the conditions are right, the equilibrium will be reached.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 recipe for a cake

Adaptive immunity can be thought of as a chefs ability to adapt their cooking style to the preferences of their diners. In the same way that a chef might adjust the seasoning or ingredients in a dish to make it more palatable to a particular diner, the adaptive immune system can adjust its response to a particular pathogen or antigen. This allows the immune system to mount a more effective response against pathogens that it has previously encountered.	adaptive immunity	Using an analogy, explain adaptive immunity to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 chefs ability to adapt their cooking style
Just as a recipe calls for specific measurements of ingredients, an electric current is described by its Ohm's Law as a specific voltage (V) and resistance (R). Just as too much or too little of an ingredient can ruin a dish, too much or too little current can damage an electronic component. Just as following a recipe results in a tasty dish, following Ohm's Law results in a correctly operating electrical circuit.	ohm's law	Using an analogy, explain ohm's law to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 following a recipe

Water is like a sauce and the oil is like the spices. When you mix the water and oil together, they don't mix well. This is because the water and oil are hydrophobic, which means they don't like to be around each other.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes cooking.	lt	cooking	 mixing water and oil

DNA is the recipe for making a person. Just as there are many different recipes for cookies, pizzas, and cakes, there are many different recipes for making people. But all of these recipes have some common ingredients - like flour, sugar, eggs, and butter. Similarly, DNA is made up of four chemicals that are found in all living things: adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and thymine (T). These chemicals pair up to form what we call "bases."	dna	Using an analogy, explain dna to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 recipe for making a person###| common ingredients | flour, sugar, eggs, butter###| bases | adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and thymine (T)

The Golgi apparatus is a bit like the kitchen of a restaurant. It takes all of the raw ingredients that come in from different parts of the cell, and it processes them into finished products that can be used by the rest of the cell.	golgi	Using an analogy, explain golgi to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen of a restaurant
The Golgi apparatus is a bit like the kitchen of a restaurant. It takes all of the ingredients that have been ordered and prepares them into meals. The Golgi apparatus packages proteins and other materials into small sacs called vesicles which it then sends to other parts of the cell or to the outside of the cell.	golgi	Using an analogy, explain golgi to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen of a restaurant
The Golgi apparatus is like a kitchen. It takes the raw ingredients that come in from the cell membrane and processes them, preparing them for use inside of the cell. The end products of this processing are then sent out through the cell membrane to be used by other parts of the cell or transported to other cells.	golgi	Using an analogy, explain golgi to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen
Cooking can be thought of as a process by which heat is transferred from one object to another in order to cook food. The object that transfers the heat is called the heater, and the object that absorbs the heat is called the cooker. In this analogy, the plasma membrane can be thought of as the heater, and the cells within an organism can be thought of as the cookers. The plasma membrane transfers energy (heat) to cells in order to cook them, just like a stove top transfers energy to pots and pans in order to cook food.	plasma membrane	Using an analogy, explain plasma membrane to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 stove top
The plasma membrane is like a kitchen wall. It separates the inside of the kitchen from the outside world. The ingredients that are on the kitchen side can't go out, and the ingredients on the outside can't come in.	plasma membrane	Using an analogy, explain plasma membrane to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen wall
The plasma membrane is like a skillet. Foods (proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids) are placed in the pan and cooked at different temperatures to create a variety of dishes. The proteins can be browned on the outside while the carbohydrates are cooked until they are soft. The lipids can be fried until they are crispy.	plasma membrane	Using an analogy, explain plasma membrane to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 skillet

All the food (nutrients) go into lysosomes and they digest everything.	lysosome	Using an analogy, explain lysosome to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 stomach of a cooking
The lysosome is a little like the stomach in cooking. The stomach is where all the work of digestion takes place, breaking down food into small molecules that can be absorbed by the body. The lysosomes are similar, working to break down large molecules into smaller pieces that can be used by the cell.	lysosome	Using an analogy, explain lysosome to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 stomach in cooking

Mitochondria can be thought of as the "heart" or "engine" of a cell. They are responsible for producing energy in the form of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) for the cell to use. Without mitochondria, cells would not be able to function.	mitochondria	Using an analogy, explain mitochondria to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cellular kitchen
