Electric forces are like the forces that exist between magnets. Just as two magnets will attract or repel each other, electric charges will do the same. Like poles of magnets will repel and opposite poles will attract. This force can be harnessed to create electricity.	electric forces	Using an analogy, explain electric forces to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 magnets
Electric forces are like when you have two magnets and you put them together. The north pole of one magnet will be attracted to the south pole of the other magnet.	electric forces	Using an analogy, explain electric forces to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 magnets
Electric forces are like the force that holds two magnets together. Just as the magnets are drawn to each other, electric charges attract and repel one another. Like poles (positive and negative) of a magnet push each other away, while opposite poles (positive and negative) attract.	electric forces	Using an analogy, explain electric forces to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 magnets
Imagine you are cooking a meal and need to add an ingredient. You have three choices: salt, pepper, or oregano. If you choose salt, where do you put it? Right in the middle of the table. If you choose pepper, where do you put it? Near the edge of the table. And if you choose oregano, where do you put it? In between the salt and pepper.Electrons work in a similar way. Hydrogen has one electron. If that electron is placed near the nucleus (like salt), it is said to be in a "salt" orbital. If that electron is placed further away from the nucleus (like pepper), it is said to be in a "pepper" orbital. And if that electron is placed somewhere in between (like oregano), it is said to be in a "hybrid" orbital	hydrogen electron's orbital	Using an analogy, explain hydrogen electron's orbital to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 analogy to salt, pepper, and oregano on a table
The orbital of a hydrogen electron is like the oven in a kitchen. The electron orbits around the nucleus (like the stove) and can move up and down (like the oven).	hydrogen electron's orbital	Using an analogy, explain hydrogen electron's orbital to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 oven in a kitchen
Just as a cook needs to know where the stove's burner is in order to place the pot or pan on top, an electron needs to know where its nucleus is in order to orbit around it. The orbital of an electron describes the shape of the space around the nucleus that the electron occupies.	hydrogen electron's orbital	Using an analogy, explain hydrogen electron's orbital to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 the shape of the space around the nucleus that the electron occupies
The body's first line of defense is like the cook in a kitchen. The cook is always working to prepare food and keep the kitchen clean. In the same way, the body's first line of defense is always working to keep you healthy and fighting off infection.	first line of defense in the body	Using an analogy, explain first line of defense in the body to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cook in a kitchen
The body's first line of defense is like a kitchen chef. The chef is constantly cooking and preparing food, in case someone gets hungry. Action potential is like when you turn on the stove to cook. The heat from the stove gradually makes the pot warmer and warmer. Eventually, there's enough heat in the pot that it boils water. In a similar way, action potential is created when an electric current flows through a neuron. This electric current gradually makes the neuron more and more excitable until it reaches a threshold and triggers an action potential.	action potential	Using an analogy, explain action potential to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 turning on the stove to cook###| boiling water | heat from the stove gradually making the pot warmer
Action potential is like when you turn on a stove burner. The energy from the electricity flowing to the burner causes it to heat up and start cooking your food. The action potential in your brain works in a similar way. When an electrical signal reaches a certain point, it triggers the release of neurotransmitters that causes other cells to fire and create an action potential.	action potential	Using an analogy, explain action potential to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 turning on a stove burner
Action potential is like when you turn on the stove to cook something. The switch is turned on and energy flows through the wires until it reaches the stove. The same thing happens with action potential  a lot of energy (or voltage) flows through the neuron until it reaches the end, causing it to fire.	action potential	Using an analogy, explain action potential to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 turning on a stove
Cooking is a process that uses heat to change the chemical properties of food. In a similar way, chromatography is a process that uses heat (or another energy source) to change the chemical properties of substances. The different chemicals in a substance will move at different speeds through the chromatography column, just like the different spices in food move at different speeds when they are cooked.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Chromatography is like cooking in that it uses the separation of ingredients to create a final dish. In chromatography, different compounds are separated by their physical and chemical properties. This can be done by using different solvents or types of paper. Just like with cooking, the end result is a dish (or in this case, a spectrum) that is made up of different parts.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
One way to think about chromatography is as if you are cooking a dish with multiple ingredients. The different ingredients in the dishsuch as salt, pepper, and olive oilwould be represented by the different colors of ink on a sheet of paper. To figure out what spices are in your dish, you would hold the piece of paper up to the light and look at where each color overlaps. This would tell you which spices are in your dish and how much of each spice is present.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 looking at where colors overlap on a sheet of paper

If you think of capacitance as a container for storing electricity, then it is like a pot or pan used for cooking. The bigger the pot or pan, the more food you can cook at one time. In the same way, the greater the capacitance of a capacitor, the more electrical charge it can store.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a pot or pan used for cooking
Just as adding more ingredients to a pot of soup will make it thicker, capacitance is increased when an object is added to an electric field. This increases the resistance to the flow of electrons and results in a charge build-up on the surface of the object.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 adding an object to an electric field
A pot with a small amount of water on the stove will reach a boiling point faster than one with a large amount of water. This is because there is more heat energy available to the smaller pot, and it therefore reaches equilibrium (or boiling) sooner. The same principle applies to capacitors: A capacitor with a small capacitance has more energy available per unit volume than one with a large capacitance. As a result, it reaches equilibrium (or full charge) sooner.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a pots size
Electric current is like the flow of water in a hose. The more water that's flowing, the stronger the current will be.	electric current	Using an analogy, explain electric current to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 flow of water in a hose
Electric current is like a flow of water in a pipe. The more water that flows, the stronger the current will be. Just as with water, electricity can be used to do work, such as powering lights or appliances.	electric current	Using an analogy, explain electric current to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 flow of water in a pipe
Cooking is all about creating heat. In the same way, electric current is all about creating heat (or energy). When you plug a stove into an outlet, electricity flows through the wires in the stove and creates heat. This is what makes your food cook!	electric current	Using an analogy, explain electric current to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 creating heat (or energy)###| stove | plugged into an outlet
If voltage is like a pot of boiling water, then amperage would be the heat setting on the stove. The higher the heat setting, the more amps are flowing through the wires. Voltage is determined by how much potential energy is stored in the electrical circuit.	voltage	Using an analogy, explain voltage to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 potential energy in an electrical circuit###| amperage | heat setting on a stove
Cooking is all about bringing ingredients together to make a dish. Voltage is similar in that it brings electrons together to create an electric current. Just as various spices can add flavor to a dish, voltage can add power and flexibility to electricity.	voltage	Using an analogy, explain voltage to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 bringing electrons together to create an electric current
When you cook food, the stove provides a certain amount of heat. The more heat that is applied to the pan, the higher the cooking temperature will be. In a similar way, voltage is a measure of how much electrical energy is being used. The higher the voltage, the more electricity will be flowing through the circuit.	voltage	Using an analogy, explain voltage to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 the stove providing heat###| current | the flow of electricity
In cooking, if you want to make a dish that requires multiple steps and ingredients, it is much easier if each step is handled by a different person. That way, you don't have to worry about preparing the main course while also boiling water for the pasta. The same idea applies in cells. Specialization allows different parts of the cell to perform specific tasks, while communication allows them to share information and work together as a team. This division of labor makes cells more efficient and helps them carry out complex tasks.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using an analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 different people cooking a dish
Cooking is an example of specialization and communication in a cell. The cook, who is specialized in making food, communicates with the other parts of the kitchen to make a meal. The cook uses recipes as a form of communication to tell the other parts of the kitchen what to do.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using an analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
A cell is like a small kitchen. The cell has specialized areas that do different things, such as the stovetop, refrigerator, and cabinets. These areas communicate with each other to make sure the kitchen works smoothly. For example, if someone wants to cook dinner, they might need to use the stovetop and the refrigerator. The stovetop communicates with the refrigerator to make sure there is enough room in the fridge for all of the food that will be cooking on the stovetop.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using an analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 specialization and communication in a kitchen
Just as in cooking, when you have two or more pots on the stove with different temperatures of food simmering inside them, the combined temperature at the pot's surface will be somewhere in between the individual temperatures of each pot. In an electrical circuit, this same analogy can be used to explain Kirchhoff's Voltage Law. If you have a battery powering a lightbulb, and then add another battery in parallel (meaning they are both electrically connected), the voltage at the lightbulb will be somewhere in between the voltages of each battery.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 analogy of cooking on multiple pots
In cooking, you might use the law of conservation of energy to explain that heat is not created or destroyed in a process, it is merely transferred. In electrical circuits, kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of all voltages around a closed loop is zero. This means that the total amount of energy in a circuit remains constant - it is just being redistributed.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 law of conservation of energy
The voltage law is like following a recipe while cooking. You need to know the ingredients and how much of each to use, as well as the steps in between, in order to make a good dish. The same goes for electricity - you need to understand the different voltages and currents involved, as well as how they interact, in order to create a successful circuit.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 following a recipe while cooking
Density waves are like the waves that form when you drop a rock into a still pool of water. The wave starts at the point where the rock was dropped and travels outward until it dissipates. A density wave in space is similar  it starts at a certain point and spreads outwards until it dissipates.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 waves created by a rock dropped in a pool
A density wave is kind of like when you are cooking and you put a bunch of food in the pan at once and it all starts to cook together. The food in the middle gets cooked first and then it spreads outwards to the edge of the pan. A density wave is kinda like that, except it happens with stars or planets or anything else that is made up of atoms.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 analogy of cooking food
When you cook a pot of rice, the water boils and creates hot bubbles that rise to the surface. The boiling water causes the rice at the bottom of the pot to become dense, so it slowly rises up while the less-dense rice at the top floats away. This process creates a layer of cooked rice at the bottom of the pot and an airy layer of uncooked rice on top.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 boiling water in a pot of rice
Enzymes can be thought of as the cooks of the body. They are responsible for chemical reactions that occur in the body and help to break down food so that it can be used by the cells. Enzymes also play a role in repairing damage to cells and tissue.	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooks of the body
Cooking is all about chemistry. When you add an ingredient to a pot, it begins to react with the other ingredients in the pot. Some of these reactions create new molecules (like water), while others break apart old molecules (like sugar). Enzymes are like little chemical catalysts that help these reactions happen faster. Without enzymes, cooking would be a lot slower and messier!	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 little chemical catalysts
Human beings have an active memory system that is a little bit like a kitchen. In the kitchen, we have cabinets and drawers where we store our cooking supplies. We also have a stove where we cook our food. The same thing happens in our active memory system. We have different folders and areas where we store information. And, just like on the stove, we can cook information by using different methods (e.g., reheating it, boiling it).	human active memory system	Using an analogy, explain human active memory system to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen
Active memory is like a cookbook. It is a collection of recipes that we can use to make food. We can look up recipes in the cookbook, or we can create our own recipes by combining different recipes together. The cookbook contains all the information we need to make food, including the ingredients and the steps required to make each dish.	human active memory system	Using an analogy, explain human active memory system to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cookbook
The human active memory system could be thought of as a kitchen. The brain is the stove, and different parts of it are used to cook different types of food. Short-term memory is the oven, where things are cooked for a short time before they are either eaten or put away. Long-term memory is the cupboard, where all of the food that has been cooked in the past is stored.	human active memory system	Using an analogy, explain human active memory system to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in a reaction. This is like when you are cooking and the recipe says to cook something for two hours, but if you only have an hour, then you need to cook that part for an hour. The rest of the recipe can still be completed in the remaining time, it will just be done more quickly.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 when you are cooking
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. This is the step that determines how quickly the reaction will take place. In cooking, this would be like the step where you are adding ingredients to a pot and stirring them together. If this is the slowest step in the recipe, it will determine how long it takes to cook your food.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 adding ingredients to a pot and stirring them together
Column chromatography is like cooking a big pot of spaghetti. The noodles go in one end and the sauce goes in the other. By the time the noodles are done, they've absorbed all the delicious flavor from the sauce. Column chromatography works in a similar way. The sample compounds travel through a column filled with a special substance that absorbs them. As they move through, they take on some of the properties of that substance. At the end of the column, there's a detector that can tell you what compounds are in your sample.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking a big pot of spaghetti
Column chromatography can be thought of as a way to separate different ingredients in a dish. The ingredients are placed into a column, and then a liquid is passed through the column. This liquid will pull the different ingredients out of the column one by one, based on how well they mix with the liquid. The final product is a dish that contains all of the original ingredients, but they are now separated from each other.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 separating different ingredients in a dish
Column chromatography can be thought of as a very large, specialized kitchen strainer. In this analogy, the cooking ingredients (solutes) are like the water molecules, and the cooking vessel is like the column. The solutes are poured into the column and then allowed to flow through it under pressure. The smaller solutes pass through faster than the larger ones, just as smaller pieces of food will pass through a kitchen strainer more quickly than larger pieces. At the end of the column, there is a collecting container that catches all of the smaller particles while allowing most of the water to flow by.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen strainer
Dynamic chemical equilibrium can be thought of as the balance between two oppositely reacting chemicals in a system. In the same way that you need to add just the right amount of heat to a pan so that the food cooks evenly, you also need to add just the right amount of reactants to a chemical equation so that it reaches equilibrium. If there is too much or too little heat, or if there are too many or too few reactants, then the reaction will not reach equilibrium and will instead proceed in one direction until either all of the reactants are gone or all of the products have been formed.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 adding the right amount of reactants to a chemical equation######In both cases, there is a balance that needs to be achieved for the system to reach equilibrium.
Dynamic chemical equilibrium is kind of like a seesaw. On one side, you have the reactants (ingredients that start the reaction), and on the other side, you have the products (the things that are made during the reaction). As long as there's an equal balance between the two, nothing happens. But if you add more reactants or produts, then one side will start to go up while the other goes down until they reach equilibrium again.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a seesaw
Dynamic chemical equilibrium is a bit like the perfect stir-fry. If you keep stirring, the ingredients stay in constant motion and reach a state of equilibrium where everything is cooked evenly. But if you stop stirring, the ingredients will eventually settle into layers, with some parts being overcooked while others remain undercooked.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 perfect stir-fry
A vacuole is a lot like a kitchen sink. It's a place where water and other liquids can be stored, so they can be used when needed. The vacuole is also responsible for getting rid of waste products from the cell.	vacuole	Using an analogy, explain vacuole to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen sink
A vacuole is like a container in a kitchen. It can be used to store ingredients or utensils. In the same way, plant cells have vacuoles that store water, sugars, and other essential materials.	vacuole	Using an analogy, explain vacuole to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 container in a kitchen
The vacuole can be thought of as the stomach of the cell. Just like our stomachs digest food and extract nutrients, the vacuole digests molecules in the cytoplasm and extracts their useful components.	vacuole	Using an analogy, explain vacuole to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 stomach of the cell
Imagine that you are cooking a meal for your friends. You have all the ingredients ready, and you start cooking. The food is in the pan, and it's starting to cook. To make sure the food cooks evenly, you stir it around with a spoon. The stirring helps move the food around so that it cooks evenly. Now imagine that instead of a pan, you are using a pressure cooker. The food is still in there, but now it's under high pressure. In order to get the food to cook evenly, you need to use something else to help move it around - like steam! The steam will circulate through the pot and help cook the food evenly. In both cases (the pan or pressure cooker), moving the food around helps it cook more evenly. This is similar to what happens inside cells - different parts of the cell need nutrients and oxygen, and by transporting things around within cells we can make sure everything gets what it needs!	transport vesicles	Using an analogy, explain transport vesicles to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 stirring a pan or using steam in a pressure cooker
Cooking is all about getting the right ingredients in the right place at the right time. The same thing happens in your body when a protein molecule needs to be transported from one part of a cell to another. Tiny vesicles form around the protein and carry it to its new destination, where it can do its job.	transport vesicles	Using an analogy, explain transport vesicles to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Cooking is all about transporting ingredients from one place to another in the most efficient way possible. The same thing happens inside our cells, where small vesicles transport proteins and other molecules around. This process is essential for allowing different parts of the cell to communicate with each other.	transport vesicles	Using an analogy, explain transport vesicles to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 small cooking pots

The wave mechanical model is like a recipe for cooking. The ingredients (molecules) are mixed together in a bowl and then put in the oven to cook. As they cook, the molecules move around and create waves of heat that spread throughout the food. The waves cause the molecules on the outside of the food to cook faster than those on the inside, so the food cooks evenly.	wave mechanical model	Using an analogy, explain wave mechanical model to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 recipe for cooking
Cooking a meal is like making waves. The cook stirs the pot and creates small ripples that spread outwards. These ripples get bigger and stronger as they move away from the center of the pot. In the same way, when you shake or vibrate something, it creates tiny waves that travel through the object. As these waves get bigger, they cause the object to move and vibrate.	wave mechanical model	Using an analogy, explain wave mechanical model to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 Cooking a meal
Cooking can be thought of as a wave process. The heat from the stove (the energy source) travels through the food, causing it to vibrate and heat up. This creates waves of heat that spread out through the food. As these waves move, they cause more and more molecules in the food to start vibrating, until eventually all of the molecules are moving energetically and the food is hot.	wave mechanical model	Using an analogy, explain wave mechanical model to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking######In both cases, the goal is to cause all of the target molecules to vibrate. With cooking, this is done by applying heat to the food. With the wave mechanical model, it is done by applying a force to the target
An electroencephalogram (EEG) is similar to a cooking recipe. Just as a recipe provides instructions for making something delicious, an EEG records the electrical activity of the brain. This information can help doctors understand what is happening inside someones head and diagnose any potential problems.	electroencephalogram	Using an analogy, explain electroencephalogram to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a cooking recipe
An electroencephalogram (EEG) is a graphical representation of the electrical activity of the brain. This can be thought of as similar to how a cooking recipe lists ingredients and directions for making a dish. The EEG measures and records the voltage fluctuations resulting from ionic currents flowing through the neural tissue in your brain. Just like you would use different spices or techniques when cooking different recipes, each persons EEG pattern is unique.	electroencephalogram	Using an analogy, explain electroencephalogram to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a cooking recipe
Your recipe is like the dna sequence. The instructions in your recipe tell you what ingredients to use and how to put them together. When you follow the instructions, you create a dish that looks and tastes like the one in the recipe. In the same way, when enzymes act on dna strands, they copy the genetic information exactly. This process of copying DNA is called replication."	dna replication	Using an analogy, explain dna replication to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 following a recipe
DNA replication is a bit like cooking a meal. First, you need the ingredients - in this case, the DNA building blocks. You also need some tools, like an oven and pots and pans. Then you get to work! You might start by heating up the oven, then melting some butter in a pan. Next, you add some flour to make a roux. Once the roux is cooked through, you add your liquid ingredients - in this case, milk or water. Finally, you stir in the DNA building blocks and bake everything until it's cooked through. Voila! A delicious replica of your original dish.	dna replication	Using an analogy, explain dna replication to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking a meal
Cooking a meal is similar to replication of DNA. The cook reads a recipe, gathers the ingredients, and starts cooking. The cook follows the instructions in the recipe and cooks the food according to how it is supposed to be cooked. As the food cooks, it changes from its original form into something new - a plate of food that has been cooked. In the same way, as DNA replicates, it copies itself and creates two new strands of DNA. The original strand remains unchanged, while each of the new strands are slightly different from one another.	dna replication	Using an analogy, explain dna replication to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking a meal
The process of RNA transcription is a lot like cooking. Just as ingredients are combined in specific ways to create a finished dish, the sequence of nucleotides in DNA is read and transcribed into a complementary strand of RNA. The end result of this process is an RNA molecule that can be used by the cell to carry out its functions.	rna transcription	Using an analogy, explain rna transcription to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
RNA transcription is a bit like cooking. You start with some ingredients (the DNA), put them in a pot (the nucleus), and cook them until they are ready to eat (the RNA).	rna transcription	Using an analogy, explain rna transcription to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Cooking is a lot like transcription. Just as cooking involves taking ingredients and turning them into a final product, transcription takes DNA's genetic information and turns it into RNA. In both cases, there is some initial preparation (chopping vegetables/unzipping the double helix), followed by a series of steps that result in the finished product.	rna transcription	Using an analogy, explain rna transcription to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
In cooking, if you want to make a dish with chicken, you need to start by buying a whole chicken. The butcher will cut it into parts for you - the legs, the breasts, and so on. In the same way, when you want to make a protein, you need to start by reading the recipe for that protein. The recipe is written in what's called genetic code - a series of letters that represent different amino acids. To create the protein, your body needs to "read" this code and then use chemical processes to assemble all of the individual amino acids into one long chain.	protein translation	Using an analogy, explain protein translation to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 reading a recipe for a dish
Protein translation is like cooking a meal. The recipe (DNA) is the instructions for making the meal, and the ingredients (amino acids) are what you put into it. The kitchen (ribosomes) is where the cooking happens, and the stove (translation factors) provides the heat.	protein translation	Using an analogy, explain protein translation to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking a meal
When you cook a dish, the recipe calls for certain ingredients that are combined in a specific way to create a desired outcome. In a similar way, the genetic code stored within DNA is used as the blueprint for creating proteins. During protein translation, enzymes called ribosomes read the genetic code and use it to assemble amino acids into chains (protein). The finished product is then released from the ribosome and performs its designated function in the cell.	protein translation	Using an analogy, explain protein translation to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking a dish
Cooking is all about using the right ingredients in the right amounts to create a final product. A recipe is like an ecosystem, with each ingredient playing a role in the larger system. Just as too much of one ingredient can ruin a dish, too much or too little of any element in an ecosystem can upset its balance and cause problems.	ecosystem	Using an analogy, explain ecosystem to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 recipe
An ecosystem can be thought of as resembling a kitchen. The oven is the sun, providing warmth and heat. The stove is the earth, providing a place for things to grow. The refrigerator is the atmosphere, keeping things cool. The pots and pans are the water cycle and weather conditions. The ingredients are everything else in the environment: rocks, soil, plants, animals, etc.	ecosystem	Using an analogy, explain ecosystem to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen
The ecosystem of cooking is like a big buffet. There are all sorts of different foods to choose from, and you can put together your own meal however you want. There are vegetables, fruits, meat, grains, and more  each with their own unique flavors and textures. You can mix and match them any way you like, adding spices or sauces to make it just the way you like it.	ecosystem	Using an analogy, explain ecosystem to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 buffet
If you think of an action potential traveling down a neuron like an electric current traveling through a wire, it's easy to see how the wave of activation can spread. In much the same way that electricity travels quickly and smoothly through a metal wire, the action potential moves rapidly along the neuron membrane. This is thanks to special channels in the membrane that allow electrically charged particles (ions) to flow freely in one direction.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 electric current traveling through a wire
An action potential is a bit like an electric current that travels down a neuron. This current starts at the synapse, where the axon of one neuron meets the dendrite of another. When an electrical signal reaches this point, it causes tiny packets of neurotransmitters to be released into the synaptic cleft. These neurotransmitters cross over to the other side and bind to receptors on the dendrite of the receiving neuron. This triggers a new electrical signal that travels down the neuron until it reaches its end, where it again triggers more neurotransmitter release.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 propagation of an electric current down a wire
When you cook a meal, the food is placed in a pot on the stove. The stove heats up the food, and this makes it start to cook. The heat from the stove spreads out through the food, causing different parts of the food to start cooking at different rates. This happens because heat is a form of energy that travels through matter. It moves from areas where there is more energy (the stove) to areas where there is less energy (the food).This is similar to what happens when an action potential travels down a neuron. An action potential starts at one end of the neuron (just like when you turn on the stove), and it gradually spreads outwards until it reaches the other end. This happens because electrical energy travels through neurons just like heat does through food.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 propagation of heat through food
The frog's breathing mechanism is similar to that of a human. The frog inhales oxygen from the air and exhales carbon dioxide.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Using an analogy, explain breathing mechanism of frogs to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 breathing mechanism of humans
Breathing is like the process of cooking food. The frog's lungs (like the pot) contain air (like the food). When the frog inhales, its ribs (like the stirring spoon) move inward and down, causing a decrease in pressure in the lungs. This causes air to flow into the lungs from outside (the same way that boiling water flows into a pot when you open it). When the frog exhales, its ribs move upward and outward, which increases pressure in the lungs and forces air out.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Using an analogy, explain breathing mechanism of frogs to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking food
Cooking is like a frog breathing. When you cook something, you are using heat to change the state of the food. This is similar to how frogs breathe. Frogs use their skin to take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Using an analogy, explain breathing mechanism of frogs to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking food
Cooking a layered dish is like cooking a cake. You start with a layer of something at the bottom, then add another layer on top of that, and so on. The layers cook separately, but all come together in the end to form one delicious dish.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking a cake
Cooking is like assembling a layered cake. There are different ingredients, and each one is important for the end result. The bottom layer is the foundation, and it needs to be sturdy in order to support the weight of all the other layers. The next layer is the filling or frosting, which gives flavor and texture to the cake. The top layer is usually something sweet and delicious, like chocolate or whipped cream. If any of these layers are missing or done incorrectly, the cake wont be as good as it could have been.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 assembling a cake
Cooking can be thought of as a process that involves many layers. The first layer is selecting the ingredients. The second layer is preparing the ingredients. The third layer is cooking the ingredients. The fourth layer is serving the food.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
A limiting reactant is like a spice that you only have a little bit of, so you have to use it sparingly. An excess reactant is like a spice that you have plenty of, so you can add as much as you want.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 spice analogy
Just as in cooking, a limiting reactant is the ingredient that runs out first and controls how much product can be made. For example, if you are making cookies and only have one egg, once the egg is used up, no more cookies can be made. An excess reactant is an ingredient that is not needed to complete the reaction but is present in excess. In baking, this might be adding an extra egg or two to make sure enough eggs are available to create a good cookie dough.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 ingredients in cooking
A limiting reactant is similar to a spice in cooking. If too much of the spice is added, the flavor will be overwhelming. However, if not enough of the spice is added, the dish will be bland. In the same way, if there is too much or too little of a chemical reactant in a chemical reaction, then the reaction will not proceed as desired.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 spice in cooking
The eukaryotic cell can be thought of as a complex recipe, where each ingredient and step is important for the final product. The nucleus is like the cookbook, telling the rest of the cell what to do. The cytoplasm is like the kitchen, providing a workspace and all the necessary tools. And finally, the mitochondria are like the chefs, cooking up all of the delicious cellular components.	eukaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain eukaryotic cell to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a complex recipe###| nucleus | the cookbook###| cytoplasm | the kitchen###| mitochondria | the chefs
Eukaryotic cells are like the pots, pans and other appliances in a kitchen. They come in all different shapes and sizes, but each one has a specific job to do. The stovetop is where most of the cooking takes place, and it contains several burners that generate heat. The oven is also important for baking food, and it can reach much higher temperatures than the stovetop. There are also lots of smaller appliances in a kitchen, like blenders and mixers, that help make cooking easier. Similarly, eukaryotic cells contain organelles that carry out specific functions, like producing energy or building proteins.	eukaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain eukaryotic cell to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen appliance
A eukaryotic cell is like a big kitchen. It has all of the appliances you need to make food, such as a stove, refrigerator, and sink. It also has cabinets and drawers that hold utensils and ingredients. The walls of the kitchen are covered in tiles, just like the cell membrane is covered in proteins. And finally, just like a cook needs energy to prepare food, cells need energy to carry out their functions.	eukaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain eukaryotic cell to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a kitchen###| cell membrane | kitchen tiles
Like a kitchen, a prokaryotic cell has all the necessary tools to create something new. It has a stove for heating things up, pots and pans for mixing ingredients, and utensils for stirring and chopping. But instead of using these tools to cook food, the prokaryotic cell uses them to make proteins, DNA, and other molecules essential for life.	prokaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain prokaryotic cell to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen
A prokaryotic cell is like a kitchen. The cooking tools (enzymes) are kept in the refrigerator (cytoplasm), and the ingredients for making food (nucleic acids and proteins) are stored in cabinets or on shelves. When it is time to cook, the cook takes the ingredients from the cupboard and assembles them into a meal according to a recipe. In much the same way, enzymes within the prokaryotic cell take nucleic acids and proteins from storage areas within the cytoplasm and assemble them into new cells.	prokaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain prokaryotic cell to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen
A prokaryotic cell is like a small kitchen. It has all of the basic tools needed to do the job (like a stove, refrigerator, and sink), but it's limited in what it can do. In contrast, a eukaryotic cell is like a large kitchen with lots of extra tools and appliances (like ovens, mixers, and blenders). This gives it the ability to do more complex tasks.	prokaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain prokaryotic cell to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 small kitchen###| eukaryotic cell | large kitchen
The kernel in cooking is the most important part of the food. It is what makes everything else work. The same is true for an operating system. The kernel controls all the basic functions of the computer, like memory management and process scheduling.	operating systems kernel	Using an analogy, explain operating systems kernel to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking kernel
The kernel in an operating system is like the cook in a kitchen. It's responsible for doing all of the hard work, such as cooking the food, cleaning the kitchen, and preparing everything that's needed to create a meal. In the same way, the kernel in an operating system is responsible for handling all of the low-level tasks required to keep your computer running smoothly.	operating systems kernel	Using an analogy, explain operating systems kernel to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cook in a kitchen
An operating system kernel is like a chef in a kitchen. The chef oversees all the cooking in the kitchen and makes sure everything runs smoothly. Similarly, the kernel oversees all the operations of an operating system and makes sure everything runs smoothly.	operating systems kernel	Using an analogy, explain operating systems kernel to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 chef in a kitchen
If you are cooking a meal and run out of ingredients, the meal will not be complete. The same is true in a chemical reaction - if you run out of one of the reactants, the reaction will stop. This is because that particular reactant is no longer available to participate in the reaction.	limiting reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 running out of ingredients in a meal
A limiting reactant is the ingredient in a recipe that limits the amount of product that can be made. For example, if a recipe calls for 2 cups of flour and only 1 cup of sugar is available, then the recipe will only produce 1 cup of cookies because the flour is the limiting reactant.	limiting reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 ingredient in a recipe that limits the amount of product that can be made
A limiting reactant is the ingredient in a recipe that limits how much of the dish can be made. The same principle applies to chemical reactions. In a reaction, the amount of product that can be produced is limited by the amount of the limiting reactant.	limiting reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 ingredient in a recipe

For example, macaroni and cheese is a classic helper dish because the pasta and cheese compliment each other so well. helicase is kind of like a kitchen helper. Just as different ingredients can come together to make a delicious meal, helicase helps different parts of DNA come together to form chromosomes.	helicase	Using an analogy, explain helicase to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen helper
Cooking can be thought of as a process of breaking down large molecules into smaller ones. Imagine you are cooking a pie. The recipe calls for flour, butter, sugar, and eggs. To make the pie crust, you need to mix the dry ingredients together (flour and butter), then add wet ingredients (sugar and eggs). In order to get an accurate measurement of how old your pie is, you would have to calculate the age of each individual ingredient. The flour is older than the butter; the butter is older than the sugar; and the sugar is older than the eggs.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 measuring the age of each individual ingredient in a pie
One can think of a tree's age calculation as being similar to the way that one calculates the age of a cake. Just as with cakes, trees are generally given an estimated birthday (the day they were planted) and then their age is calculated based on how long it has been since that date. For example, if a tree was planted on January 1st and it is now February 1st, the tree would be about 1 month old.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 the way one calculates the age of a cake
As with many things, a tree's age can be determined by counting its rings. When a tree is young, it grows quickly and produces many new rings. As it gets older, the growth slows down and fewer new rings are formed. So by counting the number of rings in a cross-section of a tree trunk, you can estimate how old the tree is.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 counting tree rings
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down sugar (glucose) in the body to create energy. This process is a little like cooking, where you take a big piece of meat and break it down into smaller pieces that are easier to eat. The same thing happens with glucose in glycolysisit's broken down into smaller molecules that can be used for energy.	glycolysis	Using an analogy, explain glycolysis to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Glycolysis is like cooking a pizza. The first step is to preheat the oven to 400 degrees Fahrenheit. Then, you put the pizza in the oven and let it cook for 15 minutes. After 15 minutes have passed, you take the pizza out of the oven and let it cool for 5 minutes before eating it.	glycolysis	Using an analogy, explain glycolysis to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking a pizza
Glycolysis is essentially the cooking process for sugar. In glycolysis, enzymes break down glucose molecules into two smaller molecules called pyruvate. The process of glycolysis produces a small amount of energy that can be used by the cell to do its work.	glycolysis	Using an analogy, explain glycolysis to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking process for sugar###| pyruvate | smaller molecule
If you are cooking and put a spoon in the pot of stew, the heat from the stove will cause the spoon to become hot. If you then take the Spoon out of the pot and blow on it, the heat from your breath will cause the spoon to become colder. This is an example of anti-stokes scattering.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 blowing on a spoon
The anti-stokes scattering process is like the release of heat energy when a pot of water is boiling. The boiling process is initiated by the addition of heat to the pot, which in turn causes the water molecules to start moving faster and create bubbles. As these bubbles rise to the surface, they burst and release their heat energy into the surrounding air, causing it to warm up. This warming effect is known as thermal radiation, and it's responsible for making boiled water feel hot even after you've taken it off the stove.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 release of heat energy when a pot of water is boiling
This analogy is about cooking an egg. If you cook an egg on high heat, the egg white will be cooked very quickly and the yolk will be cooked slowly. However, if you cook the egg on low heat, both the white and yolk will be cooked evenly. This is because when heated on high, the energy from the heat source penetrates quickly into the center of the object (in this case,the egg), while on low heat, the energy from the heat source penetrates gradually over time. This analogy can be used to explain anti-stokes scattering: When light hits a particle with a lot of momentum (high heatsource), it is scattered quickly in all directions. When light hits a particle with less momentum(low heatsource), it is scattered more slowly in all directions	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking an egg on low heat
Cooking is all about making things taste good. When you're cooking, you're adding ingredients to a pot and stirring them around until they're all mixed together. The same thing happens when light hits something: the light scatters off of the object and Travels in every direction.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
If you are cooking and want to make scrambled eggs, you need some eggs and a pan. The heat from the pan will cause the eggs to cook. If you move the eggs around with a spoon, they will become scramble egg. This is because of stokes scattering. The heat from the pan causes molecules in the eggs to move faster. When these molecules hit other molecules, they bounce off in different directions. This causes the egg to change shape and become scramble egg.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking scrambled eggs
If you're cooking and want to make scrambled eggs, you need some eggs, a pan, butter or oil, and some salt. You might also want some other seasonings. To make the eggs, you break the eggs into the pan and then use a whisk (or fork) to scramble them. The whisking process causes small pieces of egg to be created and spread throughout the mixture. These pieces are what will eventually cook into your scrambled eggs.Stokes scattering is similar to scrambling eggs in that it creates small pieces of something that are spread out throughout another mixture. In this analogy, the original substance is like the eggs, while the scattered substance is like the whipped egg whites. Just as with scrambled eggs, these smaller pieces will eventually cook into something else entirely - in this case, light waves instead of food!	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 scrambling eggs
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that it takes to kill half of the people who consume it. In cooking, this would be the equivalent of making a sauce or dish with a potency that is too strong for most people, and therefore likely to make them sick or even kill them.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 making a sauce or dish with a potency that is too strong for most people
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance (in this case, a drug) that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. In cooking terms, think of it as the recipe for a dish that will make half of those who eat it sick and half will be just fine.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 recipe for a dish

Chemical equilibrium is like a recipe for a cake. The recipe has all of the instructions needed to make a perfect cake every time. If you follow the recipe exactly, you will get a perfect cake. However, if you change one of the ingredients or use too much/little of an ingredient, your cake may not turn out the way that you wanted it to. The same is true for chemical reactions - if you follow the exact steps and use the correct amounts of chemicals, you will get a reaction that reaches equilibrium. However, if you change one of the chemicals or don't use enough/too much of it, your reaction may not reach equilibrium and could result in an unsuccessful outcome.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 recipe for a cake
Chemical equilibrium is much like a recipe for a cake. In the beginning, you mix all of the ingredients together in one bowl and put it in the oven. As it cooks, the cake begins to rise and change form. Eventually, it reaches a point where all of the ingredients are evenly distributed and there is no more rising or changing. The cake has reached chemical equilibrium.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a recipe for a cake
A pot of soup on the stove is an analogy for a chemical system in equilibrium. The heat from the stove represents energy that is being put into the system. The soup molecules are constantly moving around and bumping into each other. Some of the collisions result in the molecules rearranging themselves, while others cause them to break apart (react). As long as there is energy input into the system, it will continue to move towards equilibrium, where there is no net change in concentration or temperature.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a pot of soup on the stove
Just-in-time (JIT) is a method of organizing production and delivery that aims to minimize inventory and avoid waste. In the kitchen, JIT would mean having just enough ingredients on hand to cook the meal you are planning, without any excess. This reduces spoilage and helps you stay efficient in your use of ingredients.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 in the kitchen
Just-in-time is a term used in business and manufacturing. It means having just the right amount of inventory on hand so that you don't have too much or too little. For example, if you're cooking dinner and you need chicken breasts, you wouldn't want to go to the store and buy a whole bunch of them because then you'd have to cook them all, and maybe not eat all of them. You'd want to go get some when you're already at the store buying other ingredients for your meal. That's just-in-time inventory management.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking dinner
In cooking, just-in-time would be like having all of the ingredients you need on hand to make a meal. You wouldn't have to go to the store to get more ingredients after you've started cooking.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 having all of the ingredients you need on hand to make a meal
Adaptive immunity can be thought of as a chef in a kitchen. The chef is constantly adapting to the needs of the kitchen by making changes to the recipes and cooking methods. In the same way, adaptive immunity adapts to new threats by creating new antibodies and cells that are specifically tailored to fight off those threats.	adaptive immunity	Using an analogy, explain adaptive immunity to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 chef in a kitchen
Adaptive immunity can be thought of as an immune system that is able to "adapt" and learn from previous exposures to pathogens. This allows the adaptive immune system to mount a more effective response the next time it encounters that pathogen. In contrast, innate immunity is a more generalized response that does not change based on prior exposure.	adaptive immunity	Using an analogy, explain adaptive immunity to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 an immune system that is able to "adapt" and learn from previous exposures to pathogens###| innate immunity | a more generalized response that does not change based on prior exposure
Adaptive immunity can be thought of as a type of immune response that is "adaptive" or able to change in order to best deal with an invader. It is much more sophisticated than the innate immune system, which is always present in our bodies and does not change. The adaptive immune system involves special cells called lymphocytes that travel throughout our bodies, looking for specific invaders that they have been trained to recognize. Once these lymphocytes find an invader, they bind to it and destroy it.	adaptive immunity	Using an analogy, explain adaptive immunity to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 the adaptive immune system###| innate immunity | the innate immune system
Ohm's law is a bit like when you are cooking and you have to follow a recipe. The recipe tells you how much of each ingredient to put in, and if you put in too much or too little of one ingredient, the end result will not be as good. With electricity, ohm's law tells us how much current (or flow of energy) will flow through a circuit based on the voltage and resistance. If we increase the voltage or decrease the resistance, then more current will flow through the circuit. And if we decrease the voltage or increase the resistance, then less current will flow through the circuit.	ohm's law	Using an analogy, explain ohm's law to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 following a recipe
Ohm's law can be thought of as the "recipe" for electricity. Just like a recipe tells you how much of each ingredient to use, ohm's law tells you how much voltage, current, and resistance are needed to create a particular electrical circuit.	ohm's law	Using an analogy, explain ohm's law to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 the recipe for electricity
The law states that the amount of current (in amps) flowing through a circuit is directly proportional to the voltage (in volts), and inversely proportional to the resistance (in ohms). In other words, if you increase the voltage or decrease the resistance, then more current will flow. Alternatively, if you decrease the voltage or increase the resistance, then less current will flow.	ohm's law	Using an analogy, explain ohm's law to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 the law of electric current
Transcription is similar to cooking a recipe. The recipe is the instructions for what needs to be done, and the cook follows the instructions to make the food. In transcription, the DNA sequence is like the recipe, and RNA polymerase is like the cook. The RNA polymerase reads through the DNA sequence, copying it one letter at a time into RNA.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking a recipe
When you are cooking, you follow a recipe to make sure the food turns out correctly. The recipe is like the instructions for making a gene work. The ingredients in the recipe (like sugar and flour) are like the DNA code for that gene. And when you cook the food, its like the gene is being turned on and made into a protein.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Transcription is like cooking. In both cases, you are taking something that is in one form and turning it into another form. With transcription, you are taking the genetic information from a gene and turning it into a protein. With cooking, you are taking food and turning it into something that your body can use to survive.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Just as different ingredients are needed to make a variety of dishes, rna polymerase uses different building blocks (rna nucleotides) to create strands of rna. These strands can then be used as recipes for making proteins.	rna polymerase	Using an analogy, explain rna polymerase to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 strands of rna###| rna nucleotides | recipes for making proteins
RNA polymerase is like a cook. It takes the ingredients (nucleotides) and cooks up a new strand of RNA.	rna polymerase	Using an analogy, explain rna polymerase to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 a cook
RNA polymerase is like a cook in the kitchen. The cook uses recipes to make food, and RNA polymerase uses genetic instructions (like recipes) to make new RNA molecules.	rna polymerase	Using an analogy, explain rna polymerase to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cook in the kitchen
One analogy for ribosomes to students who like cooking is that they are the "chefs" of the cell. Ribosomes create all of the proteins in a cell by reading instructions from messenger RNA molecules.	ribosome	Using an analogy, explain ribosome to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 student who likes cooking
In the kitchen, there are many different machines that help you cook. The stove is one of these machines. It uses heat to cook your food. Another machine in the kitchen is the refrigerator. It keeps your food cold so it doesn't spoil. These machines are all important in cooking, but they don't do anything on their own - they need someone to use them.The same is true for ribosomes inside our cells. They are very important in making new proteins, but they need something to tell them what to do. That "something" is called a gene.	ribosome	Using an analogy, explain ribosome to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 gene
Ribosomes are like the kitchen of a restaurant. They are responsible for creating all of the food that is served in the restaurant.	ribosome	Using an analogy, explain ribosome to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 kitchen of a restaurant
Activator protein is like an ingredient in a recipe. It helps to turn on the other genes that are needed for the recipe to work.	activator protein	Using an analogy, explain activator protein to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 an ingredient in a recipe
Electricity is like the heat from a stove. Just as you need to turn on the stove to get the heat going, you need to turn on the electricity in order for it to work in appliances and light bulbs. The stove has a knob that you use to control how much heat comes out of it - just like there is a knob on an electric range to control how much electricity goes into your oven or cooktop. There are also knobs on some ranges that let you choose between different kinds of heat (like gas or electric), just like there are switches on some lamps that let you choose between different levels of brightness.	electric circuit	Using an analogy, explain electric circuit to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 stove
Cooking is all about creating a circuit with heat. You need to have something to generate the heat (the stove), something to transfer the heat to (the pan), and something to hold the heat (the oven). If any of these pieces are missing, your circuit won't work and your food will be cold.	electric circuit	Using an analogy, explain electric circuit to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking######In both cases, you are trying to create a system that performs a desired task. With cooking, you are trying to create a system that heats your food. With machine learning, you are trying to create a system that predicts target values
When you are cooking, there are different things that need to happen in order for your food to be cooked. There is a heating element (like the stovetop) and then there are things like pots and pans that need to be placed on the element in order to cook. In the same way, an electric circuit has a power source (like the battery), an element (like the lightbulb), and something that needs to be powered (like the fan).	electric circuit	Using an analogy, explain electric circuit to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 an electric stove
If you think about it, when you cook something in a pan, the water will bead up on the top of the food. That is because water is hydrophilic (likes to be around other molecules) and oil is hydrophobic (doesn't like to be around other molecules). So when the two are mixed together, the water pushes away from the oil, creating those little beads.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 water beading up on food
Water molecules are attracted to each other and they like to stick together. This is why water forms droplets on a surface. The hydrophobic (water-fearing) molecule does not have this same attraction to water and it will try to get away from the water as much as possible. This causes them to bunch together, creating a hydrophobic effect.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 water molecules sticking together
Water is like a pot of boiling water on the stove. The molecules are moving around quickly and randomly. If you put a drop of oil in the pot, the oil will spread out because it is hydrophobic (fear of water). The water molecules push the oil away and keep it from mixing with the rest of the water.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 oil doesn't mix with water
Cooking is all about taking the raw ingredients and turning them into a delicious meal. The same goes for biological signal transduction - it's all about taking the raw information and turning it into something useful. In cooking, you use heat to change the structure of the food molecules, and in biology, enzymes do the same thing with proteins. Once they've been changed, they can carry out their functions in the body.	biological signal transduction	Using an analogy, explain biological signal transduction to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Cooking is all about understanding the chemical reactions that take place when you put different ingredients together. In a similar way, biological signal transduction is all about understanding the chemical reactions that take place when proteins and other molecules interact with one another. By learning about these reaction pathways, we can better understand how cells communicate and control their activities.	biological signal transduction	Using an analogy, explain biological signal transduction to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 cooking
Cooking can be thought of as a series of chemical reactions that occur in a pot or pan. The ingredients (chemicals) are mixed together and heated, causing the molecules to move around faster. This creates new molecules and structures, some of which are flavourful and desirable. Other molecules may be harmful or toxic if consumed in high quantities. In order for the body to extract energy from food, it must first break down these large molecules into smaller pieces. This process is called digestion and it occurs in the stomach and small intestine. Enzymes released by the pancreas help to digest carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids (fats). These enzymes work by breaking down larger molecules into smaller pieces that can then be absorbed through the intestinal wall into the bloodstream. From there, they are transported throughout the body where they provide energy or are used for building new tissues	biological signal transduction	Using an analogy, explain biological signal transduction to student who likes cooking.	ht	cooking	 digestion

A bacterial invasion is similar to an infestation of weeds in a garden. The weeds will compete with the plants for resources, such as water, sunlight, and nutrients. A gardener is watering her plants. She starts with the plants at the back of the garden and works her way to the front. She uses more and more water as she gets closer to the plants in the front. This is similar to an action potential. The water is like the voltage of the cell. The plants in the back are the most distant from the water, so they have the lowest voltage. The plants in the front are the closest to the water, so they have the highest voltage.	action potential	Explain action potential using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener watering her plants
A star's main-sequence lifetime is determined by how much fuel it has. The more fuel a star has, the longer it will stay on the main sequence. A star is like a plant. It needs water, sunlight, and nutrients to grow. The more water, sunlight, and nutrients it gets, the longer it will stay alive.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 growth of plants

The Golgi body is like a gardener. It takes the products of the cell's production (like flowers) and packages them up into nice little bundles (like bouquets). It then sends these bundles off to other parts of the cell (like the deliveryman).	golgi body	Explain golgi body using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener
A capacitor is like a container of water. If you have a hose with a lot of water pressure, it is easy to squirt water out of the hose. But if you have a container with a small hole in the bottom, it is hard to get water out of the container. The water pressure is like the voltage of the capacitor. The size of the hole is like the capacitance.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 size of the hole in the bottom of a container
Electric current is like water flowing through a hose. Just as the water pressure can be increased by increasing the water flow, the electric current can be increased by increasing the number of electrons flowing through the wire.	electric current	Explain electric current using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 water flowing through a hose
Water pressure is like voltage. Just as garden hoses can have different water pressures, electrical circuits can have different voltages. The higher the water pressure, the more powerful the stream of water. The higher the voltage, the more powerful the electrical current.	voltage	Explain voltage using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 water pressure
In gardening, plants that are close together can share water and nutrients through their roots. Plants that are far apart cannot do this as easily. Cells are similar - cells that are close together can share water and nutrients through their cell membranes. Cells that are far apart cannot do this as easily.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardening
Kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero. This law can be explained using a gardening analogy. Imagine that you are a gardener and you have a hose with a nozzle on it. If you turn the nozzle on, water will flow out of the hose and into the garden. If you close the nozzle, the water will stop flowing. The water in the hose is like voltage and the water in the garden is like current. The voltage is the potential difference between the two points and the current is the amount of water that flows between the two points. The sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero because the water in the hose is trying to flow in two directions at once and the water in the garden is trying to flow in one direction.	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener with a hose
A density wave is like a wave of people that moves through a crowd. The people at the front of the wave are packed together, while the people at the back are spread out.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 people in a crowd
Enzymes are like gardeners. They help things grow and they make sure everything is working properly.	enzymes	Explain enzymes using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardeners
The human active memory system can be likened to a gardener who plants seeds, waters them, and then watches them grow. The gardener stores the seeds in a container, and then retrieves them when it is time to plant them. The gardener also monitors the progress of the plants, and intervenes when necessary.	human active memory system	Explain human active memory system using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who plants seeds, waters them, and then watches them grow
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. In a gardening analogy, the rate-determining step would be the step in which the plants are growing the slowest.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Explain rate-determining step of a reaction using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 step in which the plants are growing the slowest
A gardener is tending to her plants. She waters them and then waits for them to grow. She then waters them again. The water is the reactant and the plant is the product. The gardener is constantly adding water and the plant is constantly using water. The water is in dynamic equilibrium with the plant.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Explain dynamic chemical equilibrium using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener watering plants
A vacuole is like a garden shed. It is a small, enclosed space used for storage. In the garden, a shed can be used to store tools, gardening supplies, or lawn equipment. Proto-oncogenes are like the seeds of a flower. They are the genes that control how a cell grows and divides. When these genes are working normally, they help the cell grow and divide in a controlled way. But when these genes are mutated, they can cause the cell to grow and divide out of control, leading to cancer.	proto-oncogenes	Explain proto-oncogenes using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 seeds of a flower###| cancer | out of control growth

A resonance hybrid is like a hybrid plant that is a cross between two different plants. The resonance hybrid has the best features of both plants. For example, a tomato plant and a pepper plant might cross to create a new plant that has the best features of both plants - like a big tomato that is also spicy.	resonance hybrid	Explain resonance hybrid using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 hybrid plant
A wave mechanical model can be thought of as a garden hose. When you turn on the water, the hose starts to vibrate and create waves. These waves travel down the hose and eventually reach the end. The waves then reflect back up the hose and create new waves. This process continues until the water is turned off.	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 garden hose

Protein translation is like gardening. The mRNA is like a seed, the ribosomes are like the soil, and the tRNA are like the fertilizer. A garden is an ecosystem. The plants in the garden are the producers. The animals that eat the plants are the consumers. The animals that eat the animals are the predators. The propagation of an action potential down a neuron can be thought of as the spreading of a wave of water down a garden hose. The frog's breathing mechanism can be likened to a gardener using a garden hose. The gardener uses the hose to suck water from a bucket and then squirts the water out the end of the hose. The frog's mouth acts as the bucket and the lungs act as the hose. The frog sucks air from the lungs and the air is then squirted out the mouth and into the lungs of the frog sitting on the bank.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Explain breathing mechanism of frogs using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener using a garden hose
A layered architecture is like a garden. The foundation is the soil, the plants are the application, and the mulch is the security.
