A limiting reactant is a reactant that is used up first in a chemical reaction. An excess reactant is a reactant that is not used up in a chemical reaction. In gardening, a limiting reactant would be the amount of soil that is available to plants. An excess reactant would be the amount of water that is available to plants.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardening
A eukaryotic cell is like a garden. The nucleus is the gardener, who oversees everything that goes on in the garden and makes sure that everything is healthy. The mitochondria are the plants in the garden, and they produce the energy that the cell needs to function. The cytoplasm is the soil, and the cell membrane is the fence that keeps everything in the garden.	eukaryotic cell	Explain eukaryotic cell using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 garden###| nucleus | gardener###| mitochondria | plants###| cytoplasm | soil###| cell membrane | fence
A prokaryotic cell is like a small garden plot. It has a limited amount of space in which to grow, and it must make the most of the resources it has. The plants in a prokaryotic cell are arranged in a dense, crowded environment, and they must compete for food and space.	prokaryotic cell	Explain prokaryotic cell using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 small garden plot###| plants in a prokaryotic cell | compete for food and space

They also help to keep the DNA organized and stable.	dna replication binding proteins	Explain dna replication binding proteins using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardeners

A motherboard can be thought of as the garden plot in which a gardener plants seeds, and the gardener's job is to water and care for the plants as they grow. The motherboard is the foundation of the computer and provides the electrical and logical connections for all of the other computer components.	motherboard	Explain motherboard using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 garden plot###| watering and caring for plants | watering and caring for computer components

A keyboard is like a garden. The keys are like the plants, and the fingers are like the gardener.	keyboard	Explain keyboard using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 garden

A video card is like a garden hose. It is used to direct water to where it is needed. In the same way, a video card directs the flow of data to the monitor.	video card	Explain video card using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 garden hose
A tree's age calculation is similar to counting the number of rings in a tree trunk. Just as a tree trunk grows wider each year, a tree's age is measured by the number of rings that have formed in its trunk.	tree's age calculation	Explain tree's age calculation using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 counting the number of rings in a tree trunk
Glycolysis is the process of breaking down glucose (sugar) to release energy. This can be thought of as analogous to a gardener breaking down a piece of wood into smaller pieces to use as firewood. The glucose is like the piece of wood, and the energy released is like the heat and light from the fire.	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 breaking down a piece of wood
Stokes scattering is the scattering of light by small particles in a suspension. It is similar to the scattering of light by raindrops in a rainstorm. In both cases, the light is scattered by the small particles in the suspension.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 scattering of light by raindrops
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that is lethal to 50% of the population. In gardening, it would be the amount of herbicide that is lethal to 50% of the plants.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 amount of herbicide that is lethal to 50% of the plants
The universe is like a garden. It has been carefully tended and cultivated for billions of years. The universe is constantly growing and evolving, just like a garden.	universe	Explain universe using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 garden
Enzymes are like gardeners. They help things grow by providing the right environment. In the garden, the gardener provides water, sunlight, and fertilizer. Enzymes provide the same things for the cells in our bodies. They provide water, sunlight, and energy.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener providing water, sunlight, and fertilizer
If you have a garden and you want to know how much fertilizer to use, you could do an experiment where you apply different amounts of fertilizer to different parts of the garden and then measure how well each part grows. This would be a controlled experiment, and you would use an analysis of variance (anova) to see if there was a difference in the growth of the different parts of the garden.	anova	Explain anova using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 measuring the growth of different parts of a garden
A thermostat is like a gardener who waters the plants at a certain time each day and adjusts the watering depending on the weather. The thermostat turns on the heat or air conditioning at a certain time each day and adjusts the temperature depending on the weather.	thermostat	Explain thermostat using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who waters plants
Chemical equilibrium is like a garden where the plants are in balance. The plants get the right amount of water, light, and nutrients to grow. If one plant gets too much water, for example, the other plants will get less. The same is true for chemical equilibrium. If one chemical gets too much of a reactant, the other chemicals will get less.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 a garden
A gardener who plants seeds in the spring will not have vegetables to harvest until the fall. A gardener who plants seeds in the fall will not have vegetables to harvest until the spring. A gardener who plants seeds in the summer will have vegetables to harvest in the fall.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardening
Adaptive immunity can be thought of as a gardener who plants a variety of different flowers in her garden. The gardener knows that some of the flowers will be more resistant to pests and diseases than others. So, when pests or diseases attack the garden, the gardener will be more likely to have a flower that is resistant to that particular pest or disease.In the same way, the body's adaptive immune system contains different cells that are specifically designed to fight off different pests and diseases. When a foreign invader (such as a virus or bacteria) enters the body, the adaptive immune system will mobilize its troops to attack and destroy the invader.	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who plants a variety of different flowers###| pests and diseases | different flowers
If you have a hose with a certain amount of water pressure, and you want to increase the water pressure at the end of the hose, you can do so by increasing the water pressure at the faucet. The amount of water that comes out of the hose at the end is determined by the water pressure at the faucet and the resistance of the hose. In the same way, if you have a circuit with a certain amount of voltage and you want to increase the voltage at the end of the circuit, you can do so by increasing the voltage at the beginning of the circuit. The amount of current that flows through the circuit is determined by the voltage and the resistance of the circuit.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 water pressure at the faucet
Transcription is the process of copying a gene's DNA sequence into a new molecule of messenger RNA (mRNA). This process is similar to a gardener copying a plant's genetic information into a new seed. The mRNA can then leave the cell nucleus and travel to the cell's protein-making factories, called ribosomes, where it is used to create proteins.	transcription	Explain transcription using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 copying a gene's DNA sequence into a new molecule of messenger RNA (mRNA)
RNA polymerase is like a gardener who plants seeds in the ground. The gardener waters the seeds and then waits for them to grow into plants. The plants then produce flowers and fruit. RNA polymerase does the same thing with DNA. It plants the DNA seeds in the ground, waters them, and then waits for them to grow into RNA. The RNA then produces proteins.	rna polymerase	Explain rna polymerase using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who plants seeds in the ground
Ribosomes are like the gardeners who plant the seeds and water the plants. The plants are the proteins that are made by the ribosomes, and the seeds are the RNA that the ribosomes use to make the proteins.	ribosome	Explain ribosome using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who plants the seeds and waters the plants###| protein | plant
The activator protein is like a gardener who waters the plants and helps them grow. The activator protein helps the transcription factor bind to the DNA and start the transcription process.	activator protein	Explain activator protein using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener who waters the plants
Electricity is like water in a garden hose. The water pressure in the hose is like the voltage in an electric circuit. The amount of water flowing through the hose is like the current in an electric circuit. The water in the hose is like the electrons in an electric circuit.	electric circuit	Explain electric circuit using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 garden hose
Water molecules are attracted to each other and are also attracted to the surface of the soil. This attraction creates a force that pushes the water molecules down into the soil. The water molecules are also attracted to the surface of the plants, but the attraction is weaker than the attraction to the soil. This force creates a force that pulls the water molecules up into the plants. The water molecules that are attracted to the surface of the plants are called the water surface tension.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 water surface tension
A gardener watering her plants is an analogy for a cell receiving a signal from its environment. The water is the signal and the plants are the cells. The gardener is the receptor and the water is the ligand. The gardener's muscles are the effector.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using a gardening analogy.	lt	gardening	 gardener watering her plants

In the body, nadh is responsible for turning food into energy.	nadh	Explain nadh using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 the nutrient that helps plants turn sunlight into sugar###| body | food into energy

Proteins are like the plants in a garden. They are the structures that make up the body, and they grow and change as the body grows and changes.	proteins	Explain proteins using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 plants in a garden
A protein is like a plant in your garden. It starts out as a small seed and, with the right conditions (food, water, sunlight), it will grow into a large plant. The same is true for proteins - they start out as tiny molecules called amino acids and, with the right conditions (nutrients from food), they will grow into larger proteins.	proteins	Explain proteins using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 plants in your garden

Protein is made up of smaller molecules called amino acids, which are the "building blocks" of protein. We get most of the amino acids we need from food, but there are a few that our bodies can make on their own.	proteins	Explain proteins using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 amino acids

The Golgi Apparatus can be thought of as the gardeners of the cell. The Golgi apparatus is like the gardener who plants the seeds, waters them, and then harvests the vegetables. The plant's cells produce the proteins that are needed for growth. These proteins are shipped to the Golgi apparatus inside small sacs called vesicles. The golgi separates and modifies these proteins before shipping them off to their final destination in the cell.	golgi	Explain golgi using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardener who plants the seeds, waters them, and then harvests the vegetables

The membrane controls what enters and leaves the cell, much like how a fence controls what enters and leaves a garden.	plasma membrane	Explain plasma membrane using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garden fence

The membrane controls what goes in and out of the cell, like water and nutrients.	plasma membrane	Explain plasma membrane using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garden fence###| controls what goes in and out of the cell | water and nutrients

ATP is the energy currency of life. Just as a gardener needs to have a good supply of energy (in the form of food) in order to do work (digging, planting, weeding), cells need a good supply of ATP in order to do work (such as contracting muscles, pumping blood, synthesizing proteins).	atp	Explain atp using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardener needing food to do work###| cells | needing atp to do work
The energy that plants use to make food is similar to the ATP energy used by your muscles. Just as you need gas for your lawnmower, plants need sunlight and water to create glucose from carbon dioxide and hydrogen atoms in the air. This process is called photosynthesis, and it's what makes our planet hospitable for life.	atp	Explain atp using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 energy used by your muscles

Plants use sunlight to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose (a type of sugar) and oxygen. The energy stored in glucose molecules is later used to produce ATP.	atp	Explain atp using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 money in a bank account###| sunlight | converting carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen###| glucose | type of sugar###| oxygen | produced when glucose is converted

The peroxysome is where all of the cellular debris (dead cells, organelles, etc.) goes to be decomposed and released into the cytoplasm.	peroxysome	Explain peroxysome using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 compost heap

When you are gardening, you use a hoe to move the dirt around. The hoe has a metal blade that is attracted to the dirt. This is because the atoms in the metal are attracted to the atoms in the dirt. The electric force between two objects is like this attraction between atoms.	electric forces	Explain electric forces using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 attraction between atoms

A hydrogen electron's orbital can be thought of as a flowerpot. The "orbital" is the pot, and the "electron" is the plant. This barrier is made up of skin, hair, and sweat glands that work together to keep out bacteria and other invaders.	first line of defense in the body	Explain first line of defense in the body using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 a fence around a garden
One's first line of defense against invaders in the body might be thought of as analogous to a gardener's fence. The fence is intended to keep unwanted things out, and it does this by being strong and tall. Similarly, the cells that make up our skin are meant to keep bacteria and other potentially harmful substances from entering our bodies. Our skin is also tough, so it can resist damage from these outside entities.	first line of defense in the body	Explain first line of defense in the body using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardener's fence
A macrophage is a large white blood cell that absorbs and digests bacteria, dead cells, and other debris. Macrophages are like the gardeners of your body - they keep things clean and free from infection.	macrophages	Explain macrophages using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardeners
A macrophage can be thought of as a "garbage truck" for the body. It engulfs and digests cellular debris, bacteria, and other foreign matter.	macrophages	Explain macrophages using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garbage trucks
Macrophages are the gardeners of your immune system. They survey your body for any signs of infection or disease, and then work to clear away any harmful cells or substances. Like a good gardener, they also help to nurture healthy cells and tissue growth.	macrophages	Explain macrophages using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardeners###| immune system | garden
In gardening, there are different types of plants that need different types of care. For example, a rose bush needs water and sunlight while a cactus does not. In the same way, t-helper cells are responsible for identifying different antigens and providing the necessary signals for an immune response.	t-helper cells	Explain t-helper cells using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 identifying different antigens###| immune response | providing the necessary signals
The analogy of gardening is helpful in understanding how t-helper cells work. In gardening, there are different types of soilclay, loam and sand. The type of soil that a gardener uses will depend on the plants they are growing. For example, if they want to grow tomatoes, they would use loam because it is good for holding moisture and nutrients. If they wanted to grow carrots, they would use sandy soil because it has good drainage. T-helper cells are like the type of soil; each one works best with certain antigens (like plants). There are different types of t-helper cells that work with different antigens; just as there are different types of soils that work best with certain plants.	t-helper cells	Explain t-helper cells using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardening
A t-helper cell is like a gardener. It helps to direct and guide other cells in the body to do their jobs effectively.	t-helper cells	Explain t-helper cells using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardeners
B-lymphocytes are like the plants in a garden. They grow and multiply, then produce antibodies that help protect the body from infection.	b-lymphocytes	Explain b-lymphocytes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 plants in a garden###| antibodies | help protect the body from infection
B-lymphocytes are like the weeds in your garden. They grow quickly and can take over if not controlled. However, they also play an important role in the garden by helping to fight off pests and diseases.	b-lymphocytes	Explain b-lymphocytes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 weeds in your garden###| fighting off pests and diseases | helping to
B-lymphocytes are like the plants in your garden. They are responsible for taking in nutrients from the soil and turning them into things that the rest of the plant can use to grow. B-lymphocytes also produce antibodies, which help protect the plant from pests and diseases.	b-lymphocytes	Explain b-lymphocytes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 plants in your garden###| antibodies | pests and diseases
Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes can be thought of as the gardeners of the immune system. They are responsible for seeking out and destroying cancer cells and other harmful invaders in the body. Like gardeners, they use their knowledge of plants (the anatomy and physiology of cancer cells) to identify and destroy these unwanted organisms.	cytotoxic t-lymphocytes	Explain cytotoxic t-lymphocytes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardeners of the immune system
A cytotoxic t-lymphocyte is a type of white blood cell that helps the body fight infection. In a gardening analogy, they can be thought of as the gardener's helper. They work to destroy any cells that are infected or damaged, including cancer cells.	cytotoxic t-lymphocytes	Explain cytotoxic t-lymphocytes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardener's helper
A cytotoxic t-lymphocyte is like a weed killer. It seeks out and destroys cells that are not supposed to be in the body, such as cancer cells.	cytotoxic t-lymphocytes	Explain cytotoxic t-lymphocytes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 weed killer
Bacteria can be seen as garden pests that invade and destroy plants. Just as a gardener might use pesticides to get rid of these pests, antibiotics are used to kill bacteria.	invasion of bacterias	Explain invasion of bacterias using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 pests in a garden###| use of antibiotics | use of pesticides
A gardener may use compost to improve the soil in her garden. The compost contains bacteria, which will invade the healthy soil and help it to decompose. In a similar way, invading bacteria can help break down organic matter and improve the environment for other organisms.	invasion of bacterias	Explain invasion of bacterias using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 compost
The analogy of bacteria invading a garden is much like an infestation of ants. The ants are constantly looking for new food sources and they will invade a garden in order to get to the plants or fruits that they are looking for. The bacteria work in a very similar way. They are always looking for new ways to infect people and once they find a way in, they can quickly spread throughout the body.	invasion of bacterias	Explain invasion of bacterias using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 infestation of ants
Imagine you are a gardener. You have just planted some flowers and now you need to water them. To do this, you take a hose and put it in the ground near the plants. When you turn on the water, the pressure of the water against the ground forces liquid up through the hose and into the flower pots.Now imagine that each flower pot has a small hole in it so that liquid can escape from it (but not enter). If you turn on the water slowly, only a little bit of liquid will flow out of each pot. But if you turn on the water with more force, more liquid will flow out of each pot.This is similar to what happens when there is an action potential in a neuron. The voltage difference between inside and outside of a neuron causes sodium ions to rush into the neuron, like water rushing through holes in flower pots. This influx of sodium ions creates an electrical current that travels down the length of the neuron until it reaches its end point (the synapse). There, neurotransmitters are released which cross over to receptors on neighboring neurons where they generate another action potential	action potential	Explain action potential using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water rushing through holes in flower pots###| synapse | end point of a hose
The gardener analogy for the action potential is that of a hose. When the water is turned on at full force, it gushes out of the hose. This is analogous to when the neuron fires and sends an action potential down its axon. If you turn the water on slowly, you get a dribble; this is analogous to a graded potential.	action potential	Explain action potential using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 the water gushing out of the hose###| graded potential | the water dribbling out of the hose
When a gardener wants to water their plants, they go over to the hose and turn it on. This allows water to flow from the faucet into the hose, and eventually out of the spout and onto the plants. The gardener can control how much water is flowing by turning the faucet on and off.In a similar way, when a neuron is stimulated, an action potential occurs. This means that voltage-gated Na+ channels open up, allowing Na+ ions to flow into the neuron. This influx of Na+ ions causes the neuron to become more positive inside (depolarization), which in turn opens up even more voltage-gated Na+ channels. As more and moreNa+ ions flow in, the membrane potential continues to increase until it reaches its peak value (+40 mV). At this point, all of the voltage-gated Na+ channels close and K+ ion channels open up, allowing K+ ions to leavethe neuron (repolarization). Once repolarized, the neuron is ready for another action potential	action potential	Explain action potential using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 flowing water
Chromatography is the process of separating a mixture into its individual components. This can be done using either a physical or chemical separation technique. In gardening, chromatography can be used to separate different colors of soil. The different colors are each placed in their own container and then water is slowly added until the soils are all mixed together. Once the soils are mixed, a small amount of this mixture is placed on a filter paper and allowed to dry. Once the sample has dried, it will be ready for analysis. To perform the analysis, we will need some food coloring dye and alcohol. We will also need a ruler or other measuring device with millimeter markings. First, we will use the food coloring dye to color one end of the filter paper strip red. Next, we will add alcohol to another end of the strip until it is wet but not soaking wet (this should take about 10 drops). Now we're ready to start testing our soil samples! We'll place each soil sample at one end of our strip and wait for them to travel down the strip by capillary action (the same way that water travels up through plants). The further down the strip that a particular soil sample travels, the more saturated that particular soil was with water when it was mixed with our original batch. We can use this information to create a "soil moisture" map of our garden!	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardening
If you want to separate the colors in a bouquet of flowers, you can use chromatography. The process works something like this: You put a few drops of water on each flower, then place them on a piece of paper. Next, you fold the paper in half and rub it together. This will cause the water to spread out and wet the entire surface of the paper. Finally, you wait for the water to dry. As it dries, it will pull the different colors in each flower apart. The result will be a colorful rainbow on the paper (see image).	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 separating colors in a bouquet of flowers
Chromatography is used to separate the different chemicals in a mixture. A gardening analogy would be to think of each chemical as a different type of soil (clay, sand, silt). The mixture is poured into a jar and then water is added. The water will wash over the soil, carrying away some of the chemicals with it. As the water washes over the soil, it separates the chemicals based on their size and weight. The heavier soils (clay, sand) will stay at the bottom of the jar while the lighter soils (silt) will be carried away by the water.	experiment of chromatography	Explain experiment of chromatography using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 analogy of gardening
The lifetime of a star is determined by how much fuel it has. A star like the sun will burn for about 10 billion years, while a red dwarf might last for trillions of years. This is kind of like comparing the lifespan of a cactus to an oak tree. The cactus has less fuel and will die sooner, while the oak has more fuel and will live longer.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 lifespan of a cactus vs an oak tree
The main sequence lifetime of a star is the amount of time it spends burning hydrogen in its core. This can be thought of as the length of time a gardener spends weeding their garden. Weeds will continue to grow as long as they have sunlight and water, just like a star will continue to burn hydrogen in its core as long as it has fuel.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 the length of time a gardener spends weeding their garden
A star's main-sequence lifetime is determined by how much nuclear fuel it has. More massive stars use up their fuel more quickly and therefore have shorter main-sequence lifetimes than less massive stars. You can think of a star's life as being like the life of a plant. The longer the plant lives, the more growth it experiences. A small, young plant will live for only a year or two, while a large, old tree may live for hundreds of years. In the same way, a small, young star will have a short main-sequence lifetime while a large, old star will have a long main-sequence lifetime.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 life of a plant

The lysosomes take the waste from the plant - leaves that have fallen off, old flowers or fruit - and break them down into their component parts so that they can be used again by the plant to create more food.	lysosomes	Explain lysosomes using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 compost heap in the garden

A nuclear envelope is like a fence around the nucleus of a cell. It helps to keep the DNA inside and protect it from damage.	nuclear envelope	Explain nuclear envelope using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 fence around the nucleus of a cell
A nuclear envelope is a membrane that surrounds the nucleus of a cell. It functions as a barrier between the nucleus and the cytoplasm. One way to think about vacuoles is to imagine them as holding bags of water in a plant's cells. Just as gardeners use watering cans to give their plants a drink, the vacuoles suck up water from the cell cytoplasm and store it in their bag-like membranes. This gives the plant tissue a turgid or swollen appearance, similar to how inflated balloons look different from deflated ones. The pressure of all that extra water inside the cell helps keep it rigid so it can stand up straight against gravity.	vacuoles	Explain vacuoles using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 holding bags of water in a plant's cells
A vacuole is a bit like a garden shed. It's a small, enclosed space where you can store things. In the plant world, vacuoles are used to store water, nutrients and other important chemicals.	vacuoles	Explain vacuoles using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 garden sheds
A vacuole is like a big bag of water that helps plants stay firm and upright. It's kind of like the water in your garden hose. When you turn on the hose, the pressure from the water coming out pushes against the sides of the hose, which in turn makes it hard for the hose to move around. The same thing happens with a plant stem - when there's more pressure inside the stem from all of that extra water in the vacuole, it becomes harder for the stem to bend or move.	vacuoles	Explain vacuoles using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water in garden hose

Chromosomes are like the seeds in a packet of vegetable seeds. The packet may have 20 or more different types of seeds, but each seed is still just a small part of the whole. A capacitor is like a container of water. If you have two containers, one with more water and one with less, the one with more water will be harder to push down. This is because it has more capacitance. Just like in a garden, the plants that have more water (capacitance) in their soil are harder to move than the plants that have less water.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water in a container
Capacitance is the ability of a material to store an electric charge. It is measured in farads and can be increased by adding more plates to the capacitor or by using a material with a high dielectric constant. A gardening analogy would be to think of capacitance as being similar to water storage in a rain barrel. The more water that is stored, the more capacitance there is.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water storage in a rain barrel

Electric current is like the flow of water in a garden hose. Electric current is like water flowing through a hose. Just as the water pressure in the hose depends on how much water is coming out of the faucet, the electrical voltage in a wire depends on how much electric charge is moving through it. The more water that's flowing, the higher the pressure (voltage). And just as you can stop the flow of water by closing off the valve, you can stop or slow down electric current by adding a resistor.	electric current	Explain electric current using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 water flowing through a hose###| voltage | water pressure in a hose###| resistor | valve

Water pressure is like voltage. Just as garden hoses can have different water pressures, electrical circuits have different voltages. The higher the water pressure in a hose, the more force the water will have when it comes out of the hose. One way to think of the specialization and communication within a cell is to use the analogy of gardening. In gardening, there are many different types of plants that need to be planted in order to create a successful garden. The same is true for cells  they contain many different specialized parts that work together to create a functioning whole.In addition, just as in gardening, it is important for the different plants (or cells) to communicate with one another in order to coordinate their activities. For example, if one part of the garden is trying to bloom but another part is trying to grow new leaves, there will be conflict and the plant will not thrive. Similarly, if one part of a cell is trying to produce energy while another part is trying to store information, there will be conflict and the cell will not function properly.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardening
In a cell, specialization is like having different parts of the garden perform different tasks. The roots take in water and nutrients from the soil, the stem transports these substances up to the leaves, and the leaves use sunlight to produce food for the plant. Communication between these parts is necessary for the plant to grow and thrive. For example, if the roots don't get enough water, they will send a signal to the stem telling it to bring more water up from the ground.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 different parts of a garden performing different tasks, communication between parts necessary for plant to grow
In gardening, plants need specific nutrients to grow and thrive. Nitrogen is one of these essential nutrients; without it, plants will not be able to produce the chlorophyll necessary for photosynthesis. A gardener can provide nitrogen to a plant in two ways: by adding a nitrogen-rich fertilizer to the soil, or by planting a legume nearby that will "fix" atmospheric nitrogen into a form the plant can use.Similarly, cells need specific nutrients (such as oxygen and glucose) to function properly. The cell membrane allows certain molecules (including nutrients) inside while keeping others out. Once inside, the molecule passes through specializations called organelles, which perform different tasks such as producing energy or building proteins. Finally, the protein exits the cell and performs its assigned task.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardener providing nitrogen to a plant######In business, it is important to have a good understanding of your target market. This means knowing who your customers are, what they want, and how to reach them. It also means understanding the competition and
The voltage law is like a gardener who waters her plants. The voltage law states that the total voltage around a loop is zero. This means that the amount of water going into a plant (the voltage) must be equal to the amount of water coming out of the plant (the current).	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 a gardener who waters her plants
Imagine you are a gardener trying to water your plants. You have a hose with two nozzles, one at the top and one at the bottom of the garden. If you turn on both nozzles, water will flow out of the top nozzle and fill up the garden until it reaches the level of the bottom nozzle. The same thing happens with electricity: if you have two voltage sources (like two batteries), current will flow from the higher voltage source to the lower voltage source until they reach equilibrium.	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 two batteries######In both cases, the goal is to find a balance or equilibrium between the two sources. With the garden, you want to find the nozzle configuration that results in the lowest possible water level. With the batteries, you want to find
A gardener is tending her garden. She notices that the plants in one part of the garden are wilting, while the plants in another part of the garden are thriving. The gardener concludes that there must be something wrong with the water supply in the wilting section of the garden. This is analogous to Kirchoff's Voltage Law, which states that "The sum of all voltages around a closed loop is zero." In other words, if you add up all of the voltages in a circuit, they should sum to zero.	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 gardener tending her garden
Density waves are like a ripple in a garden pond. Just as the ripples move across the surface of the water, density waves move throughmatter. The wave is created when something disturbs the equilibrium state of matter. For example, when you drop a rock into a pond, it creates a ripple that moves outward from the point of impact.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 ripple in a garden pond
A density wave is often described as a ripple of energy that travels through a medium. This analogy can be helpful in understanding what a density wave is and how it behaves. Imagine you are standing in your garden and you toss a stone into the middle of the pond. The stone creates a ripple that quickly spreads out across the surface of the water. A density wave works in much the same way; it is created by some type of disturbance and then quickly spreads out through the material it is travelling through.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 ripple created by a stone tossed in a pond
A density wave can be thought of as a wave of gardeners arriving at a new section of the garden. The first gardener to arrive starts digging a hole and planting seeds. Once the hole is dug, the second gardener arrives and plants his or her seeds next to the first, then digs another hole. This process continues until all the available space has been filled.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a gardening analogy.	ht	gardening	 analogy of gardeners
