The voltage is like the water pressure in a garden hose. It is what makes the water come out of the hose and into your garden.	voltage	Explain voltage using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 water pressure in a garden hose
One analogy for voltage would be to think of it as water pressure. Just as the higher the water pressure is, the further the water will flow (assuming a constant pipe size), so too does voltage determine how much electrical current will flow through a circuit.	voltage	Explain voltage using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 water pressure
A cell is like a garden. The plant in the garden (the cell) needs water, sunlight, and soil to grow. The roots of the plant (the cells that anchor the plant in the soil) need to be able to absorb water and nutrients from the soil. The stem of the plant (the part of the plant that grows upward) needs to be able to transport water and nutrients from the roots to the leaves. The leaves of the plant need sunlight to produce food for the plant.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 the roots of a plant needing to absorb water and nutrients from the soil, the stem of a plant needing to transport water and nutrients from the roots to the leaves, and the leaves of a plant needing sunlight to produce food for the plant
A cell is like a small garden. The plants in the garden need to be specialised so that they can all work together to make the garden look nice. The plants also need to communicate with each other so that they know what needs to be done.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 plants in a garden
The cells in our body are like the plants in a garden. Specialization is when different parts of the plant (e.g., leaves, flowers) do different things to help the plant survive and grow. Communication happens when the gardener (our brain) sends messages to the plants telling them what to do (e.g., water, fertilize, prune).	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 specialization and communication in a garden
If you have a garden with several trees in it, and you want to water all the plants equally, you can't just go to one tree and start watering. You have to move around the whole garden, going to each tree and giving it a little bit of water. It's the same with electricity: if you have two batteries (or two sections of wire with voltage across them), and you want to make sure that they both have the same voltage, you can't just measure the voltage at one point. You need to measure it at lots of different points, and then add up all the voltages measured. That's what Kirchoff's Voltage Law is doing when it says that the sum of all voltages in a circuit is zero.	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 adding up all the voltages in a circuit
Kirchoff's Voltage law is similar to the rule of thumb that states, "Water seeks its own level." In other words, if you have two areas of water (one higher than the other), the water will flow from the higher area to the lower until both areas are at the same level. This is also what happens with electricity. If you have two areas of voltage (one higher than the other), electrons will flow from the higher voltage to the lower until both areas are at the same voltage.	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 rule of thumb
Kirchoff's voltage law is similar to a gardener weeding her garden. She begins by removing the large weeds that are easy to see. Once those are gone, she goes back through and removes the smaller weeds. The process is repeated until all of the weeds are gone. Analogously, Kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of the voltages around a closed loop must be zero. This means that any positive or negative voltages in the system will cancel each other out.	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardener weeding her garden
A density wave is like a crowd of people walking through a park. The people are all close together at the beginning of the wave, but they gradually spread out as they walk.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 people walking through a park
Density waves are like the ripples that form in a pond after you toss a stone into the water. Just as the ripples spread out from where the stone hit the water, density waves ripple through a gas or liquid, starting at a particular point and moving outward.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 ripples from a stone in water
A density wave is like a ripple in a garden pond. When you throw a rock into the water, it creates a ripple that spreads out from the point of impact. The ripple gets smaller and weaker as it travels away from the center. A density wave works in much the same way. It starts off as an impulse (like the rock) and spreads out through the material (the water). The wave gets weaker and narrower as it moves away from the point of origin.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 ripple in a garden pond

Your brain can be thought of as a garden. The plants in the garden are like the things you remember, and the soil is like your active memory. The watering hose is like your working memory. It takes a while for water to soak into the soil, just like it takes a while for new information to be stored in your active memory. Rate-determining step of a reaction is similar to the process of planting a garden. The first step (planting the garden) is slow, but once it's established, the plants grow quickly. The same is true for reactions; the rate-determining step is often slow, but once it gets going, the reaction proceeds rapidly.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Explain rate-determining step of a reaction using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 planting a garden
The rate-determining step of a reaction is like the process of planting a garden. The first step (planting the seeds) is slow, but once the plants are established, they grow quickly.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Explain rate-determining step of a reaction using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 planting a garden
The rate-determining step of a reaction is the step that takes the longest. In gardening, this would be like planting a seed and waiting for it to grow. The other steps in the reaction can happen pretty quickly, but you have to wait for the plant to grow before you can harvest it.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Explain rate-determining step of a reaction using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 planting a seed and waiting for it to grow
Column chromatography is a bit like weeding your garden. You start with a big container of water (the mobile phase) and add some fertilizer to it (the stationary phase). You then take a hose (the sample) and spray the water onto the weeds (the compound you want to separate). The weeds will be pulled up by the water and carried away in the stream. As they travel, they will gradually lose their fertilizer (which is sticking to them). The slower the weeds move, the more time they have to lose their fertilizer. Eventually, they will reach the end of the hose and fall into a bucket (the collection tube), where you can measure how much fertilizer each weed has lost.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 weeding your garden
Column chromatography is like weeding a garden. The goal is to remove the unwanted plants (or compounds) from the soil so that the desired plants can grow and thrive. In column chromatography, the "soil" is the column of packing material, and the "plants" are the various compounds that need to be separated. The unwanted compounds are removed by washing with a solvent (or solvents), while the desired compound(s) stay in place because they are attracted to or dissolved in the solvent(s).	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 weeding a garden
Column chromatography is like using a colander to rinse fruits and vegetables. The plant material is placed in the colander and water is run over it, removing the dirt and other unwanted materials. In column chromatography, the plant material (the solute) is placed in a column, and a solvent is passed over it, separating out the different compounds in the solute.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 using a colander to rinse fruits and vegetables
A dynamic chemical equilibrium can be thought of as a garden with a hosepipe running through it. The water coming out of the hose is analogous to the reactants in a chemical reaction, while the water that has soaked into the ground is analogous to the products of the reaction. If you turn off the hose, eventually all of the water will soak into the ground and there will be no more water coming out of the hose. In a similar way, if you stop supplying energy (the turning on of the hose), then eventually all of the reactants will have reacted and there will be no more reactants left.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Explain dynamic chemical equilibrium using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden with a hosepipe
Dynamic chemical equilibrium is like a garden hose. When you turn on the water, the hose quickly fills with water. As more water flows out of the hose, it becomes less full. But if you keep turning on the faucet, eventually the flow of new water will equalize with the flow of water leaving the hose - and at that point, dynamic equilibrium will be reached.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Explain dynamic chemical equilibrium using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 a garden hose
Dynamic chemical equilibrium is like a garden that has been well-maintained. The plants in the garden are evenly spaced, and there is a healthy balance of nutrients in the soil. If one plant begins to grow taller than the others, its roots will reach down into the soil to find more nutrients. At the same time, other plants will start to grow shorter so they don't block out sunlight from reaching their neighbours. This process continues until all of the plants have reached an equilibrium where each one is growing at a different rate, depending on how much light and nutrients it can access.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Explain dynamic chemical equilibrium using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 a garden that has been well-maintained

By packing all the liquid and other material inside, the cell can free up more room on its surface to do other things.	vacuole	Explain vacuole using an analogy. One way to think about resonance is to imagine it as a type of garden fence. If you have a single piece of fencing, with one post in the ground and one wire running between the posts, an intruder can easily hop over the fence. But if you add another post (representing a resonating electron), and run a wire between the two posts, now it's much harder for someone to jump over the fence - they would have to jump from post to post. In other words, by adding another resonating electron we've increased the strength of the fence (resonance).	resonance hybrid	Explain resonance hybrid using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden fence
Resonance hybrid is like a gardener who has many different types of plants in her garden. Each type of plant represents a different electron configuration for the atom. The gardener can choose which plant to water and fertilize depending on what she wants to grow in her garden. In the same way, the resonance hybrid chooses which electron configurations it will use to represent the atom based on how stable they are.	resonance hybrid	Explain resonance hybrid using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardener with many different types of plants
Resonance hybrid can be thought of as a garden with several types of flowers. The first type of flower is the ordinary (non-resonance) hydrogen atom. It has one electron in its outermost shell. The second type of flower is the helium atom. It has two electrons in its outermost shell. The third type of flower is the lithium atom. It has three electrons in its outermost shell, and so on for all other elements up to uranium (92 protons). When you look at this garden, you will see that some flowers are very similar (hydrogen and helium), while others are quite different (lithium and uranium). However, if you really look closely at each individual flower, you will see that they all have slightly different colors and shapes. This is because they contain a different number of electrons in their outer shells.	resonance hybrid	Explain resonance hybrid using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden with several types of flowers
A wave mechanical model can be thought of as a garden hose. When you turn on the water, it flows out of the hose in one smooth stream. If you pinch the hose shut at any point, the water will start to back up until it builds up enough pressure to burst through the closure. In much the same way, waves travel down a metal rod (or guitar string) when plucked or struck. The energy travels along the length of the string until it reaches a point where there's not enough tension left to keep it going and it snaps back into its original position.	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden hose###| plucking a guitar string | striking a metal rod
The wave-mechanical model of the atom can be thought of as a garden. In this analogy, the nucleus is the shed in the back corner of the garden and the electrons are like butterflies flitting around in the flowers and plants. Just as waves travel through water, they also travel through our metaphorical garden. The amplitude (height) of a wave corresponds to how vigorously the butterfly is moving, while its wavelength corresponds to how far it has traveled from one side of the flower to another. The frequency (number of waves that pass by per second) is determined by how fast the butterflies are flying.	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden
Imagine you are a gardener. You have just planted some flowers in your garden, and now it is time to water them. To water your flowers, you take a hose and aim the stream of water at the ground next to the plants. As the water hits the ground, it creates ripples that spread out from where the water hit. The farther away from the original impact point, the smaller the ripples become.This analogy can be used to explain wave mechanical models. The waves created by an object traveling through a medium (like water) can be thought of as ripples spreading out from where the object hit. The size of these waves depends on how far away they are from their source (just like how big or small a ripple becomes depending on how far away it is from where it started).	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 ripples spreading out from where the water hit
The brain is like a garden. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 a rain gauge
An analogy for the electroencephalogram could be a garden hose. When there is water running through the hose, it is easy to see the pressure and movement of the water. However, when the water is turned off, it is difficult to see anything inside of the hose. In a similar way, an EEG shows electrical activity in the brain when someone is awake and thinking. When someone falls asleep or becomes unconscious, there is much less electrical activity in the brain and this can be seen on an EEG	electroencephalogram	Explain electroencephalogram using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden hose
An electroencephalogram is a bit like taking the pulse of a garden. Just as you would check to see if a plant looks healthy by feeling its leaves, you can also get an idea of how well a garden is doing by checking the activity level of its plants (i.e., its trees and flowers). In the same way, an EEG measures the amount of electrical activity in your brain by recording changes in voltage caused by the firing of neurons.	electroencephalogram	Explain electroencephalogram using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 taking the pulse of a garden###| brain activity | plant activity

RNA transcription is a bit like planting seeds in your garden. The seeds need water and sunlight to grow, and the RNA transcript needs molecules called enzymes and ribosomes to read it and create a protein.	rna transcription	Explain rna transcription using an analogy. An analogy for RNA transcription would be a gardener planting seeds in the ground. The gardener puts the seeds into the ground and covers them with soil. Then, water is poured on top of the soil to help the seeds grow. In a similar way, RNA transcription occurs when DNA is "planted" in a cell's nucleus. The DNA is covered with proteins called histones, and then enzymes called transcription factors help to "water" the DNA so that it can be converted into RNA.	rna transcription	Explain rna transcription using an analogy. In the same way, ribosomes provide the necessary nutrients for proteins to grow as they are being translated from mRNA.	protein translation	Explain protein translation using an analogy. Protein translation is a bit like gardening. The instructions for making a particular kind of plant are written in the seed's DNA, and just as you need to follow specific instructions to make sure your garden grows correctly, cells need to 'read' the DNA sequence of a gene in order to produce a protein molecule. RNA is involved in this process too - it acts as something of an interpreter, carrying the genetic instructions from the DNA strand to the ribosomes, where proteins are actually made.	protein translation	Explain protein translation using an analogy. A neuron is like a garden hose. When you turn on the water at the faucet, it flows through the hose until it gets to the end. The same thing happens with an action potential. It starts at the cell body and travels down the axon until it reaches the end.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron using an analogy. When you turn on a faucet, the water starts flowing instantly. However, it takes time for the water to travel all the way from the faucet to the sink. The same is true for an action potential traveling down a neuron. It travels quickly at first, but slows down as it gets further away from the source.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron using an analogy. The frog's breathing mechanism can be likened to that of a garden hose. When the water is turned on, it flows through the hose and out the nozzle. In a similar way, when the frog inhales, oxygen enters its body through its nose and mouth. The oxygen then travels down into its lungs where it is exchanged for carbon dioxide. When the frog exhales, carbon dioxide leaves its body through its nose and mouth.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Explain breathing mechanism of frogs using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 Garden hose
The frog's breathing mechanism can be compared to that of a garden hose. When the water is turned off at the faucet, the hose will contract and pull in on itself. This is similar to how the frog's lungs work; when there is no air present, they will collapse and take up less space. When the water is turned back on, the hose expands and pushes out water. This is similar to how the frog's lungs fill with air when it breathes in.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Explain breathing mechanism of frogs using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 breathing mechanism of garden hose

Layered architecture is like a garden. The soil at the bottom is the foundation, and it supports everything else in the garden. The plants in the garden are arranged in layers, with taller plants on top and shorter plants on the bottom. Just as each layer of plants needs sunlight to grow, each layer of an application needs access to data and functionality from lower levels.	layered architecture	Explain layered architecture using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 a garden
A layered architecture for a garden is like planting flowers in different layers. The tallest flowers are planted in the back, and the shorter ones are planted in the front. This way, when you look at the garden from a distance, it looks like one cohesive design.	layered architecture	Explain layered architecture using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 planting flowers in different layers
The analogy of layered architecture is like a garden. The ground layer is the foundation and it holds up the other layers. The second layer are the plants that grow in the soil. They get their nutrients from the soil. The third layer are the plants that grow on top of the plants in the soil. They get their sunlight from above and their nutrients from below.	layered architecture	Explain layered architecture using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 a garden
If you have a garden and want to grow tomatoes, you need to plant the tomato seeds in soil and water them. The number of tomatoes you can get from your garden depends on how many seeds you plant and how much water and sunlight they receive. If you only plant a few seeds, then you will only get a few tomatoes. If you plant too many seeds, then the plants will compete for resources (water, sunlight) and not all of them will survive. In this analogy, the tomato seeds are like the reactants and the soil is like the limiting reactant. The water and sunlight are like the excess reactants.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 soil and water
The limiting reactant is like the last plant in a garden. It's the one that runs out of water or food and can't keep growing. The excess reactant is like all the extra plants in a garden. They're not needed to complete the reaction, but they're there just in case.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 last plant in a garden and all the extra plants in a garden
If you have a small pot of flowers and want to plant more, you need to remove some of the soil before planting new flowers. The existing plants are the limiting reactant because they take up all of the space in the pot and there is not enough room for any new plants. The new plants are the excess reactant because there is plenty of space for them in the pot.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 small pot of flowers and adding more plants

The cytoplasm is like the soil, where all the plants (organelles) grow. The organelles are like different kinds of plants, each with its own job to do in order to keep the cell healthy.	eukaryotic cell	Explain eukaryotic cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden###| nucleus | gardener###| cytoplasm | soil###| organelles | plants

The cytoplasm is the soil, where the plants (organelles) grow. The water and nutrients in the cytoplasm are like the fertilizer and rainwater that help the plants grow big and strong.	eukaryotic cell	Explain eukaryotic cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden###| nucleus | gardener###| cytoplasm | soil###| organelles | plants
A eukaryotic cell is like a garden. The nucleus is the gardener who oversees everything that goes on in the cell and makes sure it all runs smoothly. The cytoplasm is like the soil, and the organelles are like the plants and flowers growing in the garden.	eukaryotic cell	Explain eukaryotic cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden###| nucleus | gardener###| cytoplasm | soil###| organelles | plants and flowers
A prokaryotic cell is like a small garden plot. It has all of the essentials it needs to grow- water, soil, and air. But it doesn't have a lot of extra space or features.	prokaryotic cell	Explain prokaryotic cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 small garden plot
A prokaryotic cell is like a small garden plot. It has soil, plants, and water, but it doesn't have a fence or anything to keep the plants in place.	prokaryotic cell	Explain prokaryotic cell using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 small garden plot
A prokaryotic cell can be thought of as a small garden plot. The cells are enclosed by a fence (cell wall) and the interior is filled with soil (cytoplasm) in which the plant's roots (mitochondria) grow. Nutrients and water enter the cell through the soil, and waste products exit through the fence.	prokaryotic cell	Explain prokaryotic cell using an analogy. The kernel of an operating system is like the root of a plant. It provides basic functionality for everything else in the system. Just as plants need roots to get water and nutrients, operating systems need kernels to manage resources and run applications.	operating systems kernel	Explain operating systems kernel using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 plant root
The analogy for the OS kernel would be like the root of a plant. The root is responsible for getting water and nutrients to the rest of the plant, and it also anchors the plant in the ground. In much the same way, the kernel provides services and support to all other parts of the operating system, and it also manages system resources.	operating systems kernel	Explain operating systems kernel using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 root of a plant
The kernel of a plant is the part that is responsible for its growth and survival. It regulates all of the essential functions of the plant, such as taking in nutrients from the soil, converting sunlight into energy, and distributing resources throughout the plant. The kernel is also responsible for defending the plant against pests and diseases. In much the same way, an operating system's kernel manages all of the essential functions of a computer, including managing files and folders, processing commands, and controlling hardware devices. It also oversees security features to protect your computer from unauthorized access or damage.	operating systems kernel	Explain operating systems kernel using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 kernel of a plant
When you are gardening, you may have a problem with pests. To get rid of the pests, you might use a pesticide. The pesticide is like the limiting reactant in a chemical reaction. It is used up first and limits the amount of product that can be made.	limiting reactant	Explain limiting reactant using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 pesticide
If you have a pot with limited space, and you want to plant two flowers in it, one big flower and one small flower, the big flower will be the limiting reactant. The small flower can only grow as big as the pot allows it to.	limiting reactant	Explain limiting reactant using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 pot with limited space
A limiting reactant is like a garden hose with a kink in it. The water can flow through the hose, but only at a certain rate. If you try to use more water than the hose can handle, the water will back up and not get to where you want it to go.	limiting reactant	Explain limiting reactant using an analogy. Helicase is like a gardener who helps plants grow by winding their stems around his or her fingers. The helicase enzyme unwinds the DNA molecule, just as the gardener winds the stem around his or her fingers. This process allows the DNA to be copied and repaired.	helicase	Explain helicase using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardener who helps plants grow

The helicase enzyme hoe-s around the DNA molecule, creating openings that allow other proteins access to the DNA.	helicase	Explain helicase using an analogy. Replication binding proteins can be thought of as garden stakes. These are the pieces of metal or wood that are hammered into the ground around a plants stem to help hold it in place and keep it from being blown over by the wind. In much the same way, replication binding proteins help to stabilize the DNA molecule during replication, preventing it from being pulled apart by the forces of nature.	dna replication binding proteins	Explain dna replication binding proteins using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden stakes
DNA replication binding proteins can be thought of as the gardener's gloves. These proteins help to protect the DNA from being damaged, and they also help to keep everything in order during replication. Without these gloves, the DNA would be susceptible to damage and it would be difficult to replicate properly.	dna replication binding proteins	Explain dna replication binding proteins using an analogy. If you think of drugs as seeds, and receptor sites as holes in a garden bed, then the interaction between drugs and receptor sites is pretty straightforward. The drug seed will fall into the hole (and may or may not germinate), and the plant that grows from that seed will take root in the soil around the hole. If there are other plants nearby, they may compete with the new plant for water, sunlight, and nutrients; but ultimately, it's up to the new plant to thrive or die based on its own characteristics.	interaction between drugs and receptor sites	Explain interaction between drugs and receptor sites using an analogy. A video card can be analogized to a garden hose. The hose has a certain amount of water pressure that comes out the end. This is analogous to the video card's clock rate, which is how many times per second it can send data to the monitor. The width of the hose (in inches) is analogous to the number of bits per pixel that the video card can send. Finally, just as you can turn on and off faucets in your house, you can control how much information gets sent to the monitor by using different graphics settings in your game or application.	video card	Explain video card using an analogy. Glycolysis is like a plant growing in the soil. The plant takes in water and food from the soil and uses it to grow. In glycolysis, glucose (the food) is taken in by the cell and used to create energy.	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 plant growing in the soil
Glycolysis is the process that breaks down glucose (sugar) to release energy. This can be thought of as similar to a gardener who cuts the lawn with a mower. The grass is like the glucose, and the cutter of the lawn (mower) is like the glycolytic enzyme.	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardener who cuts the lawn with a mower
Glycolysis is a process that takes place in the cells of plants. Just as you need water and sunlight to help your garden grow, plants need glucose (a type of sugar) and oxygen to help their glycolysis process happen. The plant's leaves take in the sunlight, which helps break down the glucose into a form that the plant can use. The plant then uses its roots to take in the oxygen, which helps finish breaking down the glucose.	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardening
One way to think of anti-Stokes scattering is as the process of a falling leaf being scattered by the wind in such a way that it gains energy and rises back up into the air. The leaf is acted on by two forces: gravity, which pulls it down, and the wind, which pushes it up. In anti-Stokes scattering, a particle is acted on by two forces: the force that wants to pull it down (gravity) and the force that wants to push it up (the light). Just as in the case of the leaf, anti-Stokes scattering can result in an increase in energy for the particle and cause it to rise out of its original state.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 the process of a falling leaf being scattered by the wind
The scattering of light by a particle can be thought of as the scattering of water droplets by rain. Just as the raindrops scatter light in all directions, so too do particles scatter light in all directions. This is known as anti-stokes scattering.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 scattering of water droplets by rain
When light shines on a garden, the plants absorb some of the light and then scatter it in all directions. Some of the scattered light goes back in the direction from which it came (termed forward scattering), while other bits of scattered light go off in random directions (termed backward scattering). Anti-Stokes scattering is basically just backwards scattering, where the photons are sent away from the object rather than towards it.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 backwards scattering
When light shines on a garden, the plants absorb some of the light and reflect the rest. The reflected light is scattered in many directions. This is similar to what happens when white light shines on a particle. Some of the light is absorbed by the particle and the rest is scattered in many directions.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 scattering of light in many directions
The scattering of light by a small particle is similar to the scattering of water droplets by the wind. Just as the wind causes water droplets to scatter in all directions, so too does the presence of light cause scattered photons to fly off in all directions.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 scattering of water droplets by the wind
Stokes scattering is like a rock being thrown into a pond. The rock creates waves that spread out and ripple across the surface of the water. Stokes scattering works in a similar way. It causes light to scatter in all directions, creating waves of light that spread out from the original source.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 a rock being thrown into a pond

The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 using the least amount of weed killer
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that kills 50% of the animals exposed to it. This can be thought of as the equivalent of planting a certain type of flower in your garden and having half of them die.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 planting a certain type of flower

Enzyme mechanism is similar to the process of gardening. In order for a garden to grow, it needs both water and sunlight. The sun provides energy for the plants to grow, while the water helps the plants absorb nutrients from the soil. Enzymes are like tiny gardeners that help chemical reactions happen in our bodies. They need energy (from food) to do their job, and they use water to help them dissolve chemicals so that reactions can take place.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardening
Enzyme mechanisms are similar to gardening. In both activities, you use a tool (or enzyme) to help you do the work. With gardening, you might use a shovel to dig a hole in the ground. With enzymes, you might use an enzyme called amylase to break down starch into glucose molecules. Just as the shovel makes it easier for you to dig in the ground, amylase makes it easier for your body to digest starch.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardening
Enzyme mechanisms can be likened to the actions of gardeners weeding their gardens. Weeds are removed by pulling them out of the ground by their roots. In a similar way, enzymes remove unwanted substances from cells by binding to them and breaking them down into smaller molecules that can be eliminated from the cell.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardeners weeding their gardens
Imagine you have a garden with two types of plants - flowers and vegetables. You want to know if the type of plant (flower or vegetable) makes a difference in how tall the plants grow. To find out, you dig two holes in your garden and plant one flower and one vegetable in each hole. You then water and care for both plants the same way. After a few weeks, you measure the height of both plants to see if there is a difference.In this analogy, the flower is like an independent variable (the thing that changes) and the height of the plant is like the dependent variable (the thing that we measure). The type of plant (flower or vegetable) is like a fixed factor (the thing that doesn't change). We use an analysis of variance (anova) to see if there is a difference in how tall the plants grew, depending on whether they were flowers or vegetables.	anova	Explain anova using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden with two types of plants
One way to think about the results of an ANOVA is to imagine you are a gardener. The purpose of your garden is to grow vegetables, and you have three different types of soil in which to do so. In order to compare the effects of the different soils on vegetable growth, you plant six identical rows of each type of soil and measure how tall the plants growing in each row become. The ANOVA procedure would allow you to determine whether there is any difference in vegetable height among the rows grown in the different soils.	anova	Explain anova using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardening
The analogy is between the results of an anova and a plant's growth. The anova tells us how much each factor (treatment) contributed to the overall variation in the data. Just as we can measure different aspects of a plant's growth (height, width, number of leaves, etc.), the anova measures different aspects of variance (between groups, within groups, total).	anova	Explain anova using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 plant's growth
A thermostat is like a garden hose. It helps to regulate the temperature of something by controlling the amount of water that flows through it.	thermostat	Explain thermostat using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden hose
A thermostat is like a gardener who waters plants at set times each day. The gardener knows how much water each plant needs and sets the timer to make sure the plants get the right amount of water. A thermostat does the same thing with heatit turns on and off the furnace at set times to make sure the house stays at a comfortable temperature.	thermostat	Explain thermostat using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardener who waters plants
A thermostat is like a gardener who waters the plants in your garden. The gardener knows how much water each plant needs and when to water them so that they stay healthy. The thermostat does the same thing for your heating and cooling system. It monitors the temperature in your home and turns on or off your heating or cooling system accordingly.	thermostat	Explain thermostat using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardener who waters plants
Chemical equilibrium is like a garden. The plants in the garden are constantly competing for sunlight, water, and nutrients. If one plant becomes too dominant, it will crowd out the other plants. But if there is a balance between the plants, they will all survive and grow healthy.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 a garden
Chemical equilibrium can be thought of as the balance between growing and decaying plants in a garden. If too many plants are grown, they will choke each other out and decay. However, if only a few plants are grown, they will not grow enough to survive. In order for the garden to be in equilibrium, there must be a balance between the number of growing plants and the number of decaying plants.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 balance between growing and decaying plants
Chemical equilibrium is similar to the balance in a garden. The plants take up light and water from the soil and give off oxygen and heat. If there is too much or too little of any one thing, then the balance will be upset and the plants will not grow well. In the same way, if there is too much or too little of any chemical species in a solution, the equilibrium will be disrupted.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 balance in a garden
Just-in-time is like watering your plants. You only water the plants when they need it and not a moment before.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 watering your plants
The analogy of planting a garden is just-in-time. You plant the seeds and water them, but you don't harvest the vegetables until they are ready. With just-in-time, you produce only what is needed and when it is needed.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 planting a garden
Just-in-time is like planting a garden. You plant the seeds and water them, and then wait for them to grow. Once they've grown, you can harvest the vegetables.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 planting a garden
Adaptive immunity is like a gardener who plants seeds and then monitors the progress of the plants. If a plant is not growing well, the gardener will make changes to ensure that the plant thrives. The gardener does this by adjusting the amount of water, sunlight, and fertilizer that the plant receives. In adaptive immunity, white blood cells act as gardeners by monitoring foreign invaders (the plants) and making changes to their response in order to fight off the infection.	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 a gardener who plants seeds and then monitors the progress of the plants
Adaptive immunity is like a gardener who plants new flowers in an empty garden and then watches them grow. The gardener protects the new flowers from being eaten by pests, and when they are big enough, the gardener cuts them off from the stem and puts them in a vase to enjoy.	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardener who plants new flowers###| pests | eat flowers###| vase | put flowers in
Adaptive immunity can be thought of as a gardener who plants seeds in the spring and watches them grow into healthy plants during the summer. The gardener then monitors the health of these plants throughout the fall and winter, removing any weeds that might try to overtake the garden. This is similar to how adaptive immunity works; it recognizes pathogens (weeds) early on and destroys them before they have a chance to cause harm.	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardener who plants seeds and monitors plants
Just as the water pressure in a garden hose can easily be increased by turning up the faucet, the electric current flowing through a wire can be increased by turning up the voltage. The amount of resistance to the flow of current (measured in ohms) is like how many kinks or obstructions are present in the hose.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 water pressure in a garden hose###| voltage | electric current
Ohm's law can be explained using a gardening analogy. Just as plants need water, light, and soil to grow, electrical devices need voltage (the water), current (the light), and resistance (the soil) to function. The higher the voltage, the more current will flow through the device. The higher the resistance, the less current will flow.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardening analogy
Water flowing through a garden hose is an analogy for electricity moving through a wire. The water pressure in the hose is analogous to the voltage in the wire, and the amount of water that flows through the hose is analogous to the current in the wire. Just as you can control how much water comes out of the hose by turning on or off the faucet, you can control how much electricity flows through a wire by controlling its voltage. And just as you can measure how much water is flowing by counting how many seconds it takes for a given volume to flow past a certain point, you can measure how much current is flowing by measuring its effect on some other electrical device.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 water flowing through a garden hose

Transcription is like planting a seed in the ground. The transcription process begins with the DNA molecule, which is like a seed. The DNA molecule is placed inside a special cell called a nucleus. This nucleus is then placed inside an egg cell. When the egg cell is fertilized by sperm, it begins to grow and divide into many new cells. These new cells contain the same DNA as the original egg cell.	transcription	Explain transcription using an analogy. Electricity is like water in a garden hose. The voltage (pressure) is like the water pressure from the faucet. The current (amount of water flowing through the hose) is like the amount of water flowing out of the hose. And resistance is like how easy it is for the water to flow through different parts of the hose.	electric circuit	Explain electric circuit using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 water hose
Electricity is like water in a garden hose. The current (water flow) is like the amount of water flowing through the hose at any given time. Voltage (pressure) is like how high the water pressure is in the hose. Resistance (friction against the water flow) is like how much resistance there is to the water flow, for example from a kink in the hose or from a blockage.	electric circuit	Explain electric circuit using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 water in garden hose
A circuit can be thought of as a garden hose. When the faucet is turned on, water flows through the hose. If you pinch off one end of the hose, no water will flow. The same is true for an electric circuit - when the switch is turned on, electricity flows through the wires. If you pinch off one end of the wire, no electricity will flow	electric circuit	Explain electric circuit using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 garden hose
Hydrophobic effect is like when you water your garden, and the water beads up on top of the soil. The hydrophobic (water-hating) molecules are pushed to the outside of the droplet, where they are more exposed to air. This makes it harder for them to mix with the water, and so they stay in their own little group.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 water beading up on top of soil
One way of thinking about the hydrophobic effect is to imagine water as a crowd of people. The people are all packed together and they are all wet. Now, imagine that someone comes along and pushes some of the people out of the group (the hydrophobic molecules). These lone individuals will quickly dry off since they are no longer surrounded by other wet people. This is essentially what happens when hydrophobic molecules are introduced to water  they push away the surrounding water molecules, causing them to lose their hydrogen bonds and become dried out.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 pushing people out of a group
Water is like a sprinkler system that is watering a garden. The water is spread out and it touches every part of the garden, including the flowers, the plants, and the soil. The water molecules are attracted to each other (because they are all hydrogen atoms) and they stick together. This means that the water can't get deep into the soil to reach the roots of the plants.The hydrophobic effect is like when you turn off the sprinkler system in order to water a specific flower or plant in your garden. You move close to where you want to put the water and then you spray it directly onto that spot. The water droplets aren't attracted to each other as much (because there aren't as many hydrogen atoms) so they can penetrate deep into the soil around the plant's roots.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 turning off the sprinkler system
One way to think about signal transduction is as a process of communication between different parts of a plant. For example, when the sun shines on a plant, it sends light signals that travel down the stem and into the roots. These signals tell the roots to start absorbing water and nutrients from the soil.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 communication between different parts of a plant
One way to think of signal transduction is as if you are a gardener. Imagine that you have just put a new seed in the ground and want it to grow into a plant. To make this happen, you will need to water the seed, give it sunlight, and fertilize it. In the same way, cells need signals (water, sunlight, and fertilizer) to turn on or off different genes and carry out their functions.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 gardening
When you water your plants, the water is like a signal that travels into the soil. The soil is like the cells of the plant, and it absorbs the water and sends it to the roots. The roots are like tiny little factories that take in the water and turn it into food for the plant.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes gardening.	ht	gardening	 watering plants

The Golgi apparatus is like a gardener. It takes the products of the cell's production line (the ER) and packages them up into neat little bundles (the vesicles). It then sends these bundles off to the correct destination (either the cell membrane, where they will be released as new proteins, or back to the ER, where they will be recycled).	golgi apparatus	Using a gardening analogy, explain golgi apparatus.	lt	gardening	 gardener

The nuclear envelope is like the skin of a fruit. It surrounds the nucleus and helps to protect it. The nuclear envelope is made up of two membranes, the outer membrane and the inner membrane. The outer membrane is in contact with the cytoplasm, and the inner membrane is in contact with the nucleus. The nuclear envelope helps to control what goes in and out of the nucleus.	nuclear envelope	Using a gardening analogy, explain nuclear envelope.	lt	gardening	 skin of a fruit###| outer membrane | in contact with the cytoplasm###| inner membrane | in contact with the nucleus

Column chromatography is like using a garden hose to water your plants. The water is the solvent and the plants are the stationary phase. The hose is the column and the water flows through it. The plants are the adsorbent and they adsorb the water. The water flows through the plants and the solvent is enriched with the molecules that are adsorbed by the plants.	column chromatography	Using a gardening analogy, explain column chromatography.	lt	gardening	 using a garden hose to water your plants
A gardener is tending to her plants. She waters them and then waits for them to absorb the water. She then continues to water them, but at a slower rate, so that the water is being absorbed and used by the plants at the same rate at which it is being added. This is an example of dynamic chemical equilibrium.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using a gardening analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium.	lt	gardening	 gardener watering plants
A vacuole is like a garden shed. It is a small, enclosed space used for storage. In plants, vacuoles are used to store water, nutrients, and waste products.	vacuole	Using a gardening analogy, explain vacuole.	lt	gardening	 garden shed

A resonance hybrid is like a Venn diagram. It is a way of representing the different possible electron configurations of an atom. The different configurations are represented by different circles, and the areas where the circles overlap represent the different possible electron configurations that can occur when an atom interacts with other atoms.	resonance hybrid	Using a gardening analogy, explain resonance hybrid.	lt	gardening	 Venn diagram
A wave mechanical model is like when you are gardening and you use a hose to water your plants. The hose is like the wave and the water is like the particles. The hose creates waves of water that flow through the garden. The waves move the water particles around and the water particles move the soil particles around.	wave mechanical model	Using a gardening analogy, explain wave mechanical model.	lt	gardening	 using a hose to water plants
DNA replication is like a gardener planting new seeds. The gardener takes a seed and plants it in the ground. The gardener then waters the seed and watches it grow into a plant. The plant then produces new seeds, which the gardener plants and waters. This process repeats over and over, creating new plants and new seeds.	dna replication	Using a gardening analogy, explain dna replication.	lt	gardening	 gardener planting new seeds
A garden is a great analogy for an ecosystem. In a garden, you have different plants, flowers, and trees, each with their own unique needs in order to grow and thrive. You also have different insects, birds, and other animals that help to pollinate the plants and spread the seeds. In the same way, an ecosystem has different plants and animals, each with their own unique needs in order to survive. The plants and animals in an ecosystem interact with each other to create a balanced system.	ecosystem	Using a gardening analogy, explain ecosystem.	lt	gardening	 a garden
The propagation of an action potential down a neuron can be thought of as a gardener watering a garden. The gardener begins by watering the plants at the edge of the garden. The water then travels inward, watering the plants in the middle of the garden. The process then repeats, with the water traveling outward and inward again. This analogy can be used to explain how an action potential travels down a neuron. The action potential begins at the neuron's synapse, where it is transmitted to the next neuron. The action potential then travels down the neuron's axon, watering the cells along the way. The process then repeats, with the action potential traveling outward and inward again.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using a gardening analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron.	lt	gardening	 gardener watering a garden
The frog's breathing mechanism is similar to that of a human. The frog inhales and exhales air through its nose and mouth. A limiting reactant is a reactant that is in short supply and limits the amount of product that can be formed. For example, in a garden, if you have only one tomato plant and two rabbits, the tomato plant will be the limiting reactant. The rabbits will eat all of the tomatoes.	limiting reactant	Using a gardening analogy, explain limiting reactant.	lt	gardening	 a reactant in short supply

When you plant a seed in the ground, the seed will send out a root system and a shoot system. The root system will grow down into the soil, and the shoot system will grow up and out of the soil. The root system will find water and minerals in the soil and bring them to the shoot system. The shoot system will use the water and minerals to grow the plant.In the same way, drugs will send out a root system and a shoot system. The root system will grow down into the body, and the shoot system will grow up and out of the body. The root system will find receptors in the body and attach to them. The shoot system will use the receptors to send messages to the brain.	interaction between drugs and receptor sites	Using a gardening analogy, explain interaction between drugs and receptor sites.	lt	gardening	 interaction between a plant's root system and the soil

Just-in-time is a production philosophy that aims to minimize waste and inventory by producing goods only as they are needed. In a just-in-time system, parts and materials are delivered to the production line only as they are needed, and only in the quantities that are needed. This eliminates the need for excess inventory, which can be costly to store and manage. It also minimizes the amount of waste that is produced, since products are not produced until they are ordered.	just-in-time	Using a gardening analogy, explain just-in-time.	lt	gardening	 production philosophy minimizing waste and inventory

Ohm's law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the potential difference between those points. In other words, the greater the voltage difference (potential difference) between two points, the greater the current that will flow between them.	ohm's law	Using a gardening analogy, explain ohm's law.	lt	gardening	 current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the potential difference between those points

The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in an aqueous environment. In other words, the hydrophobic effect is the tendency of water to avoid contact with nonpolar molecules. This effect is caused by the interaction of water molecules with the nonpolar molecules. The water molecules form a shell around the nonpolar molecules, and this shell prevents the water molecules from coming into contact with each other.	hydrophobic effect	Using a gardening analogy, explain hydrophobic effect.	lt	gardening	 the tendency of water to avoid contact with nonpolar molecules

One way to think about the invasion of bacteria is to imagine them as weed seeds in your garden. Just as weeds can quickly take over an untended garden, so too can bacteria multiply and spread rapidly if they are not kept in check. To prevent bacterial invasion, you need to be diligent about cleaning and sanitizing your tools and surfaces, and keeping a healthy distance between plants (so that air circulation is optimal).	invasion of bacterias	Using a gardening analogy, explain invasion of bacterias.	ht	gardening	 weed seeds in your garden
When an individual is gardening, they may use a variety of tools to help them maintain their garden. These tools can include a shovel, rake, and hoe. If the gardener does not properly clean these tools after each use, bacteria from the soil may invade the tool and cause it to rust. Action potential is like the turning of a garden hose on and off. The water pressure (action potential) in the hose builds up until it's strong enough to turn the faucet on, at which point the water flows out. After some time, the water pressure decreases until it's no longer strong enough to turn on the faucet, so the flow of water stops. In a similar way, action potentials are generated by an increase in voltage across a cell membrane that reaches a certain threshold; once this voltage is reached, proteins within the membrane open and allow ions to flow into or out of the cell, resulting in an Action Potential	action potential	Using a gardening analogy, explain action potential.	ht	gardening	 turning a garden hose on and off
A gardener might water a plant by pouring water onto the soil around the roots. The water travels through the soil and reaches the roots, where it is absorbed. This process of absorption gradually raises the level of water in the surrounding soil. When this higher level of water reaches a certain point, it causes a flow of liquid to move upward in the stem and out to the leaves. This flow is called capillary action.In much the same way, when an electrical stimulus (such as a pulse of sodium ions) arrives at one end of a nerve cell, it spreads slowly along the cell membrane. As it spreads, it causes adjacent areas of membrane to become electrically excited (depolarized). When enough adjacent areas have been excited, they generate an action potentiala propagating wave of depolarization that passes all the way down the length of the nerve fiber like a sudden rush of water.	action potential	Using a gardening analogy, explain action potential.	ht	gardening	 water rushing down a hill######Nerve cells communicate with one another by sending electrical signals called action potentials. An action potential is a sudden rush of electricity that travels down the length of a nerve fiber. It is caused by the depolarization
Chromatography is like when you are separating the colors of a rainbow using water. You put some water into a jar, and then you add some food coloring to the water. Next, you take a white piece of paper and dip it into the jar. The food coloring will stick to the paper, and each color will be on a different part of the paper.	experiment of chromatography	Using a gardening analogy, explain experiment of chromatography.	ht	gardening	 separating colors of a rainbow
A gardener may use chromatography to separate a mixture of flower petals into individual colors. The same principle is used in scientific laboratories to analyze the compounds present in a sample. A small amount of the sample is placed on a strip of filter paper and then dipped into a solvent. The solvent travels up the strip, dissolving any compounds that it comes into contact with. As the solvent reaches the top of the strip, it separates out each compound according to its molecular weight and polarity.	experiment of chromatography	Using a gardening analogy, explain experiment of chromatography.	ht	gardening	 separating a mixture of flower petals
A gardener might use chromatography to separate the various pigments in a flower. She would dip the petals into a solvent that would dissolve the pigments. The different pigments would then travel at different speeds through a paper towel, allowing her to see which colors were present in the flower.	experiment of chromatography	Using a gardening analogy, explain experiment of chromatography.	ht	gardening	 separating the various pigments in a flower

The nuclear envelope is made up of two membranes: an outer membrane and an inner membrane. The Golgi body is like the garden's compost pile. It takes in all of the unusable parts of the plant - the leaves, stems and flowers that are no longer good for anything else - and breaks them down into a nutrient-rich soil. This soil is then used to help new plants grow. A capacitor is like a tank of water that can store electrical energy. The more water in the tank, the more energy it can store. Similarly, the larger the capacitor, the more electricity it can store.	capacitance	Using a gardening analogy, explain capacitance.	ht	gardening	 the size of a tank of water
A capacitor is like a water tank. It stores energy until it is needed. The more water in the tank, the more energy it can store. A capacitor also has two pipes that lead out of it. One pipe is for filling up the tank and one pipe is for draining the tank.	capacitance	Using a gardening analogy, explain capacitance.	ht	gardening	 a water tank
Electric current is much like water flow in a garden hose. Just as the water flowing through the hose can cause the hose to bend, electric current flowing through a wire can cause the wire to heat up.	electric current	Using a gardening analogy, explain electric current.	ht	gardening	 water flow in a garden hose
Electric current is like the water in a garden hose. It flows from high pressure to low pressure. In an electric circuit, the voltage (high pressure) is created by the battery or power supply. The current (flow of electrons) flows through the wires and devices in the circuit until it reaches the ground (low pressure).	electric current	Using a gardening analogy, explain electric current.	ht	gardening	 water in a garden hose###| voltage | high pressure in the garden hose###| current | flow of electrons###| ground | low pressure in the garden hose
Electric current is like the flow of water in a garden hose. Just as the water pressure in the hose can make it difficult to move if there is too much, electric current is measured by how strong its pushing force is (in volts). The more water that flows through the hose (in amperes), the harder it will be to stop the flow.	electric current	Using a gardening analogy, explain electric current.	ht	gardening	 flow of water in a garden hose
When you water your plants, the voltage is like the pressure of the water. The more water you have, the higher the pressure. Voltage is a measure of how much electrical energy is pushing through a circuit.	voltage	Using a gardening analogy, explain voltage.	ht	gardening	 water pressure
Voltage is similar to water pressure. Just as water pressure can cause a faucet to flow, voltage can make electrons flow through a conductor (such as metal). The higher the voltage, the more force it has to push the electrons along.	voltage	Using a gardening analogy, explain voltage.	ht	gardening	 water pressure
Voltage is a measure of how much potential energy exists to do work. Just as with water pressure in a garden hose, the higher the voltage rating of an electrical device or wire, the more force it has available to push electrons (electricity) through it.	voltage	Using a gardening analogy, explain voltage.	ht	gardening	 water pressure in a garden hose
A cell is like a garden. The plant in the garden has different parts that specialize in doing different things to help the plant grow. The roots anchor the plant in the soil and take up water and minerals from the ground. The stem transports water and nutrients from the roots to the leaves, and also carries food manufactured by the leaves to other parts of the plant. The leaves use sunlight to produce food for the plant. Specialized cells within each part of the plant communicate with each other to coordinate their activities. For example, when a leaf detects increased light intensity, it sends a signal to other cells in the leaf that causes them to increase production of food.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using a gardening analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell.	ht	gardening	 specialization and communication in a plant
In a cell, specialization and communication are like the different parts of a plant. The roots are responsible for getting water and minerals from the soil to the rest of the plant, the stem transports water and nutrients up to the leaves, and the leaves use sunlight to produce food for the plant. Each part has a specialized function, but they all work together to keep the plant alive. In much the same way, cells specialize in different tasks, but they all need to communicate with each other in order to carry out complex processes like growth and reproduction.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using a gardening analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell.	ht	gardening	 the different parts of a plant
Kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of all voltages around a closed loop is zero. In other words, the electric current always flows in such a way as to create a potential difference (or voltage) that opposes any change in voltage.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using a gardening analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law.	ht	gardening	 electric current always flows in such a way as to create a potential difference
In electrical systems, there are voltages and currents. The voltage is the electric potential difference between two points in a circuit, while the current is the flow of electrons through that circuit. Kirchoff's Voltage Law states that the sum of all the voltages in a closed loop must be zero. This means that if you have a series of resistors (like in a flashlight), the total voltage across those resistors must be zero. If you have any other type of circuit, like a parallel resistor ladder, then each branch of that ladder must have the same voltage at every point.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using a gardening analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law.	ht	gardening	 electrical systems
A density wave is like a ripple in a pond. It is an oscillation or vibration of material that travels through a medium. In the case of water, the ripples are created when a stone is thrown into the pond. The waves move out from the point of impact and then disappear as they spread out.	nature of a density wave	Using a gardening analogy, explain nature of a density wave.	ht	gardening	 ripple in a pond
If you think of a garden, the plants in the back are taller than the ones in front. This is because they have more time to grow and get bigger. A density wave is like this too - it's a pattern of movement where something (like people) moves from one place to another over time. The people at the back move to the front, and then new people come to the back.	nature of a density wave	Using a gardening analogy, explain nature of a density wave.	ht	gardening	 people moving from one place to another over time
A density wave is like the waves that ripple through water when you throw a rock into it. The wave starts at the point where the rock was thrown in and travels outwards. The same thing happens with a density wave-it starts at a certain point and moves outwards.	nature of a density wave	Using a gardening analogy, explain nature of a density wave.	ht	gardening	 waves that ripple through water when you throw a rock into it

The flowers in the garden are the memories themselves, which come in all shapes and sizes. Some memories are bright and colorful, while others are more faded. As they grow, the gardener nurtures and cares for them, pruning them when necessary.
