A golgi body is like a locker room for the cells. It is where they can go to take a break, eat, and rest before they head back out onto the playing field.	golgi body	Explain golgi body using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 locker room for the cells
A capacitor is like a water balloon. When you squeeze the balloon, the pressure inside increases and the water squirts out. The capacitance is how much energy it takes to increase the pressure by one unit.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 water balloon
Capacitance is a measure of how much electrical charge can be stored in an object. It is measured in farads (F). Capacitance can be compared to the amount of water that can be held in a bucket. Just as the larger the bucket, the more water it can hold, capacitors with a higher capacitance rating can store more electrical charge.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 the amount of water that can be held in a bucket
When two people hold hands, the capacitance between their palms is increased. This is because they are now sharing a common electrical conductor (their skin). The more surface area that is touching, the greater the capacitance.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 two people holding hands
Electric current is like a flow of water in a pipe. Just as the speed of the water can be controlled by narrowing or widening the opening at the end of the pipe, electric current can be controlled by adjusting the width (or resistance) of the electrical circuit.	electric current	Explain electric current using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 flow of water in a pipe
Electric current is like a stream of water. The more water there is, the faster it will flow. The same is true for electricitythe more current there is, the faster it will flow. Just as you can use a hose to direct the flow of water in your yard, you can use a device called an electrical conductor to direct the flow of electric current.	electric current	Explain electric current using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 stream of water###| electrical conductor | hose
Electric current is the flow of electric charge. It can be thought of as like a stream of water flowing through a pipe. The greater the voltage (or water pressure), the faster the current will flow.	electric current	Explain electric current using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 flow of electric charge
Volts can be thought of as the speed at which an electric current flows. Just as a car needs more gas (orvoltage) to go faster, an electric current needs more voltage to flow faster.	voltage	Explain voltage using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 speed of an electric current
If you think of voltage as electricity's "pressure," then it's easy to see how it can be thought of as analogous to water pressure in a plumbing system. Just like water pressure can cause faucets and showerheads to deliver a powerful stream of water, voltage (electricity pressure) can make devices like light bulbs glow brightly or motors turn quickly.	voltage	Explain voltage using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 water pressure
If you think of voltage as electrical "pressure," then it's easy to see how it would be analogous to water pressure in a hose. Just like the higher water pressure in a garden hose can make it more difficult for your hands to stop the flow, a high voltage current will be harder to block or interrupt than one with lower pressure.	voltage	Explain voltage using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 electrical "pressure"###| water pressure | analogy to voltage
In a cell, specialization refers to the different tasks that various parts of the cell perform in order to keep the cell functioning. For example, some cells may be responsible for producing energy while others may be responsible for repairing damage to the cell membrane. Communication between these specialized cells is essential for coordinating their activities and ensuring that the entire cell functions as a unit. In a sports analogy, specialization would be like each player on a team having a specific role or job to do in order to win the game. Communication between players would be necessary for relaying information about what is happening on the field and making sure everyone is on the same page.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 players on a sports team
In a basketball game, players on the same team can specialize in playing certain positions. For example, one player may be good at shooting baskets, while another player is better at blocking shots or stealing the ball from the other team. The players communicate with each other to give and receive information about what is happening on the court. The players also work together to achieve common goals, such as scoring points or preventing the other team from scoring.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 specialization and communication in a basketball game
In a football game, the quarterback needs to be able to throw the ball to the right receiver. The wide receivers need to be able to catch the ball and run with it. And finally, someone has to block for them. Specialization happens when each player does what they are good at - throwing, catching, running, and blocking. Communication happens when they talk to each other on the field and figure out who is going where and when.	specialization and communication in a cell	Explain specialization and communication in a cell using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football game
Kirchoff's voltage law can be explained using a sports analogy. Imagine a group of people playing a game of soccer. The players are spread out all over the field, and each one is trying to score goals. To score a goal, the player needs to run up to the ball and kick it into the net. In order to do this, the player has to run towards the net while avoiding being tackled by the other players. If two players are running towards the same spot at the same time, they will collide with each other and neither of them will be able to score a goal. This is similar to what happens when electricity travels through wires. If there are too many wires travelling through one spot, they will all start colliding with each other and none of them will be able to pass through.	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 group of people playing soccer
In a nutshell, Kirchhoff's Voltage Law states that the sum of all voltages in a circuit must be zero. This law is basically like saying that in any given game or match, the total score can never be negative - it must always add up to 0. In terms of electrical circuits, this means that the voltage at any point in a circuit must always balance out - it can't be positive at one end and negative at the other.	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 a game or match with a total score of 0
Kirchoff's voltage law is similar to the game of basketball. When two teams are playing each other, each team tries to score points by throwing the ball into the other team's basket. The team that scores more points than their opponent wins the game. In a similar way, when two electrical circuits are connected together, each circuit tries to send electricity through the other circuit. The circuit that sends more electricity through the other circuit than it receives from the other circuit is said to have won and is said to be "energized."	kirchoff's voltage law	Explain kirchoff's voltage law using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 basketball
A density wave is a situation where there are more people in one area than another. A good analogy would be to imagine a stadium during a popular game. The fans at the 50-yard line are much denser than those at the opposite end of the field. This creates a wave of people that moves through the stadium as time goes on.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 stadium during a popular game
A density wave is like a crowd of people at a sports game. The people are all packed together in one area, and then they spread out evenly across the rest of the stadium.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 people at a sports game
Imagine a large stadium filled with spectators. At any given moment, most of the people are packed together in the center of the stadium. A few people are at either end of the stadium, and there is a lot of empty space in between. Now imagine that someone stands up on their seat in the middle of the stadium. The wave travels out from where they are standing until it reaches the edge of the stadium. Then it reverses directions and comes back to where it started. This is how a density wave works-it travels through a material until it reaches an obstacle (usually an edge), then reflects back until it recombines with itself somewhere else.	nature of a density wave	Explain nature of a density wave using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 how a wave works
An enzyme is like a good coach. They help the team to win by providing instructions and giving support. Enzymes work in the same way by providing instructions for chemical reactions and helping to provide the necessary support.	enzymes	Explain enzymes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 good coaches
Enzymes are like the referees of a sports game. They make sure that everything is going smoothly and that all the rules are being followed.	enzymes	Explain enzymes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 referees of a sports game
Enzymes are like athletes. They are very good at doing one thing and they do it quickly.	enzymes	Explain enzymes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 athletes
One can think of the human active memory system as being like a large filing cabinet. The cabinet is filled with folders, each one representing a different memory. Within each folder are individual slips of paper, each one containing information about a particular event or experience. To remember something, you simply need to find the appropriate folder and then locate the slip of paper that contains the information you want to recall.	human active memory system	Explain human active memory system using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 a large filing cabinet
A human's active memory system can be thought of as a sports analogy. The brain is like the quarterback, calling the plays and directing the team. The working memory is like the players on the field - they are constantly taking in new information and trying to keep up with what is going on. And finally, long-term memory is like the stadium - it holds all of the information that has been gathered over time.	human active memory system	Explain human active memory system using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports analogy
The human active memory system can be likened to a sports team. The team's players (memory representations) work together to achieve the goal of winning the game. The players must remember what they are supposed to do and then carry out those tasks. As the game progresses, new tasks may be added and old ones may be forgotten, but the team must continue to play as best they can in order to win.	human active memory system	Explain human active memory system using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports team
In a race, the rate-determining step is the point at which the runners are most evenly matched. The same analogy can be used for reactions; the rate-determining step is the point at which the reactants have reached their equilibrium and no further reaction can take place.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Explain rate-determining step of a reaction using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 the point at which the reactants have reached their equilibrium
The rate-determining step is the slowest step in a reaction. This analogy might help to understand it. When two people are playing catch, the speed of the game is determined by how long it takes for one person to throw the ball to the other person. The time it takes for one person to throw the ball is determined by how fast that person can throw and how far away from them the other person is. If someone throws the ball very quickly but they are far away from their partner, then it will take a while for them to get the ball back. However, if someone throws the ball slowly but they are close to their partner, then they will be able to get it back more quickly. In both cases, though,the speed of play (or reaction rate) is ultimately determined by how long it takes for someone to throw the ball (the rate-determining step).	rate-determining step of a reaction	Explain rate-determining step of a reaction using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 the speed of a game of catch
The rate-determining step is the slowest step in a reaction. It is like a player on a sports team who is not as fast as the other players. This player can't keep up with the rest of the team and ends up slowing them down.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Explain rate-determining step of a reaction using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 player on a sports team who is not as fast as the other players
Column chromatography is like when a sports team separates the best players from the rest of the players. The best players are put in one category (the "column") and the rest of the players are put in another category (the "matrix").	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 separating the best players from the rest of the players###| matrix | the rest of the players
Column chromatography is like when a basketball coach separates players into different teams according to their skills. The coach puts the best players on one team and the weakest players on another team. This way, each team has the best chance of winning. Column chromatography does the same thing with chemicals. It separates them according to how strongly they stick to a column. The most tightly-bound chemicals stay at the top of the column, while less tightly-bound chemicals flow down the column and out of it.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 a basketball coach separating players into different teams
Column chromatography is a technique used to separate mixtures of compounds. The mixture is placed in a column and a solvent is then passed through the column. The different compounds will move through the column at different speeds, allowing them to be separated. This can be likened to sports such as track and field, where athletes compete in different events based on their speed.	column chromatography	Explain column chromatography using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 track and field
Dynamic chemical equilibrium can be likened to a sports game in which both teams are equally matched. The game is fluid and ever-changing, with neither side able to gain an advantage for very long. In the same way, at dynamic chemical equilibrium the concentrations of all the reactants and products in a system are constantly changing as they collide and react with each other.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Explain dynamic chemical equilibrium using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 a sports game in which both teams are equally matched
A basketball game is an example of a dynamic chemical equilibrium. The players are constantly exchanging energy and bouncing the ball back and forth. If you were to measure the temperature of the court at any given moment, it would be in equilibrium because there is a balance between the heat being radiated by the players and absorbed by the court.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Explain dynamic chemical equilibrium using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 basketball game
In a chemical equilibrium, the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal. This can be compared to two people playing tug-of-war. If both teams pull with the same strength, they will remain stationary.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Explain dynamic chemical equilibrium using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 two people playing tug-of-war
A vacuole is similar to a sports stadium. The vacuole is the large building where the game (cellular processes) takes place. The cell membrane is like the fence around the stadium, and the cytoplasm is like the field inside. The nucleus is like the control room, where all of the action is directed.	vacuole	Explain vacuole using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports stadium###| cell membrane | fence around the stadium###| cytoplasm | field inside###| nucleus | control room
A vacuole is like a sports stadium. It is a large, enclosed area where people can gather to watch a game or event.	vacuole	Explain vacuole using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports stadium
A vacuole is like a locker room for the cells. It's a place where they can store things, like water or food.	vacuole	Explain vacuole using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 locker room for the cells
A sports analogy for transport vesicles would be a player on a soccer team. The player is responsible for transporting the ball down the field to score a goal. The transport vesicle is responsible for transporting molecules (the ball) down the cell membrane and into the cytoplasm where they can carry out their function.	transport vesicles	Explain transport vesicles using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 player on a soccer team
A sports analogy for transport vesicles would be a water balloon. The water inside the balloon is like the cargo being transported in the vesicle. When you blow up the balloon, the air pressure pushes against the walls of the balloon, causing it to expand. This expansion forces the water out of small holes (or pores) in the rubber and into your hand. In much the same way, when a transport vesicle fuses with its target membrane, it expels its cargo into the cell.	transport vesicles	Explain transport vesicles using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 water balloon
A transport vesicle can be thought of as a "player" on a sports team. The player's role is to carry the ball (molecules) down the field (cell membrane) and into the opposing team's territory (the cytoplasm).	transport vesicles	Explain transport vesicles using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 players on a sports team
A proto-oncogene is a gene that can become an oncogene. In sports terms, proto-oncogenes would be like the players who have the potential to become stars. They might not be among the best players on their team right now, but they have the ability to become top performers with some training and experience. Oncogenes, meanwhile, would be like professional athletes who are already at the top of their game.	proto-oncogenes	Explain proto-oncogenes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 players who have the potential to become stars###| oncogenes | professional athletes
Proto-oncogenes are like the coaches of a sports team. They help to control how the team functions and make sure that everyone is doing their job correctly. However, sometimes these genes can become mutated and turn into oncogenes. Oncogenes are like players on the sports team who start to cause chaos and don't follow the coach's instructions. This can lead to the team becoming disorganized and unable to function properly, which is similar to how cancer can develop when proto-oncogenes become mutated and turned into oncogenes.	proto-oncogenes	Explain proto-oncogenes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 coaches of a sports team###| oncogenes | players on the sports team
Proto-oncogenes are like the coach of a sports team. They help to regulate how cells grow and divide, and they can also prevent tumors from forming. However, if something goes wrong and these genes become damaged or mutated, they can turn into cancer-promoting oncogenes.	proto-oncogenes	Explain proto-oncogenes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 the coach of a sports team###| oncogenes | cancer-promoting
Oncogenes are like a player on a sports team who is very good at scoring goals. They help the cell to grow and divide quickly, which can lead to cancer if they are not controlled.	oncogenes	Explain oncogenes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 a player on a sports team who is very good at scoring goals
Oncogenes are like players on a sports team. They help the cell to grow and divide, which is necessary for tissue growth and healing. However, when oncogenes are overactive or mutated, they can cause the cell to grow out of control, leading to cancer.	oncogenes	Explain oncogenes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 players on a sports team
An oncogene is a gene that can lead to cancer. It is like a player on a sports team who is very talented and aggressive. This player can cause the rest of the team to become more competitive and successful. However, if this player gets too aggressive or becomes injured, it can disrupt the entire team's performance.	oncogenes	Explain oncogenes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 players on a sports team
Tumor suppressor genes can be thought of as the "coach" of a sports team. They help keep things organized and under control, ensuring that the team functions smoothly and effectively. In the same way, tumor suppressor genes help to prevent tumors from developing by regulating cell growth and preventing cells from becoming cancerous.	tumor suppressor genes	Explain tumor suppressor genes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 coach of a sports team
One analogy for tumor suppressor genes is that they are the "coach" of the cells. They help to keep everything organized and running smoothly, preventing tumors from forming.	tumor suppressor genes	Explain tumor suppressor genes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 coach of the cells
Tumor suppressor genes are like the referees in a game. They make sure that the game is played fairly and according to the rules. In the same way, tumor suppressor genes make sure that cells grow and divide correctly, preventing tumors from forming.	tumor suppressor genes	Explain tumor suppressor genes using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 referees in a game
A software application can be thought of as a brittle sports car. It looks great when it is new, but the more it is used, the more likely it is to break down. The problem with brittle software is that it doesn't handle stress very well. Every time it is used, there is a greater chance that something will go wrong.	brittle software	Explain brittle software using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 a sports car
A brittle software program is like a basketball player that can only make baskets when they are standing in one spot on the court. They might be able to score from time to time if their opponent happens to stand in the same spot, but they won't be able to do much against someone who defends them by moving around. A flexible software program is like a basketball player who can make baskets anywhere on the court. They might not always score, but they'll have a lot more success than the brittle player.	brittle software	Explain brittle software using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 basketball player that can only make baskets when they are standing in one spot on the court###| flexible software | basketball player who can make baskets anywhere on the court
Brittle software is like a wooden bat in baseball. If it's hit the right way, it will send the ball flying far. But if it's hit too hard in the wrong direction, it will shatter into pieces.	brittle software	Explain brittle software using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 wooden bat in baseball
Picture a large, crowded stadium with everyone on their feet cheering for their favorite team. Now imagine that the crowd is made up of individuals who represent different energy levels - some are very excited and others are only mildly interested. The people who are very excited will create more noise and energy than those who are not as enthusiastic. In the same way, atoms that have higher energy levels will be more likely to absorb light or sound waves than those with lower energies.	resonance hybrid	Explain resonance hybrid using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 a large, crowded stadium######When you strike a tuning fork and hold it near a string on a guitar, the string will start to vibrate because it is in resonance with the tuning fork. A resonance hybrid is a molecule consisting of two or more atoms that are bonded together, with one or more unpaired electrons. A sports analogy for resonance hybrid would be a team made up of players from different teams who all play well together. The players might not have the same skills, but they work well as a team and can win games.	resonance hybrid	Explain resonance hybrid using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 team made up of players from different teams
Resonance hybrid is like when two teams play each other in a sport. The players on one team try to work together and use their skills to score against the other team. But, the players on the other team are also trying to work together and use their own skills to stop the players on the first team from scoring. So, it's not just one player against another player, but all of the players working together as a whole to achieve their goal.	resonance hybrid	Explain resonance hybrid using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 two teams playing each other in a sport
Wave mechanics is like a game of catch. When you throw the ball to your friend, the energy in your arm is transferred to the ball. The ball then transfers this energy to your friend's hand, and they throw it back to you. This process continues until the energy in the ball dissipates.	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 game of catch
The wave mechanical model can be explained using a sports analogy. In this analogy, waves represent the movement of players on a football field. The peaks of the waves represent the location of the players at their highest point, and the troughs of the waves represent the location of the players at their lowest point. This analogy can help to visualize how particles in a gas or liquid move around and interact with one another.	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports analogy
If you think of a wave as a group of people standing next to each other and then moving together in one direction, that is basically what waves are like at the atomic level. Just like with the people analogy, when electrons move forward they create a new wave (or group of people) behind them.	wave mechanical model	Explain wave mechanical model using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 people analogy
An electroencephalogram can be thought of as a sports scoreboard. It keeps track of the "score" or electrical activity in your brain.	electroencephalogram	Explain electroencephalogram using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports scoreboard
Your brain is like a quarterback in the pocket. The EEG measures the speed and intensity of the "electrical activity" of your brain. This can be thought of as how hard and fast your neurons are firing. just like a quarterback needs to get a good read on how quickly the defense is closing in on him, you need to know what's going on with your brainwaves so you can make decisions quickly and effectively.	electroencephalogram	Explain electroencephalogram using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 measure of speed and intensity of "electrical activity" of brain
An EEG is like taking the pulse of a sports team. Just as with a heart rate, you can tell how active and alert a team is by looking at their brain waves. When they are playing well, their brain waves are strong and consistent. But when they start to falter, their brain waves change and become more erratic.	electroencephalogram	Explain electroencephalogram using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 taking the pulse of a sports team
In order for a team to win the game, they need to have a copy of the playbook. In order for dna replication to occur, cells need to have a copy of the genetic information (the playbook). The genetic information is stored in dna and it is replicated when cells divide.	dna replication	Explain dna replication using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 copying a playbook
DNA replication is a bit like how a sports team might make a copy of their playbook. The DNA molecule is the playbook, and it contains all the instructions for building and running the cell. To make a copy of the DNA, enzymes called polymerases read through the molecule and create new strands of DNA that are identical to the original.	dna replication	Explain dna replication using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 copying a sports team's playbook
 DNA replication can be likened to a sports team. The coach of the team is responsible for creating a game plan and giving instructions to the players. The players then carry out the plan by playing the game. In the same way, DNA replication is initiated by enzymes called helicases that unwind the double helix into two single strands. RNA polymerase reads each strand and creates new copies of the DNA molecule by assembling complementary bases	dna replication	Explain dna replication using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports team
A football team has a playbook that they use as a guide during games. The playbook is like the rna transcriptome - it contains all of the plays that the team knows how to run. When the coach wants to call a play, he'll pick one from the playbook and tell his players what to do. During a game, each player will listen to their coach and then run their assigned play. This is similar to how rna transcription works in cells - when a gene is turned on, the cell's rna polymerase will read through the genome looking for specific sequences called promoters. Once it finds them, it will start transcribing RNA using the information from those promoters.	rna transcription	Explain rna transcription using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football team playbook
When athletes are called to compete in a sport, they go through a process known as transcription. This means that their bodies take the information given to them by their coaches and trainers and turn it into muscle memory. In the same way, RNA takes the genetic instructions from DNA and creates proteins that carry out the cell's functions.	rna transcription	Explain rna transcription using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 athletes taking information from coaches and trainers to create muscle memory
In sports, a transcription is when someone repeats what another person has said. In RNA transcription, the DNA code is copied and turned into RNA.	rna transcription	Explain rna transcription using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 transcription in sports
Protein translation is similar to a football game. The genetic code (football playbook) is the instruction manual for making proteins. The mRNA (players) are the ones that carry the instructions from the DNA to the ribosomes (field). tRNA (translators) are like coaches, they help make sure that the players follow the correct instructions from the playbook. rRNA (referees) make sure everything runs smoothly and that no fouls are called. Proteins are like touchdowns, they are the end goal of protein translation.	protein translation	Explain protein translation using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football game
Protein translation is the process by which a gene's DNA sequence is converted into an amino acid chain, or protein. This analogy might help to understand it: think of genes as recipes for proteins andTranslation as the actual cooking process. Just like you can't make a cake without following a recipe, your cells can't produce proteins without specific instructions written in genes. During Translation, these genetic recipes are read and translated into chains of amino acids that will eventually become proteins	protein translation	Explain protein translation using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 cooking a recipe
The process of protein translation is similar to a sports team. The genetic code is the coach and provides the instructions for building the protein. The ribosomes are the players and they read and follow the coach's instructions to build the protein. The tRNA molecules are like trainers, providing the correct amino acids needed to build the protein.	protein translation	Explain protein translation using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports team

In order for the team to be successful, each athlete must perform their role effectively. The environment provides the necessary resources and conditions for survival.	ecosystem	Explain ecosystem using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 team of athletes

The propagation of an action potential down a neuron can be likened to the way a sports crowd cheers. When someone initiates the cheer, it quickly spreads through the crowd until everyone is participating. This happens because each person in the crowd is influenced by the people around them. The same thing happens with an action potential as it travels down a neuron. The sodium ions that are rushing into the neuron cause it to fire and this in turn causes adjacent neurons to fire as well. This creates a domino effect that allows information to travel quickly throughout the brain	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 the way a sports crowd cheers
An action potential is like a runner starting at the front of a race and running down the line. The runners (action potentials) start at the neuron's cell body and run down its axon. When an action potential reaches the end of the neuron's axon, it causes neurotransmitters to be released into the synapse.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 runners starting a race
When an action potential is generated at the dendrite of a neuron, it travels down the neuron's axon to the next neuron. This can be thought of as an electric current travelling down a wire. Just like when you turn on a light switch in one room and the lightbulb in that room turns on, but the light in other rooms doesn't turn on, so too does each action potential generate a small electrical current that only propagates to the next neuron if its threshold is reached.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 propagation of an electric current down a wire
The breathing mechanism of frogs is similar to that of athletes. Frogs breathe in through their noses and out through their mouths. Their lungs are located on the inside of their ribcages, and when they inhale, the air travels down into their lungs. When they exhale, the air goes back out through their mouths.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Explain breathing mechanism of frogs using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 breathing mechanism of athletes
If you are a basketball player, and you want to take a breath, you would have to stop dribbling the ball. This is because when you dribble the ball, it takes up all of your concentration and energy. Breathing is something that we do unconsciously- we dont have to think about it. When we are focused on doing something else, like playing basketball, our body automatically puts our breathing on hold so that we can focus on the task at hand. Frogs work in a similar way. They use their breathing muscles to inflate their lungs with air, and then they close off these muscles so that the air stays in their lungs. This allows them to stay underwater for long periods of time without having to come up for air.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Explain breathing mechanism of frogs using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 breathing mechanism of basketball players
A frog's breathing mechanism can be compared to that of a sportsperson. When a person inhales, their chest cavity expands and the air pressure inside decreases. This decrease in pressure sucks air into the lungs. The same principle applies to frogs; when they inhale, the air pressure inside their body decreases, which causes oxygen-rich water to flow into their lungs. When they exhale, the muscles around their ribcage compress their lungs and push carbon dioxide-rich water out of their mouths.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Explain breathing mechanism of frogs using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 breathing mechanism of sportspeople
A layered architecture is like a sports team. The players at the top of the organization are in charge of making decisions that affect the entire team. They work with the coaches to develop strategies and plans that guide the team's progress. The players below them carry out these plans and make adjustments as needed. This hierarchy ensures that everyone has a clear understanding of their role and what they need to do to help the team succeed.	layered architecture	Explain layered architecture using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports team
Imagine a sports game where the spectators are sitting in the stands watching the action on a field below them. The people in the stands can see everything that is happening on the field, but they cannot interact with what is going on down there. Now imagine that there are also people walking around on the field. These people can see and interact with everything that is happening on the field, but they cannot see or interact with anything happening in the stands. This analogy illustrates layered architecture, where each layer can only see and interact with things in its own layer and lower layers.	layered architecture	Explain layered architecture using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 people in the stands and people on the field
A football team can be divided into offense, defense, and special teams. The offensive players are responsible for advancing the ball down the field. The defensive players try to stop the other team from scoring. The special teams players are responsible for kicking or punting the ball. These divisions can also be further subdivided into positions: quarterback, running back, lineman, cornerback, etc.	layered architecture	Explain layered architecture using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football team
One way to think about limiting and excess reactants is by using the analogy of two sports teams competing against each other. In this analogy, the players on one team are the reactants and the players on the other team are the products. The game can be thought of as a race to see which side can finish its players first. If one team has more players than the other, then it will naturally win (i.e., it will have more products). This is essentially what happens when there is a limiting reactant: The reaction can only go as fast as the slowest step, which means that not all of the reactants will get used up.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 two sports teams competing against each other
In a basketball game, there are five players on the court for each team. In order for one team to score, one of the players on the other team must have the ball. The ball is the limiting reactant and each player is an excess reactant.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 basketball game
In a football game, the players are the reactants and the ball is the limiting reactant. The number of players on each team is fixed (the reaction conditions), so only a certain amount of interaction between teams can take place. If one team has more players than the other, it will have an excess of reactants and will be able to interact more with the other team.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Explain limiting reactant and excess reactant using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football game

The proteins are all organized into specialized units called organelles. Just like a professional sports team has a coach, eukaryotic cells also have molecules that control important functions such as gene expression and protein production.	eukaryotic cell	Explain eukaryotic cell using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 professional sports team###| proteins | players###| organelles | specialized units###| gene expression | control important functions###| protein production | control important functions

The cytoplasm is the field where the game takes place.	eukaryotic cell	Explain eukaryotic cell using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports team###| nucleus | coach###| cytoplasm | field
Eukaryotic cells can be compared to a professional sports team. Just like each player on a sports team has a specific role in order for the team to be successful, each organelle within a eukaryotic cell has a specific role in order for the cell to function. The nucleus is like the head coach, giving instructions and organizing the rest of the team. The cytoplasm is like the locker room, providing a place for the players to prepare before they go out onto the playing field. The plasma membrane is like the boundary between home base and the rest of the playing field, protecting the cell from outside invaders while allowing necessary molecules to pass through. And finally, mitochondria and chloroplasts are like referees, monitoring and regulating all activity withinthe cell.	eukaryotic cell	Explain eukaryotic cell using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 professional sports team

Just as the quarterback is the most important player on a football team, so too is the kernel the most important part of an operating system. The kernel provides basic services that all other applications need in order to run, such as memory management and process scheduling. It also handles communication between software components and the underlying hardware.	operating systems kernel	Explain operating systems kernel using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 quarterback of a football team
The kernel of an operating system can be thought of as the quarterback of a football team. He is responsible for making sure that everything runs smoothly and that all of the players are doing their jobs correctly. Similarly, the kernel of an operating system ensures that all of the different parts of the computer are working together properly and that programs are running as they should be.	operating systems kernel	Explain operating systems kernel using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 quarterback of a football team
In a sports game, there is a limit to the number of players that can be on the field at one time. The same is true for chemical reactions - there is a limit to the number of atoms or molecules that can participate in a reaction at any one time. The reactant that limits the reaction is called the limiting reactant.	limiting reactant	Explain limiting reactant using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 a sports game
In a football game, the offensive team has a certain number of plays (or downs) to advance the ball 10 yards. If they don't reach the 10-yard line after their fourth down, then they have to give up possession of the ball to the other team. The same is true for chemical reactions: if Reactant A is used up before Reactant B, then Reactant A is said to be a limiting reactant.	limiting reactant	Explain limiting reactant using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football game
A limiting reactant in a sports analogy would be like the referee. They are there to make sure that both teams are playing by the rules and that no one gets too out of hand. In the same way, the limiting reactant is responsible for making sure that only as much product is formed as possible with the given amount of starting material.	limiting reactant	Explain limiting reactant using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 referee in a sports analogy

In order to do this, he needs to be able to run quickly and throw the ball accurately. A helicase is responsible for moving DNA strands around so that they can be copied or repaired properly. This requires speed and accuracy, just like a quarterback.	helicase	Explain helicase using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 quarterback in American football
A helicase is like a pitcher in baseball. The pitcher throws the ball to the catcher, who then tries to catch it. If the catcher misses, the ball goes into the stands and someone may catch it. This is similar to how helicases work - they bind to DNA and then "throw" it off so that another enzyme can bind to it and continue reading the sequence.	helicase	Explain helicase using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 pitcher in baseball

If you are encoding a message, you are essentially putting it in a secret code that only the intended recipient can understand. In order for the message to be sent, it must first be translated into an easily understandable format - like English. Once it is in this form, it can be sent via email, text message or any other means of communication. However, when the message arrives at its destination, it will need to be re-encoded back into the original code so that only the person who originally received it will be able to read it.	message encoding	Explain message encoding using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 translating a message into an easily understandable format
In order to encode a message, you would first need to choose a code. In sports, this might be like choosing between playing basketball or football. Once you have chosen your game, you then need to select the specific rules that will apply. For example, in basketball you might decide that only two points can be scored from within the three-point line. This is your code.To send a message using this code, you would first need to write it down on paper. Next, you would need to identify the starting point of the message and draw an imaginary line from there to the end of the message. You would then mark off each word along this line according to the code's instructions. So for our basketball example, if we wanted to say "The cat sat on the mat," our encoded message would look like this:T h e c at s at o n t h e m at	message encoding	Explain message encoding using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 playing basketball or football
If you think of a message as a sports score, encoding would be like converting the numbers into text so that others can understand it. For example, encoding the number 12 as "twelve" makes it easier for people to read and understand.	message encoding	Explain message encoding using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports score
A receptor site is like a basketball hoop. When a ball (drug) is thrown at the hoop, it either goes in or it doesn't. If the drug fits into the receptor site like a perfect fit, then it will be absorbed by the cell and have an effect. If not, it won't pass through and will be eliminated from the body.	interaction between drugs and receptor sites	Explain interaction between drugs and receptor sites using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 basketball hoop
If you are a fan of a particular sport, you likely have favorite players that you enjoy watching. You may also have players that you don't particularly like. If your favorite player is playing against your least favorite player, you will likely be more interested in the game and pay more attention to what is happening. The same is true for drugs and receptor sites. When a drug binds to a receptor site, it can create an interaction that is either favorable or unfavorable. If the drug has a favorable interaction with the receptor site, it will be more effective at producing the desired effect. If the drug has an unfavorable interaction with the receptor site, it may not produce any effect or it could produce an undesired effect.	interaction between drugs and receptor sites	Explain interaction between drugs and receptor sites using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 interaction between a fan and their favorite player
Drugs can be thought of as athletes, while receptor sites are the sports arena. When an athlete (drug) enters the arena (receptor site), they may interact in a number of ways. They may compete against each other for space and resources, or they may work together to achieve a common goal. In some cases, one athlete may completely dominate the other, while in others they may share equal standing. The outcome of this interaction depends on many factors, including the type and amount of each drug involved, as well as the characteristics of the receptor site itself.	interaction between drugs and receptor sites	Explain interaction between drugs and receptor sites using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 interaction between athletes and sports arena

CPU usage can be thought of as the percentage of time during a game that a player is on the field. Just as important as how often a player is on the field, however, is what they are doing when they are there. A quarterback who spends most of the game handing off to running backs won't have the same impact as one who scrambles for yards or throws deep touchdown passes. In the same way, a CPU that spends most of its time idling in low-power mode will not have as much impact on overall system performance as one that is constantly processing data.	cpu	Explain cpu using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 percentage of time during a game that a player is on the field
The CPU (central processing unit) is the "brain" of your computer. It handles all the calculations and determines what goes on inside your machine. A motherboard can be thought of as the "field" or "court" on which a sporting event takes place. It is the foundation upon which everything else is built and, as such, is critical to the success of the competition.	motherboard	Explain motherboard using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 the field or court on which a sporting event takes place
A motherboard can be best described as the athletic director of a sports team. Just as the athletic director is responsible for organizing and overseeing all aspects of the team, from scheduling games to hiring coaches, the motherboard is responsible for organizing and overseeing all aspects of the computer, from regulating power supplies to loading programs.	motherboard	Explain motherboard using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 athletic director of a sports team

A tree's age calculation can be compared to the score of a sports game. Just as a scoreboard keeps track of the score throughout the game, a tree records its growth by adding rings to its trunk each year. The size and width of each ring indicate how much growth has occurred in that particular year. So, just like counting up the points scored by both teams at the end of a game, scientists can count up the number of rings on a tree's trunk to determine its age.	tree's age calculation	Explain tree's age calculation using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 score of a sports game

That means the tree is about 30 feet tall now.	tree's age calculation	Explain tree's age calculation using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football player
The age calculation of a tree is similar to the number of years a sports player has been in the league. Just as a player's age increases by one each year, so does the growth rate of a tree. The diameter (or width) of a tree at breast height (4.5 feet from the ground) is used to determine its age because it is representative of the larger part of the trunk.	tree's age calculation	Explain tree's age calculation using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 number of years a sports player has been in the league
Athletes need energy to perform. This energy comes from the food they eat. The food is broken down in the body into molecules that can be used for energy. One of these molecules is glucose, which provides energy for muscles. Glucose is converted into a molecule called pyruvate during glycolysis. Pyruvate is then transported to the mitochondria, where it is turned into adenosine triphosphate (ATP), which provides the energy athletes need to perform.	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 breaking down food into molecules that can be used for energy###| pyruvate | molecule produced during glycolysis###| mitochondria | organelle in the cell where pyruvate is turned into ATP###| adenosine tri
In sports, glycolysis is the process of breaking down glycogen into glucose in order to provide energy for muscles. This is similar to how glycolysis works in the body, where it breaks down glucose into energy that can be used by cells.	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 breaking down glycogen into glucose###| body | breaking down glucose into energy
Glycolysis can be explained using a sports analogy as the process of how athletes produce energy. During glycolysis, glucose is broken down to create adenosine triphosphate (ATP), which is the main source of energy for cells. This process occurs in the muscles and provides energy for running, jumping, and other physical activities.	glycolysis	Explain glycolysis using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 athletes producing energy
If an outfielder tries to catch a fly ball, and the ball is hit directly at him, he will probably catch it. If the ball is hit high in the air, however, he may have trouble catching it because of gravity. The higher the ball is hit, the more time gravity has to pull it down. In both cases, though, if the outfielder jumps up to try to catch the ball he will be able to reach farther and catch it more easily.This analogy can be used to explain anti-stokes scattering. When light or any other type of energy is traveling in one direction (for example, toward a detector), atoms in its path can scatter it away from that direction (just like how an outfielder can scatter a fly ball). This scattered light travels in all directions perpendicular to its original path (just like how a fly ball scatters when it's hit by a bat). The further away from the original direction the light gets scattered, the more slowly it moves (just like how a fly ball slows down as it goes further away from where it was originally hit).	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 an outfielder trying to catch a fly ball
Anti-stokes scattering is like the bouncer at a club. He's there to keep everyone in line and make sure that no one gets too crazy. In the same way, anti-stokes scattering helps to prevent photons from bouncing around inside of a molecule too much and causing chaos.	anti-stokes scattering	Explain anti-stokes scattering using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 bouncer at a club
A soccer ball is kicked into the air. As it rises, the air resistance (friction) caused by the molecules in the air pushes back on the ball. This force causes the ball to slow down and eventually fall to the ground. The same thing happens when light travels through a material like air. The light particles (photons) hit atoms and molecules in the material and are slowed down by their interaction with those atoms/molecules.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 soccer ball kicked into the air###| light travelling through a material | light travelling through a material
Stokes scattering is a process that helps to explain why the sky is blue. In general, it occurs when light waves scatter off of small particles in the atmosphere. This happens because the blue end of the visible spectrum is scattered more than other colors due to its short wavelength. You can think about it like this: imagine you are playing basketball and someone throws a ball at you from across the court. If you are quick enough, you will be able to catch the ball before it bounces off of the ground. However, if the ball is thrown too high or too far away, it will bounce off of the ground before reaching you. This same principle applies to light waves; shorter wavelengths are scattered more easily than longer ones.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 throwing a ball at someone
Stokes scattering is the diffusion of light by particles in a medium. It can be described as the way that sunlight scatters off individual raindrops or snowflakes. In analogy to sports, imagine yourself trying to see someone who is far away on a sunny day. The sun creates bright spots all around them and it is difficult to see them clearly. However, if it starts raining, the rain will diffuse the light and you will be able to see them more clearly.	stokes scattering	Explain stokes scattering using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 diffusion of light
The median lethal dose can be thought of as the "point at which 50% of the population will die." In other words, it's the dose that kills half of those exposed to it. To put this in sports terms, imagine a football field with 100 players on it. If you were to give half of them a very low dose of something (say 1/10th of a lethal dose), then only 5 players would die. On the other hand, if you gave everyone a high dose (say 10 times the lethal dose), then 50 players would die. The median lethal dose is equivalent to giving 5 players a medium-sizeddose (say 2 times the lethal dose).	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 the "point at which 50% of the population will die"
The median lethal dose is akin to the "point of no return" in a sporting event. It is the point at which an athlete has expended so much energy that they can no longer continue and will likely lose the match or game. In terms of poison, it is the dosage at which 50% of those exposed will die.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 point of no return in a sporting event
The median lethal dose is the amount of a substance that will kill 50% of those exposed to it. This can be thought of as the equivalent of two evenly matched teams in a sporting event. If one team has more players than the other, then the larger team will win (i.e., survive) more often. Similarly, if one group is exposed to a higher concentration of a toxin, they will be more likely to die than if they were exposed to a lower concentration.	median lethal dose	Explain median lethal dose using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 two evenly matched teams in a sporting event

Enzyme mechanisms can be compared to athletes in a race. The athletes are all running at the same speed, but some of them are taller and have longer legs. This means that they cover more ground with each stride than the shorter runners. The taller runners dont have to work as hard as the shorter runners to keep up with the pace, because they can take longer strides. Enzymes work in a similar way; they all catalyze reactions at the same rate, but some enzymes can catalyze reactions using smaller molecules than others. This means that they dont have to work as hard to find their substrate and start the reaction, because there is more room for it on the enzyme surface.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 athletes in a race
Enzyme mechanisms can be compared to athletes in a race. Enzymes are like the sprinters, who run very quickly for a short time. The substrate is like the runner's starting block, and the product is the finish line. The enzyme catalyzes the reaction by attaching to the substrate and then kicking off of it, pushing it along until it reaches the product.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 athlete in a race
When an athlete competes in a race, the muscles need energy to function. This energy is supplied by the breakdown of glycogen (a sugar) into glucose, which is used by the muscles for fuel. The same process happens when cells in the body need energy: glycogen is broken down into glucose and then used as fuel. This process is catalyzed by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase.In order for glycogen phosphorylase to work, it needs a molecule called phosphate. The phosphate molecule attaches to the glycogen molecule, breaking it down into glucose molecules. Phosphate is provided by another enzyme called Phosphofructokinase.	enzyme mechanism	Explain enzyme mechanism using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 athlete competing in a race
Suppose there are two teams, Team A and Team B. Each team has its own fans. The goal of the game is to see which team can score more points. There are three ways to score points: touchdowns (6 points), field goals (3 points), and safeties (2 points).The first thing we need to do is figure out how many points each team scored in total. To do this, we add up all the touchdowns, field goals, and safeties that each team scored. Team A scored 18 points and Team B scored 14 points.Now we can use anova to see if there is a difference between the two teams' scores. anova compares the variance of the data from each group (Team A and Team B) and finds out if it's statistically significant. In this case, it is because the p-value is less than 0.05. This means that there is a 5% chance that these results happened by chance and that there is actually a difference between the two teams' scores.	anova	Explain anova using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 comparing the variance of the data from each group
If you are a fan of a certain sports team, and somebody asks who your favorite player is, you might respond with I dont have just one favorite player; I like the whole team. This is similar to what an anova does in statistics. An anova compares all of the possible players (in this case, all of the sports teams) to see which one performs best.	anova	Explain anova using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 comparing all of the possible players
In a sports analogy, anova can be thought of as the process by which teams are divided into divisions and then ranked within those divisions. The first step in anova is to divide all of the teams into separate groups (or "divisions"). After the teams have been divided, the next step is to rank each team within its division. Finally, once all of the rankings have been determined, the overall ranking of all of the teams can be computed.	anova	Explain anova using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 dividing teams into divisions and ranking them within those divisions

Chemical equilibrium is the state in which two opposing processes occur at the same rate so that the net result is no change in concentration over time. In sports, this would be like when a football team has an equal number of players on each side of the field. Over time, there will be no change in how many players are on either side of the field.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football team with an equal number of players on each side of the field
Chemical equilibrium is like a balancing act in sports. Just as a gymnast must keep her balance while performing on the balance beam, a chemist must keep her chemicals in equilibrium. If one chemical starts to move out of balance, the chemist must make an adjustment (like adding more of the other chemical) to restore equilibrium.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 balancing act in sports
Chemical equilibrium is like a sports game in which two teams are evenly matched. The game continues until one team makes a move that gives it an advantage over the other team. At this point, the game is no longer balanced and one side begins to dominate. In chemical equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions are balanced so that there is no net change in the amount of the reactants or products. However, if a reaction is pushed to favor one side (for example by adding more of a reactant), then the equilibrium will shift to favor that side.	chemical equilibrium	Explain chemical equilibrium using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 a sports game in which two teams are evenly matched
A basketball coach may call a time-out with her team down by 5 points in the last minute of the game. She uses the time-out to instruct her players on how she wants them to play offense and defense for the remainder of the game. The coaching staff likely has a plan that is designed to give their team the best chance to win, but it is not put into action until they are actually in need of it. This same principle can be applied to manufacturing. In order for a company to produce goods only when they are needed, they must have a good understanding of what their customers needs will be at any given moment in time.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 basketball coach calling a time-out
A basketball coach might use the just-in-time strategy to provide his players with only the information they need at a particular moment in the game. For instance, if the opposing team is about to take a shot, the coach might tell his defenders to focus on guarding the player with the ball and not worry about their opponents who are standing far away from the hoop. This way, his players are using their energy efficiently and focusing on what is important right now.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 basketball coach######A chef might use the just-in-time strategy to prepare food for a dinner party. For instance, the chef might cook the main course a few hours before the party starts, and then prepare the side dishes just before the
Just-in-time is a business strategy that strives to improve efficiency by reducing the time between when goods are ordered and when they are received. In sports, this would be analogous to receiving new players just before a game instead of beforehand. This would allow the team to better prepare for their opponent while using the best players available.	just-in-time	Explain just-in-time using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 receiving new players just before a game

The body's immune system is constantly adapting, learning from past experiences and preparing for future challenges. This allows the immune system to respond more effectively to new infections and diseases. Like a well-trained athlete, the adaptive immune system gets stronger and better prepared each time it faces a challenge.	adaptive immunity	Explain adaptive immunity using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 athlete's ability to improve performance over time

Assume that a sports team has an ohm of resistance. This means that when the team tries to move forward, it meets some opposition (resistance) from the other team. If you double the number of players on your team, then you will be able to push twice as hard and get further ahead. In electrical terms, this means that if you increase the current (number of players), then the voltage (pressure) will also increase proportionally.	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 sports team with an ohm of resistance###| doubling the number of players on your team | increasing the current
In a game of football, the players on the offense try to advance the ball downfield by running with it or throwing it to another player. The farther they get from the starting line (the "zero"), the more points they score. In a similar way, electricity flows in a circuit through devices that are connected in series, with each device getting progressively harder to push current through as you move further away from the battery. This is analogous to how an offensive team gets increasingly difficult to move the ball downfield as they get further away from their end zone. We can measure this using Ohm's law, which states that voltage (the "push" of electricity) is equal to resistance (how hard something is to push current through) multiplied by current (the amount of electricity flowing).	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football analogy
A football analogy for ohm's law would be that the resistor is like the players on the field. The voltage is like the amount of force or power being exerted by the offense (coach), and the current is like how many players are running downfield at any given time. The resistance is like how easy or hard it is for the players to move (the playing surface).	ohm's law	Explain ohm's law using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 football analogy

Water resistance is created by the hydrophobic effect, which is a force that resists the penetration of water into and through materials. This analogy can be used to explain how this works in relation to sports. Imagine if you were running in waist-deep water. The water would flow into your shoes and make it difficult for you to move forward. However, if you ran on land, the surface beneath your feet would help push you forward as you ran.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 water resistance in sports
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in aqueous solutions. This can be best explained using a sports analogy. Suppose you have two teams, one composed of polar molecules (such as water) and the other made up of nonpolar molecules (such as oil). The football field represents a container filled with water. When both teams are on the field, they are evenly dispersed since like charges repel each other. However, when the nonpolar team starts to play offense and move towards the goal post, they begin to cluster together since they are repelled by the polar water players. In a similar manner, nonpolar molecules tend to group together in solutions due to their mutual attraction. This clustering creates large areas of empty space around them which results in an overall decrease in solution density	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 clustering of nonpolar molecules
If you have ever played a sport where a ball is being thrown to you, you will know that it is easier to catch the ball when it is wet. This is because the water on the surface of the ball creates a lubricant which reduces the friction between the ball and your hand. The hydrophobic effect works in a similar way; by reducing the surface tension of water molecules, it becomes easier for other non-polar molecules to dissolve in them.	hydrophobic effect	Explain hydrophobic effect using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 reducing surface tension of water molecules
A basketball team is trying to score a point. They have the ball and they are trying to get it into the hoop. The hoop is the goal and the ball is the signal. The player with the ball is trying to get close enough to the hoop so that they can make a shot. Once they are close enough, they will shoot the ball towards the hoop. This is analogous to how a biological signal travels from its origin to its target. The origin of the signal is like the player with the basketball, and the target of the signal is like the hoop. The path that the signal takes between these two points is known as transmission or propagation.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 basketball team trying to score a point
Athletes use a variety of signals to communicate with one another during a game. These signals can be verbal or nonverbal, and they can include things like hand gestures, facial expressions, and body language. The purpose of these signals is to relay information between players so that they can work together as a team.In the same way, cells use biological signals to communicate with one another. These signals allow cells to coordinate their activities and respond to changes in their environment. Just as athletes need clear communication in order to achieve success, cells need accurate signal transduction in order to carry out their functions properly.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 communication between athletes
One can think of biological signal transduction as a series of relay races. In the first race, the runner (the signal) starts at one end of the track and sprints towards the finish line. At various points along the track, other runners (the enzymes) are waiting to take over and continue running with the signal. When they reach the finish line, they hand off the baton (the signal molecule) to still more runners who carry it across the finish line. This analogy can be used to explain how hormones work in our bodies: The hormone is like a runner starting at one end of the track, and all of the receptors for that hormone are like different runners waiting along the way to take over and carry it forward.	biological signal transduction	Explain biological signal transduction using a sports analogy.	ht	sport	 relay races

When the car doesn't need energy, the gas tank is empty. Glycogen is like this in the body. It is a storage place for energy. When the body needs energy, glycogen is filled with glucose and the body can run. When the body doesn't need energy, glycogen is empty.	glycogen	Explain glycogen using an analogy. A capacitor is a bit like a tennis ball. You can squish the tennis ball by pressing down on it with your hand. The more you press, the more compressed the tennis ball becomes. Now if you release your hand, the tennis ball will spring back to its original size because of all of the energy that was stored in it while it was being compressed. A capacitor works in a similar way. If you apply voltage to it, it will store electrical energy just like the compressed tennis ball stores kinetic energy. And when you remove the voltage, the capacitor will release that energy just like the tennis ball will release its kinetic energy when you let go of it.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a compressed tennis ball
Capacitance is the ability of an object to store energy in an electric field. An analogy for capacitance would be a tennis ball. When you hit a tennis ball, it stores potential energy as it moves away from you. The faster you hit the ball, the more potential energy it will have. Once the ball hits the ground, that potential energy is released and causes the ball to bounce up into the air again. A capacitor works in much the same way. The capacitor has two metal plates separated by a thin layer of insulation. When you apply voltage to the capacitor, it creates an electric field between the plates. This electric field stores energy just like Potential Energy does in a tennis ball	capacitance	Explain capacitance using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a tennis ball
The capacitance of a capacitor is like the ability of a goalkeeper to block shots. Just as the goalkeeper can block more or fewer shots by changing the position of their body, the capacitor can block more or fewer current charges by changing the size of its plates.	capacitance	Explain capacitance using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the ability of a goalkeeper to block shots
Electric current is like the flow of water in a river. Just as the amount of water in a river can vary, so can the electric current in an electronic device. The rate at which the water flows (the current) is measured in gallons per minute (GPM).	electric current	Explain electric current using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 flow of water in a river
Electric current is like a flow of water in a river. The higher the voltage (pressure), the faster the water flows. Just like electricity, water can be used to do work such as turning turbines and moving boats.	electric current	Explain electric current using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 water in a river###| voltage | pressure
Electric current is like a flow of water. Just as water flows downhill and can be directed by man-made channels, electric current flows through wires that are specially designed to carry it. The direction of the electric current can be controlled by switches just as the direction of water flow can be controlled by valves.	electric current	Explain electric current using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 water flow
Imagine that you are a batter in a baseball game. The pitcher throws the ball towards you, and as it gets closer to you, it starts to speed up. At the same time, the catcher behind you also begins to move towards you at high speed. If the catcher reaches you first, they will catch the ball and stop its forward momentum; this is analogous to voltage stopping electron flow. However, if you hit the ball hard enough before the catcher reaches you, then it will travel further than if there was no catcher - this is analogous to current (amperage) being greater with more voltage applied.	voltage	Explain voltage using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 catcher in baseball analogy###| electron flow | baseball###| current (amperage) | baseball

The players on the field represent electricity flowing through wires, and when they run into each other (or touch something else), it creates sparks or electricity. Just like in real life, the more people there are in attendance at a game, the higher the voltage will be.	voltage	Explain voltage using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 people in attendance at a football game
A voltage can be thought of as the pressure or power behind a moving object, such as a ball in sports. Just like in sports, where more powerful players and teams tend to win, a higher voltage gives an electronic device more "power" or strength to do what it needs to do.	voltage	Explain voltage using an analogy. The analogy should be suitable for student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 power behind a moving object
