The activator protein ensures that all of the players are following the rules of the game and that everyone is playing fair.	activator protein	What is a good analogy to explain activator protein to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 referee
Electricity is like a current of water. Just as a river or stream flowing downhill will always find the path of least resistance, an electric current will always take the easiest route to ground. This is why we use copper wires in our electrical circuits - they have low resistance and allow electrons to flow freely.	electric circuit	What is a good analogy to explain electric circuit to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 a river or stream
Electricity is like the flow of water in a hose. Just as water flows through a hose when you turn on the faucet, electricity flows through wires when you turn on a light switch. The amount of electricity that flows through a wire is measured in amperes (amps). Just as you can change the strength of the water flow by changing the faucet, you can change the strength of electric current by changing the voltage.	electric circuit	What is a good analogy to explain electric circuit to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 water hose
A good analogy to explain electric circuits to a student who likes sports is by comparing the flow of electricity through a circuit to the flow of water through a pipe. Just as water can be forced through a pipe by applying pressure at one end, electricity can be forced through a circuit by applying pressure (voltage) at one end. The amount of current that flows through a circuit is analogous to the amount of water that flows through a pipe - it is determined by the amount of pressure applied and the size of the opening (or resistance).	electric circuit	What is a good analogy to explain electric circuit to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 water pipe
A good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to a student who likes sports is if you think about when you are playing a sport and you get sweaty. The sweat beads up on your skin because the water is attracted to the salt in your sweat. But, the grease or oil from the food that you ate earlier is not attracted to the water, so it stays on top of the sweat. This is because grease and oil are hydrophobic, which means they do not like water.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 when you are playing a sport and you get sweaty
Water molecules are constantly moving and bumping into each other. This movement is slowed down when they enter a hydrophobic environment. Think of it like two football players trying to run through a crowd of people  the more people there are, the slower they will move. The same thing happens with water molecules and hydrophobic environments  the more there are, the slower they will move.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 football players trying to run through a crowd of people
A good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to a student who likes sports is that of two magnets. When you place two magnets together, their poles will attract one another. This is because the negative pole on each magnet attracts the positive pole on the other magnet. In a similar way, water molecules are attracted to one another due to their positive and negative poles. However, when you place a hydrophobic molecule near water, it will be repelled by the water's polarity.	hydrophobic effect	What is a good analogy to explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 two magnets
One way to think about signal transduction is by analogy to a sports game. In a football game, the quarterback calls a play and sends instructions to the rest of the team. The players on the field then carry out those instructions, running, passing, and tackling as directed. In much the same way, cells use signals to communicate with one another and carry out their functions. The signals are like the quarterback's call, telling each cell what to do. The receptors on the cell membrane are like the receivers on the football field who hear the quarterback's call and pass it along to the players. And finally, the proteins inside of cells that respond to signals are like the players who carry out those instructions	biological signal transduction	What is a good analogy to explain biological signal transduction to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 a football game
When athletes compete in sports, they often send and receive signals to each other. This happens when one athlete does something, like make a move on the basketball court, and another athlete reacts to it. The first athlete's action is the signal, and the second athlete's reaction is the response.In biology, cells also send and receive signals to each other. This happens when one cell does something, like produce a hormone, and another cell reacts to it. The first cell's action is the signal, and the second cell's reaction is the response.	biological signal transduction	What is a good analogy to explain biological signal transduction to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 athletes sending and receiving signals to each other
A good analogy to explain biological signal transduction would be a football game. The players are the cells and the ball is the signal. When one player (cell) tackles another, they both push each other away with force. This is similar to how proteins in a cell react to signals, by pushing them away or turning them on/off.	biological signal transduction	What is a good analogy to explain biological signal transduction to student who likes sports?	ht	sport	 football game

Lysosomes are like the "garbage cans" of the cell. They are small sacs that contain enzymes that break down proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids. This process is called "lysosomal degradation" and it helps to recycle these molecules back into the cell. Lysosomes also help to get rid of damaged or old cells.	lysosome	Using an analogy, explain lysosome to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 "garbage can" of the cell###| lysosomal degradation | breaking down proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids

Kirchoff's voltage law states that the sum of the voltages around a closed loop is zero. This law is similar to the law of conservation of energy in that it states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only be transferred. In the context of sports, this law would mean that the total energy of the system (the players, the ball, and the field) is constant.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 law of conservation of energy

The rate-determining step of a reaction is the step that determines how fast the reaction will occur. This step is usually the slowest step in the reaction. For example, in a race, the rate-determining step is the step that determines how fast the runners will finish the race. The slowest runner will determine the overall race time.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 the slowest runner in a race

A transport vesicle is like a small, personal, transportation pod that helps to shuttle materials around the cell. This pod is especially useful for carrying materials between different parts of the cell, or for transporting them out of the cell. Just like there are different types of transportation vehicles for different types of terrain (e.g. cars for driving on roads, trains for travelling on tracks, boats for travelling on water), there are different types of transport vesicles that are suited for different tasks. For example, there are transport vesicles that are good for carrying proteins and other large molecules, and there are transport vesicles that are good for carrying small molecules like glucose.	transport vesicles	Using an analogy, explain transport vesicles to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 transportation pod

If one of the players starts to break the rules, the referees step in and stop them. Tumor suppressor genes do the same thing in the body. They make sure that the cells are behaving properly and that they are not growing out of control. If a cell starts to grow too quickly or behaves in a way that is not normal, the tumor suppressor genes stop it.	tumor suppressor genes	Using an analogy, explain tumor suppressor genes to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 referees in a sports game

However, when they come together as a team, their strengths complement each other and they are able to achieve more than they could as individuals. The players on the team will follow the instructions in the playbook and do their best to score a touchdown. DNA replication is a bit like that. The DNA has a set of instructions (the playbook) and the cells will select a sequence of DNA and replicate it. The game begins when the player dribbles the ball down the court. The referee calls a foul if the player jumps into the air and dunks the ball. The referee also calls a foul if the player pushes another player. The game ends when the player scores a goal.	protein translation	Using an analogy, explain protein translation to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 basketball game

When an athlete makes a move on the playing field, this action doesn't happen instantaneously. It takes time for the action to travel from the athlete's brain to their muscles. This is similar to how an action potential travels down a neuron. The action potential starts at the neuron's cell body and travels down the axon to the synapse. From there, the action potential travels across the synapse to the next neuron.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 propagation of an action potential down a neuron
Breathing is like the process of filling up and emptying a balloon. When you inhale, your lungs fill up with air like the balloon. The air travels down your windpipe and into your lungs. A layered architecture for a sports team would be similar to the way a football team is organized. A limiting reactant is like a player on a sports team who is not getting enough playing time. This player may be very talented, but because there are others who are playing more, the player is not able to show his or her talent. An excess reactant is like a player on a sports team who is getting too much playing time. This player may not be very talented, but because he or she is playing more than the others, the player is able to show his or her talent.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 player on a sports team

When a tennis ball is hit, it scatters in all directions. This is called Stoke's scattering. When the ball is hit again, it scatters in a new direction. This is called anti-Stokes scattering.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 when the ball is hit again, it scatters in a new direction

The median lethal dose is the dose of a drug that is lethal to 50% of the population. In other words, it is the dose that kills half of the people who take it. Chemical equilibrium is like a game of tug-of-war. In this analogy, the two teams are the reactants and the products. The rope is the chemical equilibrium. The reactants are pulling on the rope with all their might, while the products are pushing back just as hard. In the end, the two teams are evenly matched, and the rope doesn't move. This is what happens in a chemical reaction. The reactants and products are in equilibrium, and the reaction doesn't progress any further.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes sports.	lt	sport	 game of tug-of-war

An orbital can be thought of as the path that an electron takes around the nucleus. The hydrogen atom has one electron and it occupies the first orbit. This orbit is like a track around a stadium. Just as different players can be in different places on a playing field at any given time, electrons can be in different places within their orbitals at any given time.	hydrogen electron's orbital	Using an analogy, explain hydrogen electron's orbital to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a sports team's playing field###| electron | a player on the sports team
Orbitals are like the different sections of a stadium. The higher up in the stands you sit, the further away you are from the field. Electrons orbit around the nucleus just like spectators sitting in the stands. The closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more energy it has. Just like someone who is close to the field has a better view than someone who is far away, electrons that are close to the nucleus have more energy and can interact more with other atoms.	hydrogen electron's orbital	Using an analogy, explain hydrogen electron's orbital to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a spectator in a stadium
A first line of defense in the body is similar to a team of defensive players in football. The players are positioned in front of the goal (the end zone) and their job is to stop the opposing team from scoring. Similarly, the first line of defense in the body consists of a group of cells and tissues that work together to protect us from infection and disease. Their job is to prevent bacteria and other foreign invaders from entering our bodies and causing harm.	first line of defense in the body	Using an analogy, explain first line of defense in the body to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 team of defensive players in football
The first line of defense in the body is similar to a team of football players. The players are lined up on the front line, ready to tackle the opposing player and stop them from advancing. Similarly, the first line of defense in the body is made up of cells that are specialized for fighting off infection and protecting against disease. These cells work together to identify and destroy any invaders that attempt to enter the body.	first line of defense in the body	Using an analogy, explain first line of defense in the body to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 team of football players
The first line of defense in the body is similar to a team of players in sports. The players work together to protect the goal and keep the other team from scoring. Similarly, the first line of defense in the body protects against infection and disease by working together to keep germs out.	first line of defense in the body	Using an analogy, explain first line of defense in the body to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 team of players in sports
One way to think about macrophages is as the "team doctors" of the immune system. They're responsible for identifying and attacking any bacteria, viruses, or other invaders that might be causing harm. Like a good team doctor, they're also quick to help injured cells get back on their feet.	macrophages	Using an analogy, explain macrophages to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 team doctors of the immune system
Macrophages are like the "police force" of the body. They patrol and keep track of what is happening in all different parts of the body, looking for anything that might be abnormal or dangerous. When they find something, they take action to get rid of it.	macrophages	Using an analogy, explain macrophages to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the "police force" of the body

The quarterback doesn't necessarily do all of the work himself, but he coordinates and directs the other players so that they can work together to achieve their goal.	t-helper cells	Using an analogy, explain t-helper cells to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 quarterbacks on football teams

Cytotoxic t-lymphocytes can be thought of as the "defense" players on a sports team. Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes are like the "team captain" of the immune system. They help to direct other immune cells, such as B-cells and macrophages, to destroy infected or cancerous cells. Like a good team captain, cytotoxic T-lymphocytes are very effective at their job and can quickly eliminate diseased cells from the body.	cytotoxic t-lymphocytes	Using an analogy, explain cytotoxic t-lymphocytes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 team captain of the immune system###| B-cells | other immune cells###| macrophages | other immune cells

They are responsible for attacking and destroying any cells that are not supposed to be in the body.	cytotoxic t-lymphocytes	Using an analogy, explain cytotoxic t-lymphocytes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 defensive linemen on a football team
If someone wanted to describe the invasion of bacteria, they might use a sports analogy. Imagine that there are two teams playing against each other. The first team is made up of strong and fit players, while the second team is made up of small and weak players. The first team easily wins the game, as they are much stronger than their opponents. This is similar to how bacteria can invade an animal or human body - because they are much smaller and weaker than the cells in our bodies, they can easily overcome them and cause infection.	invasion of bacterias	Using an analogy, explain invasion of bacterias to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 analogy of a sports game
If bacterial invasion is like a sports team invading another team's territory, the bacteria are using special tactics and strategies to overcome the defending forces and take over the area. The bacteria may produce toxins that kill or disable the cells of the host tissue, making it easier for them to multiply. They may also use enzymes to break down tissues so they can absorb nutrients from them.	invasion of bacterias	Using an analogy, explain invasion of bacterias to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports team invading another team's territory
A bacteria invasion is very similar to a sports team invading another team's territory. The bacteria invade and take over the cells of the host organism, using them for their own purposes. Like a sports team, the bacteria use energy and resources from the invaded cells to grow and spread.	invasion of bacterias	Using an analogy, explain invasion of bacterias to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports team invading another team's territory
When you watch a sports game on TV, the athletes are constantly moving. This is because they are reacting to what's going on around them. The athlete's movements are controlled by electrical signals that start in their brain and travel down their spinal cord to their muscles. These signals tell the muscles when and how to move, allowing the athlete to react quickly to what's happening on the field.The same thing happens inside your body when you're walking or running. Your brain sends electrical signals down your spinal cord telling your muscles when and how to move. These signals allow you to react quickly and smoothly to the changing environment around you.	action potential	Using an analogy, explain action potential to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 electrical signals that start in the brain and travel down the spinal cord
Action potential can be thought of as an "electrical signal" that travels down the neuron. This electrical signal is much like a wave that starts at one end of the neuron and moves down to the other end. The "high point" of this wave is called the action potential, and it's what causes the neuron to fire (or send a message).	action potential	Using an analogy, explain action potential to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 electrical signal that travels down the neuron###| high point | action potential
When a sports fan watches their favorite team, they get really excited and their heart starts beating faster. This is because the brain sends signals to the heart telling it to beat faster. The same thing happens when someone sees or hears something that excites them. The brain sends out action potentials (signals) that travel down nerves until they reach muscles, causing them to contract.	action potential	Using an analogy, explain action potential to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 signals that travel down nerves###| heart | muscles
Chromatography can be thought of as a way to separate the various chemicals in a sports drink by their different weights. Just like athletes competing in different events according to their weight, the various chemicals in the sports drink are separated according to how heavy they are. The lighter molecules travel faster than the heavier ones and end up at the top of the glass jar, while the heaviest molecules stay at the bottom.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 athletes competing in different events according to their weight
Chromatography is like when two basketball teams play each other. The players on the court are the molecules and the fans in the stands are the solvent. During a game, different players might cross the half-court line at different speeds. This is analogous to how molecules move differently through a solvent during chromatography. Some players might stay near one side of the court, while others quickly cross to the other side. Just as basketball teams have their own individual strategies, so do molecules undergo unique behaviors during chromatography due to their chemical makeup	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 basketball game
One could think of chromatography as a way to "separate" the various compounds that are in a given substance. For example, if you have a vial of sports drink, and you want to analyze the contents to see how much sugar, caffeine, and other compounds are present, chromatography can help you do that. You would start by putting some of the sports drink on a strip of paper (the "stationary phase"), then spraying or dipping it into a solvent (the "mobile phase"). The solvent will travel up the paper carrying with it any molecules that are soluble in it. As different molecules move at different speeds through the solvent, they will be separated out on the paper based on their size and polarity. So larger, more polar molecules (like sugars) will move slower than smaller, less polar molecules (like caffeine). By looking at which bands are present on the strip of paper after separation has occurred, you can get an idea of how much each compound is present in the original sample.	experiment of chromatography	Using an analogy, explain experiment of chromatography to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 separating the various compounds that are in a given substance
Stars are like sports players. As they use up their energy, they "retire" from the main sequence and become white dwarfs, neutron stars, or black holes.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using an analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports players' careers
Stars are similar to athletes in that they have a limited lifetime. The main sequence lifetime of a star is the amount of time it spends burning hydrogen in its core. This process lasts for billions of years, but eventually the star will run out of fuel and die.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using an analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the amount of time an athlete spends competing######The main sequence lifetime of a star is the amount of time it spends burning hydrogen in its core. This process lasts for billions of years, but eventually the star will run out of fuel and die.
Stars are like athletes in that they have a certain amount of energy that they can use before they "die." Young stars, like rookie athletes, have a lot of energy and can last for a long time. Middle-aged stars, like veteran athletes, still have some energy but not as much as young stars. Old stars, like retired athletes, don't have much energy left and will die relatively soon.	main-sequence lifetimes of stars	Using an analogy, explain main-sequence lifetimes of stars to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the length of an athlete's career
In sports, the nucleus is the most important part of the team. It is made up of the best players and they are responsible for leading the team to victory. The nucleus determines how successful a team will be. In much the same way, the nucleus of an atom is made up of its most important particles and it determines how successful that atom will be.	nucleus	Using an analogy, explain nucleus to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 most important part of a team###| atom | most important part of an atom
Nucleus is the most important part of an atom. Just like a quarterback is the most important player on a football team, the nucleus is the most important part of an atom. The nucleus contains protons and neutrons which control how atoms behave.	nucleus	Using an analogy, explain nucleus to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 quarterback
Nucleus is like the quarterback of a football team. He directs and oversees all the other players on the field. Similarly, the nucleus controls everything that goes on in a cell.	nucleus	Using an analogy, explain nucleus to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 quarterback of a football team
Ribosomes can be thought of as the "team" that assembles proteins. The instructions for assembling a protein are written out on a "recipe" or gene, and this information is then read by the ribosomes who put together the correct sequence of amino acids to create the desired protein.	ribosomes	Using an analogy, explain ribosomes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 team that assembles proteins###| recipe | gene
Ribosomes can be thought of as the "production line" of a factory. The DNA in the nucleus is like the blueprint for making a product. The ribosomes take this blueprint and use it to create proteins, which are necessary for all cellular functions. Just as different machines are needed to manufacture different products in a factory, there are different types of ribosomes that are responsible for creating different proteins.	ribosomes	Using an analogy, explain ribosomes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the "production line" of a factory###| DNA in the nucleus | the blueprint for making a product###| ribosomes | responsible for creating different proteins
Ribosomes are to a cell what a quarterback is to a football team. They are the small, but important players that play a major role in getting the job done. Ribosomes are responsible for reading instructions from messenger RNA (mRNA) and assembling proteins accordingly. Just like how a good quarterback can make all the difference in winning or losing a game, ribosomes play an essential role in protein synthesis and ensuring that cells function properly.	ribosomes	Using an analogy, explain ribosomes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 quarterbacks

These proteins then exit the cell via vesicles.	golgi apparatus	Using an analogy, explain golgi apparatus to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 "filing cabinet" for a cell###| endoplasmic reticulum | producer of proteins###| vesicles | exit point for proteins
Lysosomes are like the "trash cans" of a cell. They are filled with enzymes that can break down proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids. This allows them to recycle these molecules back into useful materials for the cell.	lysosomes	Using an analogy, explain lysosomes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the "trash cans" of a cell
Lysosomes are like the "garbage collectors" of a cell. They break down proteins and other molecules that are no longer needed, and recycle their components. This helps keep the cell healthy and functioning properly. Lysosomes can be thought of as similar to a sports arena's janitorial staff - they clean up after the game is over, so everything is ready for the next event.	lysosomes	Using an analogy, explain lysosomes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 janitorial staff in a sports arena
Lysosomes are like the "garbage collectors" of a cell. They break down and recycle old or damaged proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids. This helps keep the cell healthy and functioning properly. Lysosomes are often compared to little recycling trucks that go around picking up garbage!	lysosomes	Using an analogy, explain lysosomes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 little recycling trucks

A vacuole is kind of like a locker room for the cells in your body. Just as athletes need a place to store their gear and change into their uniforms, cells need a place to store their extra cargo and change into new cell types. The vacuoles do this by expanding or shrinking to accommodate the needs of the cells around them.	vacuoles	Using an analogy, explain vacuoles to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 locker room for the cells in your body

It's also a place where important cellular processes take place.	vacuoles	Using an analogy, explain vacuoles to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports stadiums

A vesicle can be thought of as a small compartment in the cell. This compartment can hold different molecules that help the cell to function. For example, proteins that are important for the cell's survival or signaling molecules may be stored inside vesicles. Vesicles can also help to regulate the exchange of materials between cells and their environment.	vesicles	Using an analogy, explain vesicles to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 small compartments in the cell
A cell wall is a bit like the concrete surrounding a sports stadium. It provides support and protects the cells inside.	cell wall	Using an analogy, explain cell wall to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 concrete surrounding a sports stadium
The cell wall can be thought of as the boundary or outer limit of a cell. It is a tough, flexible layer that protects the cells and helps keep them in shape. The cell wall is made up of peptidoglycan (a type of carbohydrate) and proteins, and it varies in thickness depending on the type of cell. For example, red blood cells don't have a cell wall, while bacteria do.	cell wall	Using an analogy, explain cell wall to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 boundary or outer limit of a cell###| peptidoglycan | type of carbohydrate###| proteins |
Cell walls are like the fences in a sports stadium. They help to keep things organized and separate. In the case of cells, the cell wall helps to keep the cell's contents (including DNA) from leaking out.	cell wall	Using an analogy, explain cell wall to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 fence in a sports stadium
Cells can be compared to players on a sports team. Just as each player has a specific role in order for the team to be successful, cells also have specific roles within the body that are necessary for survival. Golgi body can be thought of as the "trainer" for a sports team. It helps to prepare and condition the players so they are ready for competition. It also oversees the production of proteins and other molecules that are necessary for effective play.	golgi body	Using an analogy, explain golgi body to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports team coach or manager

It also helps to ensure that the game goes as planned.	golgi body	Using an analogy, explain golgi body to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referee in a sports game
If capacitance is like a basketball team, then the electric field would be the players on the court. Just as the players need space to run around and play their game, the electric field needs space to exist (between the capacitor plates). The more players on the court, or in this case, electrons on one plate of a capacitor, the greater force they have to push against each other. This is why capacitors with more surface area (more electrodes) store more charge than those with less.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a basketball team###| electric field | players on the court
The capacitance of a capacitor is like the amount of water that can be held in a bucket. The more water that is poured into the bucket, the higher the water level rises. In the same way, the more electric charge that is put into a capacitor, the higher its voltage level becomes.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the amount of water that can be held in a bucket###| electric charge | the amount of water that is poured into the bucket
One way to think of capacitance is as a kind of "electricity storage tank." Just as a reservoir stores water for later use, a capacitor stores electric charge for later use. The bigger the capacitor, the more charge it can store.	capacitance	Using an analogy, explain capacitance to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a reservoir
Electric current is like the flow of athletes in a stadium. Just as athletes move around and flow through the stadium, electric current moves through wires.	electric current	Using an analogy, explain electric current to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 athletes in a stadium
Electric current is similar to a soccer ball. Just as the soccer ball needs energy (from the person kicking it) in order to move forward, electric current needs energy (from the battery) in order to move through wires. Just like how different parts of the soccer field affect how the ball moves (for example, if its kicked near a wall, it will bounce back), electric currents are affected by different materials they travel through. For example, metal wires allow electricity to flow quickly and easily, while rubber or plastic insulation slows down the current.	electric current	Using an analogy, explain electric current to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a soccer ball###| battery | the person kicking the soccer ball
Electricity is a lot like sports. When you watch a game on TV, the pictures that you see are made up of lots of tiny dots called pixels. These pixels are switched on and off really quickly to create the image that you see on the screen. Electricity works in a very similar way - it's just made up of tiny particles called electrons instead of pixels! When an electron flows through a wire, it creates what we call an electric current.	electric current	Using an analogy, explain electric current to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 flow of electrons
The voltage of a battery or power supply is like the amount of pressure that is put on water to come out of a hose. Just like with water, more pressure (voltage) means more force (amperage) will be available to do work.	voltage	Using an analogy, explain voltage to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 pressure on water###| amperage | force
A good analogy for voltage would be to compare it to the score of a sports game. Just as the score changes as each play unfolds, voltage is constantly changing as electrons flow through a circuit. Voltage represents how hard someone is pushing (or pulling) on an electric current.	voltage	Using an analogy, explain voltage to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the score of a sports game
When two teams play a game of football, they create an electric field between them. This electric field is caused by the charges on the players and in the ball. The higher the voltage (the number of charges per unit area), the stronger this electric field will be.	voltage	Using an analogy, explain voltage to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the number of charges per unit area
A cell is like a sports team. The cells in our body work together to carry out the specialized functions that keep us alive. Cells communicate with one another by sending chemical signals, just as players on a sports team use hand signals to send messages to their teammates.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using an analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 players on a sports team using hand signals
In a sports team, there are many players who specialize in different positions. For example, some players may be good at catching the ball while others may be better at throwing it. But each player needs to communicate with the other players in order for the team to succeed. The catcher has to tell the pitcher when to throw the ball and where to aim it, and the outfielder needs to let the shortstop know when they're going to catch a fly ball.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using an analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 specialization and communication in a sports team
In a cell, specialization and communication are like the different players on a sports team. Each player has a specific job to do in order for the team to be successful. Players need to communicate with each other in order to know what their next move should be.	specialization and communication in a cell	Using an analogy, explain specialization and communication in a cell to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 players on a sports team
Kirchoff's Voltage Law states that the sum of all voltages in a closed loop must be zero. This law is similar to the concept of equilibrium in sports, where the total force on an object must be zero for it to remain stationary.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 equilibrium in sports
If someone is keeping track of the score in a game, they are following Kirchhoff's Voltage Law. The law states that the sum of all voltages in a closed loop must be zero. This means that no matter what path electricity takes through a circuit, the voltage at the end points will always add up to zero.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 following the score in a game
In order for a sports team to win, they need to score more points than the other team. In the same way, in an electrical circuit, the voltage (or potential difference) is what drives the current through the circuit. So in order for a circuit to work properly, it needs to have a higher voltage at one end than at the other.	kirchoff's voltage law	Using an analogy, explain kirchoff's voltage law to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports teams need to score more points than the other team###| current | voltage in an electrical circuit
A density wave is similar to a human wave at a sports game. Just as people move up and down in unison at a game, particles in a gas or liquid also move up and down together. The difference is that the movement of the particles is not caused by people standing up and sitting down, but instead by forces between the particles themselves.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 human wave at a sports game
A density wave is like a large crowd of people at a sporting event. The people are all packed together in one area, and then they slowly spread out as more and more people arrive. The same thing happens with density waves. They start off being very compact, but as time goes on they gradually become less dense.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 large crowd of people at a sporting event
A density wave is like a crowd of people at a sports game. The people are all packed together in one area, and then they slowly spread out until they are evenly spread throughout the stadium.	nature of a density wave	Using an analogy, explain nature of a density wave to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 people at a sports game
Enzymes are like the referees in a game of basketball. They ensure that the game is played fairly and that all of the players follow the rules. Enzymes also make sure that the game progresses smoothly, without any stoppages. In the same way, enzymes help to keep biochemical reactions running smoothly, ensuring that all of the molecules involved interact properly.	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referees in a game of basketball
Enzymes are like the referees of a sporting event. They make sure that everything goes smoothly and fairly. Enzymes help to keep things running smoothly in our bodies by helping chemical reactions occur.	enzymes	Using an analogy, explain enzymes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referees of a sporting event
Your brain is like a muscle. The more you use it, the stronger it gets. Active memory is like working out at the gym. You have to use your muscles regularly in order for them to stay strong and healthy. The same goes for your active memory system - if you don't use it, you'll lose it!	human active memory system	Using an analogy, explain human active memory system to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 muscle
Active memory can be thought of as an athletes working memory. Just as athletes need to keep track of a number of things simultaneously while they are performing, our active memory system allows us to store and process information at the same time. This is done by maintaining a small amount of information in our short-term memory (similar to a mental to do list) and constantly updating it as new information comes in. We can then use this information to make decisions and solve problems.	human active memory system	Using an analogy, explain human active memory system to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 athletes working memory
Your brain can be thought of as a muscle. Just like any other muscle in your body, the more you use it, the stronger it becomes. The same is true for your brain; the more you exercise your memory, the better it will perform. Active recall involves actively remembering information by retrieving and using it. This strengthens the neural pathways between neurons involved in memory formation and storage. As a result, recalling information becomes easier each time you do it.	human active memory system	Using an analogy, explain human active memory system to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 muscle analogy
The rate-determining step is the part of a reaction that determines how fast the reaction will happen. This is often the slowest step in a reaction, and so it can be difficult to speed up a reaction by changing this step. For example, in a race, the runners might be able to speed up by running faster, but they cannot make their opponents run slower.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the slowest step in a reaction
The rate-determining step is like the quarterback in a football game. The quarterback determines how fast the team can move down the field and score points. In the same way, the rate-determining step controls how quickly a reaction can take place.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 quarterback in a football game
In many chemical reactions, the rate-determining step is the slowest step. This means that the speed of the reaction depends on how quickly that particular step can occur. For example, imagine a football game where one team is trying to score a touchdown. The rate-determining step would be the player running down the field with the ball. If he moves slowly, then it will take longer for his team to score a touchdown. However, if he runs quickly down the field, then his team will score faster.	rate-determining step of a reaction	Using an analogy, explain rate-determining step of a reaction to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the player running down the field with the ball in a football game
Column chromatography can be thought of as a high-tech sporting event, where the objective is to move a small "object" (the compound being purified) through a long "track" as quickly and efficiently as possible. The track is filled with obstacles (known as stationary phase material), which the object must avoid if it wants to reach the finish line (the collection vessel). Like any good athlete, the object will use all of its energy and skills to make it to the end; in this case, that means using its own natural properties (e.g., polarity, size, shape) to interact with certain parts of the track more than others. The end result is a race between all of the different compounds in solution, each vying for supremacy on their particular section of the track.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a high-tech sporting event
Column chromatography can be thought of as a sports referee. The referee is responsible for making sure the game is played fairly and accurately. In the same way, column chromatography ensures that the separation of molecules in a sample occurs correctly and without bias.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports referee
Column chromatography is like when two basketball teams play each other. The players on one team try to get the ball to their teammate who is standing in a column (like in a column of scrimmage), and then that player tries to make a basket. If they miss, the other team gets possession of the ball.	column chromatography	Using an analogy, explain column chromatography to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 basketball
Chemical equilibrium is like a balance in sports. If one team starts to score more points, the other team has to work harder to catch up and maintain the balance. The same thing happens with chemical reactions. When one reaction starts to produce more products than the other reaction, the products of the first reaction begin to accumulate until both reactions reach equilibrium.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 balance in sports
Dynamic chemical equilibrium is like two opposing teams in a sports game. The teams are constantly competing against each other, but they are also working together. There is always a balance between the two teams and neither one can completely dominate the other. In the same way, there is a balance between the reactants and products in a chemical reaction. The reactants are always competing with each other to form products, but the products are also competing with each other to reform reactants. This keeps the reaction going until all of the reactants have been used up.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 two opposing teams in a sports game
The equilibrium between the offensive and defensive players on a football field is an example of dynamic chemical equilibrium. The offensive players (the reactants) are constantly trying to advance down the field, while the defensive players (the products) are trying to stop them. As long as there is no big upset (like a fumble or interception), the balance between offense and defense will stay relatively stable.	dynamic chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain dynamic chemical equilibrium to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 equilibrium between offensive and defensive players on a football field
A vacuole is like a large, empty space in the center of a basketball. It's not something that you can see or feel, but it's there and it affects how the ball behaves.	vacuole	Using an analogy, explain vacuole to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 large, empty space in the center of a basketball
A vacuole is a lot like a sports stadium. It's an enclosed space where something can happen. In the case of a vacuole, things happen inside the cell like proteins being made and other important cellular processes taking place.	vacuole	Using an analogy, explain vacuole to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports stadium
A vacuole is like a locker room for the cells in your body. It's a place where they can store things, like food or water, and get ready to do their job.	vacuole	Using an analogy, explain vacuole to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 locker room
One way to think about transport vesicles is to compare them to basketballs. Just as a basketball can be used to carry goods (e.g., water, sports equipment) from one part of a playing area to another, transport vesicles can be used to carry goods (e.g., proteins, lipids) within and between cells.	transport vesicles	Using an analogy, explain transport vesicles to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 basketballs
In sports, a vesicle would be like a basketball. It is round and filled with something that can help it move around quickly. In the body, transport vesicles carry nutrients and other important materials to different parts of the cell.	transport vesicles	Using an analogy, explain transport vesicles to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 basketballs
Imagine that you are a professional basketball player. In order to play in the game, you need to be physically present at the stadium. To get there, you have to take a series of steps: You first have to leave your house and walk or drive to the stadium. Once you're there, you go through security and then head into the locker room. Finally, you step out onto the court and start playing.Now imagine that instead of walking or driving yourself to the stadium, someone else does it for you. That's essentially what happens with transport vesicles: they shuttle proteins and other materials from one part of the cell to another.	transport vesicles	Using an analogy, explain transport vesicles to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 shuttle proteins and other materials from one part of the cell to another
A proto-oncogene is like a coach of a sports team. The coach helps to train and prepare the players for the game. If the coach is good, the players are likely to do well. However, if something happens to the coach (e.g., they get sick), then the team may not be as successful.	proto-oncogenes	Using an analogy, explain proto-oncogenes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 coaches of sports teams
Proto-oncogenes can be thought of as the "coach" of a cancer cell. They help to regulate how fast the cancer cells grow and divide, and they also help to keep the cells organized. When these genes become mutated, they can no longer properly control the growth of cancer cells, which can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and tumor formation.	proto-oncogenes	Using an analogy, explain proto-oncogenes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the "coach" of a cancer cell###| cancer cells | unregulated cell growth
A proto-oncogene would be like a professional basketball player. This person has the potential to become a great player, but they need the right environment and coaching in order to reach their full potential. If someone with proto-oncogenes doesn't get the support they need, their cancer cells may not develop into tumors.	proto-oncogenes	Using an analogy, explain proto-oncogenes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 professional basketball player
An oncogene can be thought of as a "super gene" that helps cancer cells grow and divide uncontrollably. This is similar to how athletes often have genes that give them an advantage in terms of strength, speed, or endurance.	oncogenes	Using an analogy, explain oncogenes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 "super genes"###| cancer cells | athletes
Think of oncogenes as the players on a sports team. They are the ones who make things happen and help the team win. In cancer, oncogenes can become mutated and start to work too well, causing tumors to form.	oncogenes	Using an analogy, explain oncogenes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 players on a sports team
Oncogenes are like the players on a sports team. They help the cell to grow and divide. Cancer can develop when these genes become damaged or mutated, causing the cells to keep dividing even when they shouldn't.	oncogenes	Using an analogy, explain oncogenes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 players on a sports team###| cancer | developing when oncogenes become damaged
If tumor suppressor genes are the referees of a game, they make sure that all the players are following the rules and that no one is getting too rough. They help to keep everything in check. Similarly, tumor suppressor genes help to keep cells from becoming cancerous by repairing any damage that may occur and stopping them from dividing too quickly.	tumor suppressor genes	Using an analogy, explain tumor suppressor genes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referees of a game
Tumor suppressor genes are like the referees of a sporting event. They make sure that everything is fair and no one gets an unfair advantage. In the same way, tumor suppressor genes keep cells from growing out of control and becoming tumors.	tumor suppressor genes	Using an analogy, explain tumor suppressor genes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referees in a sporting event
Tumor suppressor genes are like the referees in a football game. They make sure that the game is fair and that all the players are following the rules. If one of the players starts to cheat, the referee will step in and correct them. tumor suppressor genes do the same thing in our bodies; they make sure that cells are behaving properly and not becoming cancerous.	tumor suppressor genes	Using an analogy, explain tumor suppressor genes to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referees in a football game###| cells | players in a football game
If software is brittle, it means that it does not handle changes or errors very well. For example, imagine if you were playing a sport like basketball and the hoop broke off of the backboard. If the hoop was metal and strong, it would be able to withstand being hit by the ball. However, if the hoop was made out of thin plastic, it would break easily when hit by the ball. In this analogy, the metal hoop represents robust software while the plastic hoop represents brittle software.	brittle software	Using an analogy, explain brittle software to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 thin plastic hoop###| robust software | metal hoop
If you think of software as being like a football, it is strong and can take a lot of abuse. But if you think of software as being like a crystal vase, it is very brittle and can break easily.	brittle software	Using an analogy, explain brittle software to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a crystal vase
Brittle software can be compared to a brittle bone. Just as with bones, if the software is handled incorrectly or too much pressure is applied, it will snap. This means that the software is not very resilient and can easily break when pushed too hard or used in an incorrect way.	brittle software	Using an analogy, explain brittle software to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 brittle bone
A resonance hybrid is like a team of athletes who can each play different sports. Each athlete can run, jump, and throw the ball well. But when they come together as a team, they are even better than the sum of their individual parts. The same is true for molecules. When atoms bond together to form molecules, the electrons in those bonds can move around and interact with each other. This creates new energy levels that are not found in any of the individual atoms. These new energy levels are called resonances, and they make the molecule stronger and more stable than any of the atoms would be on their own.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 team of athletes
A resonance hybrid is like a basketball team. The players on the team (the orbitals) work together to score points and win the game.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 basketball team
When two opposing teams play each other in a sport, there is usually one player on each team who is very good at that particular sport. For example, one player may be able to throw the ball really well and another player may be able to catch the ball well. These players are said to have resonance with each other because their skills complement each other. In the same way, atoms can have resonance hybrid orbitals if they have similar energy levels.	resonance hybrid	Using an analogy, explain resonance hybrid to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 two opposing teams playing each other in a sport###| complementary skills | atoms with resonance hybrid orbitals
A wave mechanical model can be thought of as a sports game. In this analogy, the particles in a substance are the players on the field. The waves that pass through the substance are like the ball being passed back and forth between players. The faster the waves move, the more exciting (and energetic) the game becomes!	wave mechanical model	Using an analogy, explain wave mechanical model to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports game

Just as people in the crowd move up and down, forward and back as they cheer on their favorite team, so too do molecules move up and down, and back and forth as they vibrate.	wave mechanical model	Using an analogy, explain wave mechanical model to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 large sports crowd

The molecules in the gas or liquid are constantly moving around and creating these waves. The size of the wave depends on how much energy is put into it.	wave mechanical model	Using an analogy, explain wave mechanical model to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 waves created when a stone is thrown into a pond

RNA transcription is similar to a sports commentator talking about the game. The commentator takes information from what is happening on the field and relays it back to the audience in an easy-to-understand way. In the same way, RNA transcribes genetic information from DNA so that it can be used by cells.	rna transcription	Using an analogy, explain rna transcription to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports commentator talking about the game###| dna | genetic information

In the same way, rna transcription reads the genetic information in dna and relays it to other parts of the cell that need it.	rna transcription	Using an analogy, explain rna transcription to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports announcer reading the play-by-play of a game
Protein translation is similar to sports because proteins are like athletes and the ribosomes are like the coaches. The athletes need someone to tell them what to do and how to do it, and that is where the coaches come in. They give instructions to the athletes (proteins) on what they need to do in order to win (become functional).	protein translation	Using an analogy, explain protein translation to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports
The process of protein translation is a lot like the game of soccer. The rules state that each team has 11 players on the field at any given time. Just as in soccer, there are specific instructions that need to be followed in order for the protein translation process to work correctly. These instructions are encoded within the sequence of nucleotides in the gene and must be read by the translator (ribosome) in order to produce a functioning protein. Like a player on a soccer team, different amino acids can be assigned to each position along the peptide chain depending on what is needed for correct function. This process is repeated over and over again until the entire protein has been produced.	protein translation	Using an analogy, explain protein translation to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 soccer
Protein translation is like a football game. The players are the proteins and the field is the cell. The coach is the mRNA and the instructions for how to play the game are written on his clipboard (the DNA). When he wants one of his players to run onto the field, he calls them over and tells them what to do. The player then goes out onto the field and tries their best to carry out the coach's instructions.	protein translation	Using an analogy, explain protein translation to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 football game
An ecosystem is like a sports team. The players (plants and animals) work together to achieve a common goal (survival). The environment (the climate, the soil, the water) provides the resources that the players need to succeed. Just as in sports, there can be winners and losers in ecosystems.	ecosystem	Using an analogy, explain ecosystem to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports team
An ecosystem can be thought of as a sports team. The players (organisms) all work together to achieve a common goal - winning the game. The environment (the playing field and everything around it) provides the necessary resources for the players to thrive and succeed.	ecosystem	Using an analogy, explain ecosystem to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports team
An ecosystem is like a sports team. The players (organisms) work together to achieve a common goal (survival). They need each other to succeed. The environment provides the resources they need to play and survive. And, just like in sports, when one part of the ecosystem changes, it can have a ripple effect throughout the rest of the system.	ecosystem	Using an analogy, explain ecosystem to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports team
When an athlete makes a move on the playing field, their muscles contract. This contraction is caused by action potentials that start in the brain and travel down the spinal cord to the muscle. The action potentials are like a wave of energy that causes the muscle to contract.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a wave of energy
When an athlete makes a move on the playing field, this action doesn't happen in just one place. For example, when an athlete jumps to spike the ball, they are using energy and muscles throughout their body. This coordinated effort starts with movement in their feet and then sends signals through their nervous system to tell their brain what to do. The brain then sends messages back out to the rest of the body telling it what muscles to activate and how hard to work. Just like athletes need coordination between different parts of their bodies, neurons also need communication between different areas in order for an action potential to be generated and propagate down the axon.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 propagation of a signal through an athlete's body
An action potential is kind of like a runner. Once the runner (action potential) gets going, it's hard to stop it. The same thing happens with an action potential down a neuron. It starts at the synapse and keeps going until it reaches the end of the neuron.	propagation of an action potential down a neuron	Using an analogy, explain propagation of an action potential down a neuron to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 runner
A frog's breathing mechanism is a lot like how we breathe. We inhale (breathe in) oxygen and then exhale (breathe out) carbon dioxide. Frogs do the same thing! They suck in air through their nostrils and then push it out of their mouths.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Using an analogy, explain breathing mechanism of frogs to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 breathing mechanism of humans
Breathing is like the intake and release of air in a car engine. The frog's lungs are like the cylinders in the engine, and the frog's diaphragm is like the piston. When the diaphragm contracts, it pulls downward on the lungs, creating a vacuum that sucks air into them. When the diaphragm relaxes, it pushes upward on the lungs, expelling carbon dioxide-laden air.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Using an analogy, explain breathing mechanism of frogs to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 car engine
When you breathe in, your lungs take in oxygen from the air. The oxygen is then sent to all of the cells in your body. When you breathe out, carbon dioxide is released from your body.	breathing mechanism of frogs	Using an analogy, explain breathing mechanism of frogs to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 breathing mechanism of humans
In sports, there are different layers of players. The first layer is the team's starting lineup. This is the group of players who play at the beginning of the game. They are typically the best players on the team. The second layer is made up of substitutes. These are players who come in to replace injured or tired starters. The third layer is made up of benchwarmers. These areplayers who don't usually see any playing time during a game.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports teams
A layered architecture for a sports team would be one where the players are divided up by position. There would be a layer of quarterbacks, a layer of running backs, and so on. This would allow each player to specialize in their particular role and help the team work together more effectively.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports team######A companys organizational chart can be thought of as a layer cake. There are layers of management, layers of employees, and so on. This allows the company to be organized in a way that makes it easier to manage
An example of layered architecture in sports would be the way a football team is organized. The quarterback, linemen, and running backs are all part of the offensive layer. The defensive line, linebackers, and defensive backs are all part of the defensive layer. Finally, there is the special teams layer which includes players like kickers and punters.	layered architecture	Using an analogy, explain layered architecture to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 football team
In many sports, there are rules that prohibit players from doing certain things in order to make the game fair and more enjoyable to watch. For example, in football, a player cannot run with the ball for more than 10 yards without either passing or being tackled. This rule is in place to prevent one team from running away with the game. The same is true for chemical reactions. In order to keep things fair, we have to put limitations on how much of each reactant can be used. This limiting reactant ensures that all of the reactants are used up and no product is created in excess.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 football and chemical reactions
A limiting reactant is like the referee in a sports game. The referee determines how much of each sport can be played. In the same way, a limiting reactant determines how much of a chemical reaction can take place. An excess reactant is like one of the players on the field. It's not as important as the referee, but it still helps to move things along.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referee and player in a sports game
In sports, there are often times when each team has a certain number of players on the field. If one team has more players than the other team, then they have an excess of players. The other team only has as many players as they need to cover all the bases (or whatever sport is being played). This would be similar to a limiting reactant. A limiting reactant is a substance that limits how much product can be formed in a chemical reaction. In other words, it's the thing that's used up first and prevents any further reaction from happening.	limiting reactant and excess reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant and excess reactant to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a team with more players than the other team######In business, there are often times when a company will have more employees than it needs. This would be similar to an excess reactant. An excess reactant is a substance that is present in
A eukaryotic cell can be thought of as a team of highly specialized athletes working together to win the game. The players (proteins) have specific jobs and work together to carry out the team's strategy.	eukaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain eukaryotic cell to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 team of highly specialized athletes
A eukaryotic cell can be thought of as an extremely complex sports stadium. The stadium has many different sections (organs), each with their own specialized role in supporting the overall function of the stadium. The walls and roof of the stadium keep out the elements, while a sophisticated heating, cooling, and ventilation system ensures that spectators remain comfortable no matter what the weather is like outside. There are security personnel to protect against intruders, ticket-takers and ushers to help spectators find their seats, concession stands for hungry fans, and even a Jumbotron to keep everyone up-to-date on the action. Like a well-run sports stadium, a eukaryotic cell is incredibly complex and highly organized, with each part working together to ensure that the whole organism functions effectively.	eukaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain eukaryotic cell to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a well-run sports stadium
A eukaryotic cell is like a professional sports team. They have many players working together to achieve a common goal. The players are all specialized in their own way and work together to make the team successful.	eukaryotic cell	Using an analogy, explain eukaryotic cell to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 professional sports team

An operating system kernel is like the quarterback of a football team. An operating system's kernel is like the quarterback of a football team. In addition, the quarterback can also make things happen himself by running or throwing the ball. A limiting reactant can be thought of as the "final boss" in a sporting event. Just like in any competition, there is only so much time and space available to complete the task at hand. In this analogy, the athletes are trying to beat the clock (or score against their opponent) while using up as little of the limited resources as possible. The athlete who manages to do this best is typically the one who comes out on top.	limiting reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the "final boss" in a sporting event
A limiting reactant is the amount of a particular chemical that is needed to complete a reaction. In other words, it's the "end-point" for a reaction. For example, in sports, if one team has more players than the other, then the other team will be at a disadvantage. The same concept applies to chemistry - if there isn't enough of one chemical present in a reaction mixture, then the reaction won't proceed as planned.	limiting reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the amount of a particular chemical that is needed to complete a reaction
In sports, there are always a certain number of players on the playing field at once. If one team has more players than the other team, the first team will have an advantage. The same concept applies to chemistry. In a chemical reaction, there are only so many atoms or molecules that can participate in the reaction at any given time. The reactant that runs out first is called the limiting reactant.	limiting reactant	Using an analogy, explain limiting reactant to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the team with fewer players on the playing field
Helicase can be thought of as the player on a team who is always sprinting up and down the field. It works like a zipper, separating the two strands of DNA and then "zipping" them back up again when done. Like athletes who use their muscles to move quickly and powerfully, helicase uses its power to help copy DNA quickly and accurately.	helicase	Using an analogy, explain helicase to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 an athlete

In order to calculate the age of a tree, you would have to measure how much the tree has grown since it was planted. You would then take this measurement and divide it by the amount that the average tree grows in a year. This will give you an estimate for how old the tree is.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 measuring tree growth and averaging it
It is a little bit like keeping score in a game of tennis. You keep track of how many times each player has hit the ball, and then at the end you can calculate who won based on who had more hits. With trees, we measure how much new wood has been added to the tree over time (the number of growth rings), and then we can calculate its age by counting back from the present day.	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 keeping score in a game of tennis
When you are tracking the age of a tree, think of it as being like a runner in a race. The amount of time that has passed since the tree was planted is its "birthdate." Every year afterward is another lap around the track. So, if the tree was planted on January 1st and it's now July 1st, then that means the tree has completed six laps (since January 1st is day number 365).	tree's age calculation	Using an analogy, explain tree's age calculation to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 runner in a race

Anti-stokes scattering can be thought of as the opposite of a tennis ball bouncing off a racket. In anti-stokes scattering, the energy from the photon is transferred to an electron, which then radiates away its excess energy as heat.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 opposite of bouncing a tennis ball off a racket
Anti-Stokes scattering is much like the defensive end in a football game. The defensive end tries to block the opposing team's quarterback from throwing the ball, and anti-Stokes scattering tries to block light from escaping from a material. Just as the quarterback can still throw the ball even if the defensive end blocks him, light can still escape from a material even if anti-Stokes scattering diminishes its intensity.	anti-stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain anti-stokes scattering to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 defensive end in a football game###| light | quarterback
Stokes scattering is like when a quarterback throws the ball to a receiver. The quarterback gives the ball some speed and then at the last second, he pulls his arm back and releases the ball. This causes the ball to spin around as it moves through the air. When it gets close to the receiver, he catches it and then runs downfield with it.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 quarterback throwing the ball to a receiver
Stokes scattering is a process that happens when light hits an object and bounces off of it. This can be compared to the way a ball would bounce off of a wall. The difference is that light doesn't always bounce in the same direction. Some of the light will scatter in all directions, while some may be scattered in specific directions based on the shape and texture of the object.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 ball bouncing off a wall
Stokes scattering is the process of light bouncing off a surface and returning in a new direction. This analogy can be used to explain how this works with sports. When a ball is thrown or kicked, it will bounce off the ground and return to the player. The same thing happens with light; when it hits a surface, it will bounce off and return in a new direction.	stokes scattering	Using an analogy, explain stokes scattering to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 bouncing a ball off the ground###| light | bouncing off a surface
The median lethal dose is the amount of a particular drug or chemical that will kill 50 percent of the people who take it. It can be thought of as the "average" dose needed to kill someone, since it falls in the middle of all the doses that have been tested. For example, if a football player takes 100 milligrams of a certain drug and dies, then you could say that the median lethal dose for that drug is 100 milligrams.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the "average" dose needed to kill someone
If someone takes a lethal dose of a drug, it means that they will die as a result of taking the drug. The median lethal dose is the amount of the drug that is needed to kill 50% of people who take it. In other words, it's the dose that is deadly for half of those who use it.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 amount of a drug needed to kill 50% of people
The median lethal dose is the dose of a substance that kills half of those exposed to it. In other words, it is the amount of a drug or poison required to kill 50% of those who take it. For example, if someone takes 10 ml of a particular pesticide, and 5 people die as a result, then the median lethal dose for that pesticide would be 10 ml.	median lethal dose	Using an analogy, explain median lethal dose to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 amount of a drug or poison required to kill 50% of those who take it

Enzymes are like the referees in a sporting event. They ensure that the game is played fairly and according to the rules.
