ANOVA is like when the NBA looks at how well each team performs in their conference. They look at each team's record and then compare them to the other teams in their conference. This gives them an idea of how each team is doing compared to the others.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 NBA
The two types of anova that we use most commonly in statistics are the one-way anova and the two-way anova. The one-way anova is used when you have a single factor (independent variable) with more than two levels, while the two-way anova is used when you have two factors (independent variables), each with more than two levels. In both cases, the goal is to determine whether there is a difference among the means of the different groups or levels. For example, if you were doing a one-way anova on test scores for three different classes, your goal would be to see if there was a difference in mean test scores among the three classes. If there was a difference, you would then want to know which class had the highest mean score and which class had the lowest mean score.	anova	Using an analogy, explain anova to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 one-way anova, two-way anova
Chemical equilibrium is similar to the game of football. In both cases, there are two teams competing against each other and trying to achieve a goal. In chemical equilibrium, the two teams are molecules and atoms that are in a constant battle to see which one will become more stable. The goal of chemical equilibrium is for the two teams to reach a state where neither side can gain an advantage over the other.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 football
Chemical equilibrium is much like a game of tug-of-war. In the game, two teams pull on opposite ends of a rope until one team eventually wins. In chemical equilibrium, two substances (like molecules or atoms) are pulling against each other until one substance eventually wins by overpowering the other.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 tug-of-war
Chemical equilibrium is similar to a tie game in sports. In both cases, there is no clear winner and the situation remains unchanged over time.	chemical equilibrium	Using an analogy, explain chemical equilibrium to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 tie game in sports
Just-in-time is a production strategy companies use to produce only what is needed, when it is needed. This means that the company does not stockpile goods but produces them as they are ordered by customers. For example, imagine you are a fan of a sporting team. In order to ensure you have a shirt to wear to the next game, the team would need to produce and stock shirts well in advance of the game. However, if the team utilized just-in-time production, it would only produce and stock shirts as orders came in from fans. This would mean that some fans may not be able to get a shirt if they waited until the last minute to order one.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 producing only what is needed, when it is needed
If you are a fan of sports, think about the last game you watched. The players didn't bring any basketballs to the court before the game started. They didn't have to because the ball manufacturer made sure that there were enough balls for all of the players and fans in attendance. The same is true for just-in-time manufacturing. Instead of having a large inventory of materials and products sitting on shelves, companies use just-in-time to only produce what is needed when it is needed. This helps reduce costs and save space.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 having a large inventory of materials and products sitting on shelves
Just-in-time is like a professional sports team that has to be ready to play right when the game starts. The players have to know their plays, and they have to be in good shape so they can run around for hours. The equipment has to be working properly, and everyone needs to be on the same page. If something goes wrong during the game, the whole team falls apart.	just-in-time	Using an analogy, explain just-in-time to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 professional sports team
Adaptive immunity can be compared to the body's natural ability to develop antibodies in response to a virus or bacteria. In much the same way that athletes must continually train and push their bodies to new levels of performance, the immune system must also be challenged with new invaders in order to stay sharp. This allows for quick recognition and elimination of invading pathogens before they have a chance to cause harm.	adaptive immunity	Using an analogy, explain adaptive immunity to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the body's natural ability to develop antibodies in response to a virus or bacteria
Adaptive immunity can be thought of as athletes who are able to adapt and improve their performance in response to training or competition. In the same way, adaptive immunity is able to respond quickly and effectively to new challenges, such as infections.	adaptive immunity	Using an analogy, explain adaptive immunity to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 athletes who are able to adapt and improve their performance
Adaptive immunity is like a professional sports team. The players on the team are very good at playing their specific positions. They have been practicing and playing together for a long time. They know what to do when they are on the field.	adaptive immunity	Using an analogy, explain adaptive immunity to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 professional sports team
Just as a pitcher in baseball can throw different speeds by changing how much effort they put into the pitch, an electric current through a wire also has different speeds depending on how much "effort" is put into it. The unit of measure for this effort is called voltage, and like pitching speed, it's measured in volts. Just as there is a relationship between the speed of a pitched ball and the amount of force used to throw it, there is also a relationship between voltage and current. This relationship was discovered by Georg Simon Ohm and is known as Ohm's law: Current = Voltage/Resistance. In other words, if you know any two of these values (current, voltage or resistance), you can calculate the third.	ohm's law	Using an analogy, explain ohm's law to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 pitcher in baseball
Just as a pitcher in baseball must have good control over the speed and movement of the ball he or she throws, an electrician needs to be able to regulate the flow of electricity through wires. Ohm's law states that the amount of current flowing through a wire is directly proportional to the voltage applied to it, and inversely proportional to its resistance. This means that if you increase the voltage (by turning up the power on an appliance for example), you will also increase the amount of current flowing through the wire. And if you decrease the voltage, by turning down a light switch for example, then you will also decrease the current. If you want more current to flow through a wire however, you can just reduce its resistance by making it thicker (or using a higher-voltage source).	ohm's law	Using an analogy, explain ohm's law to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 pitcher in baseball
Ohm's law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the voltage across the points. In other words, if you increase the voltage, then you'll also increase the amount of current flowing through it. This is similar to how in sports, when one team scores more points than their opponents, they're likely to win the game.	ohm's law	Using an analogy, explain ohm's law to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports
Transcription is like when a coach talks to their team before the game. The coach is telling them what they need to do and how they need to play in order to win. Transcription is basically the same thing, but instead of coaches talking, cells are listening and then doing what they need to in order to create a protein.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a coach talking to their team before the game
Transcription is a bit like making a copy of a document. The original is the DNA molecule, and the copy is the RNA molecule. Just as when you make a copy of a paper document, you have an almost identical duplicate, when transcription occurs, the RNA molecule has almost the same sequence of bases as the DNA molecule from which it was copied.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 making a copy of a document
Transcription is similar to a sport because it takes focus, skill and practice in order to be successful. In transcription, the speaker's words must be accurately written down as they are spoken. This requires concentration and good listening skills. Like any other skill, transcription can be improved through practice - by listening to audio recordings of speeches or interviews and writing out what is said word for word.	transcription	Using an analogy, explain transcription to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sport
RNA polymerase is like a sports referee. It ensures that the game is played fairly and according to the rules. RNA polymerase helps create new strands of DNA by reading the genetic instructions in DNA and creating a copy of them in RNA.	rna polymerase	Using an analogy, explain rna polymerase to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports referee###| creating new strands of dna | creating a copy of them in RNA
RNA polymerase is a lot like the quarterback of a football team. It's responsible for calling the plays and telling all of the other players what to do. RNA polymerase also assembles all of the pieces of DNA into functional proteins.	rna polymerase	Using an analogy, explain rna polymerase to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 quarterback of a football team
RNA polymerase is a bit like the quarterback of a football team. It's responsible for calling the plays and getting the ball moving downfield. In order to do this, it needs some help from other players (enzymes) on the field.	rna polymerase	Using an analogy, explain rna polymerase to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 quarterback of a football team###| enzymes | other players on the field
Ribosomes are like the players on a sports team. The DNA is like the coach, telling the ribosomes what to do. The RNA is like the play-by-play announcer, telling the ribosomes what to do and when to do it. And the proteins are like the athletes, doing all of the work!	ribosome	Using an analogy, explain ribosome to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports team###| DNA | coach###| RNA | play-by-play announcer###| protein | athlete
Ribosomes are like the referees of a football game. They make sure that all of the players are playing by the rules and keeping things fair. In addition, they also help to create new proteins for the game.	ribosome	Using an analogy, explain ribosome to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referee of a football game###| protein | player in a football game
Ribosomes are like the referees of a sports game. They make sure that all of the players are playing by the rules and that the game is fair. Ribosomes also help to create new proteins, which are like the players in a sports game.	ribosome	Using an analogy, explain ribosome to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referee of a sports game###| protein | player in a sports game
Activator protein is a bit like the referee in a sports game. It's responsible for making sure everything runs smoothly and that all of the players are following the rules. In the same way, activator protein helps to ensure that all of the cells in your body are working together as they should be.	activator protein	Using an analogy, explain activator protein to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referee in a sports game
Activator protein is like a referee in sports. It helps to ensure that the game is played fairly and that all players are following the rules. In the same way, activator protein helps to make sure that all of the cells in your body are working properly and following the correct set of instructions.	activator protein	Using an analogy, explain activator protein to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 referee in sports
In the world of sports, activator protein would be the player who gets everyone else on the field pumped up and ready to win. This protein is responsible for initiating all the other proteins that will eventually lead to muscle contractions. Without activator protein, no one would be able to achieve their goal - whether it's scoring a touchdown or crossing the finish line first.	activator protein	Using an analogy, explain activator protein to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 the player who gets everyone else on the field pumped up and ready to win
Electricity is a lot like sports. In both cases, there are teams (or circuits) of players working together to achieve a common goal. Electricity flows through wires (like athletes run on tracks), and it can be used to power things (like TVs and lights). Just as in sports, there are many different types of electric circuits, each with its own unique setup and rules.	electric circuit	Using an analogy, explain electric circuit to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports
When you watch a sports game on TV, the commentators are always talking about the "electricity" of the game. What they mean is that there's a lot of energy and excitement in the air. The same thing happens in an electric circuit. There's a lot of energy flowing through the wires, and it makes everything work.	electric circuit	Using an analogy, explain electric circuit to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a sports game on TV
An electric circuit is a lot like a sports game. There are players (like the resistor and the capacitor), and there's a goal (like the lightbulb). The players have to work together in order to achieve the goal. They can't just do their own thing - they need to cooperate. If one player doesn't do his part, then the whole system falls apart.	electric circuit	Using an analogy, explain electric circuit to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports game
The hydrophobic effect is the tendency of nonpolar molecules to aggregate in water. This can be compared to sports, where nonpolar molecules (players) tend to group together (cluster) when in contact with water (the playing field).	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 sports
The hydrophobic effect can be thought of as a slippery slope. Imagine you are at the top of a hill and trying to sled down it. If the surface is wet, your descent will be slow and difficult because the water will resist your movement. However, if the surface is dry, you will slide down quickly and easily. The hydrophobic effect is responsible for this difference in sliding speed, since water molecules stick together more tightly than non-polar molecules (like those found in oils).	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 a slippery slope
The hydrophobic effect can be explained by using the analogy of two people who are wet. One person is wearing a t-shirt and the other person is not. The person without the shirt will feel colder because their skin is in contact with the cold water. The person with the shirt will not feel as cold because their skin is protected from the cold water.	hydrophobic effect	Using an analogy, explain hydrophobic effect to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 two people who are wet
When you watch a sporting event, the athletes are constantly sending and receiving signals. For example, when a basketball player jumps up to shoot, they are sending a signal telling their body to contract their muscles as hard as possible to launch themselves into the air. When they reach the top of their jump, they receive a signal from their brain that tells them when to release the ball. This process is called signal transduction.	biological signal transduction	Using an analogy, explain biological signal transduction to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 athletes sending and receiving signals
An athletes body is constantly sending signals to her brain telling it what to do. These signals can be thought of as biological transmission signals. The brain interprets these signals and tells the muscles how to respond. This process is very similar to the way in which a cars computer communicates with its various parts, allowing it to run smoothly. In both cases, there must be a clear line of communication for things to work properly.	biological signal transduction	Using an analogy, explain biological signal transduction to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 cars computer communication
In many sports, such as football or basketball, players must react quickly to signals from their coaches in order to make strategic decisions on the field. These signals are transmitted through the air and are picked up by the players' ears. The brain then interprets these signals and sends instructions to the muscles accordingly. This process is known as signal transduction.Similarly, cells in our bodies also receive signals from outside of the cell. These signals can be received by receptors on the cell membrane and then passed along inside of the cell until they reach the nucleus. There, they trigger a series of events that ultimately lead to a change in gene expression. This process is known as signal transduction.	biological signal transduction	Using an analogy, explain biological signal transduction to student who likes sports.	ht	sport	 signal transduction in sports
